reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review was meant for Alpha 13.6.

This review reflects on my non in-depth experience so far of the gameplay update Alpha 13.6. Before Alpha 13 update, the game used to be more fun and balanced (not very, but better than now). But now it's a giant step back and full of bugs, glitches, unbalanced or broken game mechanics.

The game is now quite frustrating to play, even with a friend on a server, we've been killed numerous times by packs of dogs that hated by many, and walking zombies that we can't even launch a one hit kill headshot.

The melee combat is a complete joke. There's no way that you won't get slapped in the face when you're trying to hammer the zombies with your iron club, as their attack animation is instant, you can't dodge them. One of the stupid mechanics is that, 99% of the time you'll get staggered and move like a slug, say goodbye, because you'll get slapped to death as you can't run. Also you'll have a chance to get infected which you'll die after a countdown if you don't take antibiotic.

It's impossible to survive sometimes, unless disabling zombie spawning altogether, as they keep spawning randomly in horde out of nowhere, including dogs which rapes your intestines out within seconds, if you couldn't outrun them. Especially in urban areas, you're literally a dead meat with or without stealthing.

The game UI is frustratingly sloppy, or it's just me since my rig isn't that great. It's difficult to drag items across as it doesn't alway work as intented. A crafting recipe displays to the right which a list of materials is required, but you can't click the listed materials to find out how to craft them, but instead you've to search for it on the crafting categories or through the search box. The hunger and thirst were hidden into the character UI which you're forced to open frequently just to see it, but it's just my opinion. Much worst as you have to drag wearables to your character UI to equip them. Oh, you can hold shift + click inside Character UI to wear them without dragging.

The next was either it's just me or there's no music at all, other than the annoying sounds of dawn and dusk. Character models in online sometimes glitches into white stripped textures or broken animations. It has never happened before as far as I remembered before Alpha 13.

The sounds were bland and ugly, mostly all about slapping. When you plant something it feels like you're slapping the seeds into the ground instead. When the zombies break down blocks or anything it feels like they're slapping it. Even dogs and bees slaps you. Placing blocks feels like you're slapping them down to place them. Literally almost as if there's no there's little sense of distinguishment of sounds between most interactions with different blocks and objects, but still okay.

You can't crawl through a 1 block hole, seriously?

Overall the gameplay is still in the same unrealistic use of logic or broken, why do some food needs pots to cook? Boiling egg with a glass of bottled water doesn't return back the glass-- and it needs an utensil to cook, I mean, really and seriously? Ladders are hideous to climb up, sometimes you just fall to your death trying to lower yourself down. Dogs smash through doors like a sponge, not to mention zombies literally climb ladder faster than you.

Trees and many objects are much harder to break now, although breaking some of these resources drops continuous materials into your inventory before they are destroyed from the world. One of the trees glitched and stayed after breaking it.

The zombies were like made of adamantite. An explosive mine didn't even kill one from the horde attack. Literally takes dozens of arrows to their skull made of adamantite before they stop dancing everywhere.

I didn't even get to explore the game in depth as I can't even have a minute of peace rustling through the demanding UI, and dying left and right, in such unforgiving gameplay.

Other than the negative side of the game, the graphics is fine and quite beautiful. It would be great to have options to toggle different types of zombies from spawning.

For this update,
Gameplay - 5/10
Graphic - 7/10
Music - 1/10
Sound - 5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7 days to die. WOW. Where do I begin? The game offers so many options in such an early stage, it almost feels complete! However, it is not. Since this is an Early Access review, it will be wrote as such.

TL;DR at the bottom

Gameplay
7 Days To Die, in my opinion, is a good cross between what DayZ could have been, with Minecrafts building mechanics and crafting, overhauled. From time to time, the controls can be a bit clunky, swaying around in a direction you hadn't intended. Mocap hasn't been integrated yet so walking, running, and other physical motions are dry.  It is however, very polished, and does not interfere with playability. The game itself handles fine on any well equipped PC.

UI & Visuals
Options don't boast too many options in terms of video settings just yet, but offer enough to allow you to tune it to run either performance or quality. It isn't recommended to run it in ultra high settings (unless you can handle it of course), but at a mid point to save yourself from the lag in clustered POI's like cities, neighborhoods, and possible player built settlements.

The best part visual wise out of the whole thing is that the entire world is smooth. Everything looks natural and polished, and breaks and modifys just like any other voxel game. It is a learning curve to get used to it if you're just coming in from Minecraft, cause the angles of the ground, cliffs, rocks, etc can be offset looking sometimes, but it looks great and plays fine. The worlds themselves keep getting better and better looking with each update. As of Alpha 10.4, this game already looks wonderful. With the right tweaks, its is a place full of wildlife, and the undead.

The UI is nice. It has changed a few times in the course of Alpha 7 through 10, but overall is sleek and very efficient, showing you just your essential meters, belt, and compass. The Day and time count are small enough to be out of the way, and still legible. Nothing sticks out in a manner that would block peripherals, so you get full view of whats in front and next to you.

Mechanics
The mechanics to the game in general are fantastic. The crafting is what keeps me coming back time and time again. There are literally hundreds of recipes to choose from, and if that's not enough, you can make your own recipes out of items you couldn't normally craft! The community is good at coming up with unique ways to make the not so useful items useful again, and adding the recipes are as easy and copy and paste.

There are some glitches and errors that can be frustrating when crafting. At times, the forge will eat" your materials

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been hooked on this game for weeks now. Here's the elevator speech:

Is it a Day Z clone?  Yeah, sure.  It's what Day Z could have been if it wasn't abandonwear.  The developers are very active and release updates constantly.
Is it a Minecraft clone?  Sure, you could say that too.  It takes some of the best features of Minecraft and implements them well.  Yes, as others have said, it is a Day Z meets Minecraft love child, in all the right ways.  The crafting system is deep, tons of loot and a vast variety of it.  Lots and lots of building options as well.
Now to address some of the ugly stuff a few negative reviewers have said.  Yes, the game is rough around the edges.  It is and ALPHA.  Sometimes things will happen, for better or worse, due to error.  Sometimes it's tragic, sometimes it works to your advantage, sometimes it's just hilarious, but when you play this game, you need to know you're playing an alpha.  Yes, some of the textures are ugly.  Yes, there are balance issues.  Yes, some features are less than reliable.  That all being said, this is the best alpha I've ever played, and it is always getting better.
It is also true that there is a learning curve.  Just like any game with deep crafting, building, etc... because there is a lot you CAN do, there are a lot of things to know.  Most of it is pretty intuitive, but you will find yourself reading forums and the wiki alot.  It's just that kind of game.
I've been reading about rude moderators in the forums.  I don't know much about that, I jump in to find an answer to a question I have and jump right back out.  That may or may not be true, but at the end of the day, it doesn't make the game any less fun.

BOTTOM LINE:  If you like open world survival/crafting games, this is the best one of the lot, and I've played them all.  Better than RUST, better than DAY Z.  WAY better than all the other abandonwear and halfassed rip offs in this genre that polute the Steam store.  Is this a clone?  Yeah, it is.  But it's one of those rare clones that's better than it's own inspiration.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7 days to die survival guide.

Civilization has failed, you are one of very few survivors lost & alone in a desolate world.  Equipped with only your head & hands you must survive in a pocket of habitable land surrounded by blasted rubble & irradiated wastelands.   To make matters worse, the radiation has mutated a common flu bug into a terrifying disease capable of raising the dead.  Can you survive?

First & foremost you must become a scavenger, loot every item you see. Pick up every rock, feather, stick, or scrap of metal you find, every item has a use.  You will need tools, if you happen to spawn close to a road carefully check for vehicles to loot.

There are usually also zombies around cars, don’t let your guard down.   If you are lucky you may find a tool or weapon, regardless you should construct a stone axe.  It may be crude, but it is the best multi-purpose tool at the start.  It can be used to dig holes, chop trees, break boulders and in a pinch can also bash in the head of an attacking zombie.  Once you have a home, it can be used to repair blocks.

How do you survive the menacing zombie horde?  Running away is always the safest option, but sometimes you have to stand and fight. What would Darryl do?  (WWDD?) Darryl would find a crossbow, or better yet MAKE One. This is where all those sticks & stones you've been picking up are going to come in handy. While you can find feathers in rubbish piles, loot  birds nests, AS they often have eggs, which you can eat - preferably cooked.  All the foods you cook can also be eaten raw, if you don’t mind at bit of food poisoning, which is preferable to starving.  If you have full or high health, and a water supply the food poisoning wont kill you, just make life uncomfortable.  Same thing with Diarrhea from drinking murky water.

In later versions of the game these will impact your wellness" which most likely will affect things like movement and loot speed

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh boy where to start.  I am ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at the developers thats for sure.

The new patch has rendered a once great game unplayable.  Granted, I like the new gameplay changes, what I don't like is how I can't enjoy online multiplayer anymore.  The latency and frame rate is unbearable.  You will get drops to 1-5 fps anytime more then 3 zombies enter on screen.  More then that?  Forget about it, you'll be dead before your game unfreezes.  It seems they spent more time on their new motion capture zombies that they are so proud of rather then spending time optimizing performance.  This is of course running the game on the lowest settings possible, making the game look like it jumped right out of 2001.  This causes their new HD zombies to stand out even more, since they clash with the low res environment. The lag is unbearable, try as many servers as you might, its all the same deal and everyone has this issue.

Its funny because I was playing the game right before a13 dropped.  It was running fine.  Then I try to jump on that same server after the update and it had the framerate of a polaroid camera.  It was unplayable.  Of course I didnt get to enjoy that long as I was now being kicked for ping.  This is of course less then half an hour after I was playing on that same server just fine, no lag, no framerate drops.

The best part is the fanbase and official forums.  Having an issue with the game?  Don't bother reporting it.  If it isn't a posted consisting of nothing but praise for the gods that The Fun Pimps, you will be ravenously attacked by the fanboys.   All the resultings posts will insist that their version of the game runs flawlessly and that it must be your fault.  That is if you aren't banned immediately for daring to not get on your knees and pray to the devs.

As you can see I actually like this game alot, I have over 300 hours logged.  Its one of, or rather was one of my favorite games.  Now I can't even play it.

Save your money.  If after 7 months of waiting for an update they honestly couldn't test this update and see how poorly it ran then they really don't deserve your money.  Even if they delayed the update for another year I would tolerate that so long as I could actually play it.  Instead they kept giving release dates, which they shouldn't have, kept failing to meet said release dates, then rushed out a broken mess.

10/10 guys

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7 Days To Die is certainly a great game. A minecraft like shooter with zombies. What more could someone want? While the game is in alpha stage, it still has a lot to offer. There's a large list of things I could talk about, but I don't want to write a book. Essentially the game is minecraft with zombies. However, compared to some other free roam games out there, you are very limited to what you can explore. Additionally, the things you can find get very boring once you have explored enough. Another thing to keep in mind when looking at this game is the lack of objective. If you are someone who needs a goal, this won't satisfy you very much. Its more of a sandbox as of now. Something else that I consider very important when buying this game is to make sure you have some pals to play it with. You will find yourself bored VERY quickly when playing alone. Also, the online community isnt the greatest, so I would not put your trust into that.

TL;DR - The game is pretty good for the money, while it has its flaws, its only in alpha. Before you purchase, make sure you have some friends to play with and watch some gameplay videos.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you love creating a la minecraft and love zombies, this is a great concept of a game.  Though I've never played it fully in singleplayer, that's probably the best way to go, or on a secure private server well monitored by mods and admins.
I spent weeks building far away from noob spawn in a tungsten base.  Next I set up a base at hub city/noob spawn covered by over 64 claim blocks.  Once a cheater found it would be incredibly hard to break into my base, they just reassigned all claim blocks to themselves, taking ownership of my base.  Thus, weeks of effort are easily wiped out in a matter of seconds by individuals with no integrity. :p  What's the point in keeping interested in a game so exploitable?  Guess I'm forced to stay way out in fringes.  Kind of makes the point moot. (PvP server, btw.)
So while I recommend it, in concept, your experience may vary.  We'll see what comes as it matures.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 21 Aftermath
Come nightfall, I lasted for less than an hour before the zombies got me.  They clustered on the north wall until they broke through, climbing over each other's corpses.  At least I could see them better this time with the torches I'd placed.  I picked off some with arrows, but I should've used my meager supply of bullets.  In the end they surrounded me from the inner staircase and the 2nd floor balcony.  They chewed through the wall, the doors, and even halfway into the foundation, though the building's still structurally sound.

Goals for next week: forge a pickaxe and start an escape tunnel from my base to the natural cavern I found earlier.  Mine for iron in the process.  Add another layer of spikes around the base and repair/strengthen the walls.  Stretch goal: start a garden with the corn & potatoes I've scavenged.

***

Here's the thing.  The zombies are coming in 7 days, and every week they get stronger.  So while there's a big world to explore and it may seem downright tranquil now, you'd better be one focused taskmasker if you're going to be prepared in time.

You'll go back and forth between nomadic and sedentary life.  You'll start out punching grass, and charring that pig you clubbed to death over a campfire (if you don't have to devour it raw that is).  You'll progress, hopefully, until you're sitting pretty in your reinforced bunker, dining on bear stew and blueberry pie.

You'll likely always be desperate for something, be it clean water, medicine, building material, metals, or that one part you need to make a gun.  Missing any one of these for long can be fatal, because everything connects with everything else.  The crafting is intuitive, and makes good use of the materials available.  For instance, when you kill an animal, you can get meat, fat, bone, and hide.  Each of these is useful for something very different, and while you may have an excess of some stuff, you'll be wise to never throw things away if you have the space.

The game is forgiving enough without being too forgiving.  By default, when you die you can respawn on or near your bed, and all your stuff is in your backpack where you died.  However, once in a while my backpack disappears and I lose some of my best stuff (bug?).  In multiplayer you'll have to defend yourself from other survivors, who are craftier at getting to you and your stuff.  But land claim blocks and locks are meant to alleviate this.  I've only played single player and with friends, so I can't say how good or bad PvP may be.

Early Access Review

The building in this is a lot of fun, considering you have to take the structural integrity of your design into account, and the enemies are surprisingly clever about getting around your defenses~

The wepons are easy to use and feel very satisfying~ Scavenging around for food and guns is dangerous and rewarding!

And you have to be careful, if you don't maintain your base, the horde might just dig the foundation out from under it and your whole base might come crumbling down!

Very fun to play with friends, and a very very promising early access game all around! Love it~ <3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is so cool! I'm not worthy! I'm not worthy!

No seriously, this game is excellent. For being an alpha game still under heavy development, it is fun. Several friends and I have made a few multiplayer servers to play on for days to weeks at a time. The developers are very active in the community with the players. While they do have a planned agenda, they do accept ideas from the players or suggestions and incorporate them into the game. This game will also be open for players to mod.

While the graphics aren't the best I've ever seen, they aren't too shabby and they are friendly to low-end PC's. There are still a lot of bugs to be fixed. The content at the moment is a little limited in terms of building materials and the different types of buildings/structures that you encounter. However, they are consistently adding new content. I expect the finished product game to be nothing like the alpha I started playing a few months ago (for better or worse).

Gameplay is survival horror rpg. You start with nothing and build your way up to having consistent food, water, weapons, and shelter. Alternatively, you could be a nomad and live off of the buildings and structures you encounter on your journey. Either way, beware of the 7 day night horde. Health, stamina, hunger, thirst, and general wellness are all taken into account while playing. Negative things such as becoming infected by a zombie, broken legs, dysentery, and bleeding out are all things that you will have to deal with during your travels.

The zombies in this game are a force to be reckoned with. During the day, they are slow and can be dealt with individually if one is careful. If one becomes alert to your presence, many in the area will soon come to investigate. Fighting one zombie can easily turn into running away from fifteen. When the sun sets, the game becomes a whole new animal. Since the zombies run full speed at night, things can be absolutely terrifying. The sheer suspense of hearing the zombies search for you at night can be unnerving. Or the times where you are looting a house and you accidentally slam the cabinet doors in the kitchen only to realize that they heard you and they are coming.

Did you ever wish that a game like Minecraft had formidable enemies that would smell you, hear you, and hunt you?Enemies that will dismantle your base and annihilate you if you didn't take proper precautions to protect yourself? That is this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As previously stated by many others, this game has tremendous potential, but it's also greatly lacking in content with correlations to its price. The concepts are somewhat new, and this is what makes it enjoyable, but because of the lack of content, the joy rapidly diminishes in the first few hours. The game is too pricy at this point in developement. I believe the price should be around 15$. Here are a few specific reasons why:

1. There is only one map, and although its quite big, most of it is just terrain rather than interactive.(unless you consider dirt and trees interactive)
2. Not enough crafting. There are an awesome amount of weapons, but the traps, tools and building blocks are lacking in variety. The game features farming, but there are only 3 different plants.
3. Bugs and glitches. Sometimes creatures are stil spawning in thoroughly lit areas. When mining, the blocks sometimes fly out, or fall into space occupied by another block, meaning it cannot be accessed directly without removing the other block. When looking for multiplayer servers, it does not correctly display the current number of players in the server.
4. Spawn trapping. When you dont have any weapons or beds,  and you die during the night, it is almost impossible to do anything without waiting till daytime. The zombies run at you and deal relatively massive amounts of damage, and they also spawn in waves.
5. Lack of instructorial information. The interface is initally difficult to decipher, and the lack of any tips reduces our learning to nothing more than just clicking a button and waiting to see if it does anything.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For some reason, many of the negative reviews seem to have been voted most helpful, but if you look at the gameplay hours on the negatives compared to the hours people have on the positive reviews, it's clear that this game has a very loyal, dedicated fanbase, and oodles of replay value.

In a crowded field of zombie survival games, or just plain survival games, this one stands out for several reasons. First off is the fact that the enemies pose so much of a threat, that it really encourages cooperation. This game is a must to play with friends. There's something really satisfying about building up your defenses, setting up traps, and then fighting together to survive the night. It's something that Minecraft hints at, and Fortnite promises (if it ever gets released), but this game delivers.

The PvP features are a bit lacking and, being an early access alpha title, there are quite a few missing features, bugs, glitches, and security issues. Cheats and hacks are still a problem on public servers. However, as a co-op base building / tower defense / horde survival type game, this one is tough to beat.

7 Days to Die is a genuinely fun game, blending the crafting, building, and destructibility aspects of Minecraft with the over-the-top frenzied action of Serious Sam or Dungeon Defenders, where the enemies come at you in almost overwhelming numbers. It's already a blast to play, and continues to get better and better with each new patch. If this is what they've managed to come up with for an alpha release, I can't wait to find out what the finished product will look like.

Don't let the haters fool you, look at how much time the positive reviewers have put into this game. Pick it up, make friends, play it with them, and go nuts building and killing zombies! You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WARNING:
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME (For the time being, at least)

This used to be one of the funnest games to play when it was around Alpha 7-10 (as you'll notice many other players have commented in the reviews) but right now, on what I believe is Alpha 13, this game is just horrible. It's overly complex with all kinds of menus and systems for crafting that make it take half an hour just to try to accomplish the simplest of tasks. It's become buggy and laggy as hell, and I know it's not my PC because I can play games like Battlefield 4, Crysis 3, Fallout 4, etc. on near-max settings and they're 10x's smoother than this game is now.

Sure, this game was absolutely fantastic once upon a time, but now the devs have completely trashed this game AND up'ed the price (talk about adding insult to injury).

I cannot stress this enough: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW (Alpha 13). You WILL regret your purchase, I promise you. The devs need to straighten this game out before anyone else should bother wasting time on it. It's truly sad to see how they completely trashed what was once a gem of a game... :(

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I feel the need to address the detractors of this game because 7 Days to Die is like a slew of my favorite games adroitly combined into a single title. I have eagerly awaited every update thus far and will play the game now and in the future.

Some people say that this game is too difficult and favors veteran players. There are many possible difficulty levels available for players to choose from, so if you feel that the game is too difficult, you can simply lower the constraints to accomodate yourself. Loot can respawn more often, airdrops can come more quickly and zombies can be made weaker. 7DTD is not just geared toward veteran players - every game ever created would then be geared towards people who have played longer; that's just simple logic. Playing longer makes you better, and if you're new, put the difficulty at lowest.

If you found bugs in the game and you posted them on the forums, I commend you and think it's unfortunate that your good intents were met with hostility. You did your part in reporting bugs and then some, but forum moderators can make mistakes independent of the development team. Bugs will be fixed in due time, issues will be sorted out, and the forums are not integral in your ability to play and enjoy the game. I usually avoid forums in the first place, but I'm sorry that this had to happen to some of you anyway.

I also would like to remind potential players of this game that everyone will have their own opinions, but it's important to formulate your own. I was not hesitant in buying the game at all because I like voxel games and zombie survival. There is so much to enjoy about a game still in development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I went up to a glass shower door and broke it with a stone axe because it's fun breaking glass, then I noticed it dropped glass shards. I examined the item and right clicked. And turns out you can eat it. So I ate it by accident and died seconds later from internal bleeding.

Today's life lesson of the day: don't eat glass- you'll die.

In all seriousness this game is quite fun, especially for being in Alpha.
The character creator, the world generator, weapons, crafting, cooking, survival, all that.

Especially the character creator - I created numerous alien freakazoid goblin zombie things on it already, including one that looks like Michael Jackson.

The survival is also somewhat of a realistic simulation. For instance, it gets you searching for a place to stay during the night and that's quite a challenge itself because the biomes in the game all have different zombie spawn rates (as far as I know at least) and once you settle down you must search the local area for supplies like books to learn recipes, food, water, clothes and other supplies.

So, do I like the game? yes.
Should you get it? Maaaayyybe, it's great fun with friends, but can be a bit dull if you are playing by yourself, although when you are playing by yourself things such as mentioned at the very start of a review may happen.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Slightly Addictive gameplay?? with nearly 1200 hours under my belt I'd say yes indeed.
The game just keep's getting better but never losing what makes it addictive, the constant work towards something better, with the constant fear of loss.

The fully destructable world and the voxel building and crafting put it a step ahead of ARK : Srvival and the like, because you can build whatever you like, trenches, bases, defenses, it's not predefined like it is in games like ARK.
It's LEGO, you craft block by block.

The new RPG Skills and Perk tree really do a great job in fleshing out your character and brings skill benefits for working together in a small group with specialists, you can still play solo, you just need to be a little more frugal with your skill points spending.

Lots of servers out there, hugly active multiplayer, building your own server is pretty easy if yo udont like the way others are set up.

AAA+++ for the Fun Pimps, they keep working on this little gem of a game and the love and care shines through.

Follow Joel on the dev diary here http://joelhuenink.tumblr.com/

Pros:

This game is something

It's almost like an HD version of minecraft in an apocolaptic world (except there is a building limit to how many stuff you can stack and physics apply)

This game is twice as fun if you have a friend or 2 to play with.

They game will definetly keep you entertained hours on end.


Cons:

The zombie dogs in this game really ruin the expirience because they are one of the hardest to kill and this is a big problem if you have just spawned and your only weapon is your fists. So if you see one - run.

Early Access Review

This is my first review, so i apologise if it is rubbish!

I started playing this game a few months back and have to say i really love it, even my partner plays it now, there is always something to do, building to upgrade food to collect etc etc.

I see a fair few reviews of people saying that its to hard, you spawn then end up dying to quick, just one little tip for people starting out,  who havnt played the game. get some wood get some grass grab some stone, make your self a crossbow find some birds nests / trash for feathers and make some crossbow bolts, you can do that within the first few minutes of starting the game, makes it a lot easier then to not get murdered and chewed on by zombies.

Overall, in my opinion the games is brilliant and there is still more to come! graphics may not be the best, but hey! its Early Access its not going to be top notch just yet, but there is still hours upon hours of fun to be had, whether it be solo or with friends.

Huge selection of things to craft, large area to uncover, buildings to search, make a fortress, dig a hole, whatever you want! Just craft a crossbow first! (or aim for the heads).

I personally reccomend this game to anyone who likes survival crafting building kill the dam zombies! (games)

Dont give up to soon! try again!   10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review for 7 Days to Die

I'm going to write this review based on version 10.3 (29'th of december 2014)


- 7 Days to Die continues to impress with ever increasing patches and fixes coming from the development team. I must admit i was fearing for this game to turn out like the crappy Day Z or something like that, but the way this game has turned out is truly remarkable. It is so good i even bought a copy for my younger brother just to support the development team. Why is it good you ask? Well, the game contains key features regarding the freeworld, survival, RPG genres, which for example is interactive wellness needs (food, water, medication etc.) and extremely detailed building recipes and such, example: you cut down a tree, create planks, create wooden frame, fortify wooden frame, reinforces = zombie proof. This might sound like a lot of micromanagement but i assure you, it is not. You are always active while playing this game, always looking for ways to get better guns or better resources to fortify your magnificent Fort Knox of Reinforced concrete with a 100 meter deep trench......... With some wooden spikes in the bottom of course.

In short, most amazing game ever with the greatest potential i have witnessed.

Sorry for the long post steam-community here is a little song to cheer you up: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ

A great new entry to the zombie/sandbox/survival genre.  I find myself playing this more than the others, open procedural world, easy server or client/host setup, huge community, mods, help, etc.

Game worlds are like MC, have as many as you like, connect to whoever is open, multiple large biome types, procedural cities and prefabs, plenty of options.

And the game is genuinely fun to play and build in both.  Be warned, not shown zombies go WWZ at night :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alpha Build Review as of January 2015:

7D has a ton of content especially for an alpha. Compare it to other alphas like back when Minecraft was in alpha, and the quality is also notable. Few crashes in my 100 hours of play, biggest technical issue I have is a greatly variable framerate, on a GTX 970 still dipping to 20fps at times.

Overall, people might say it's a Minecraft/DayZ... and it pretty much is, but in the good way. A challenge to scavenge, a variety of changing, persistent PVE as time goes on, and a fairly hefty crafting system that mimics Minecraft's simplicity-crafting-grid type scenario. The voxel system is a neat physics addition compared to most builders, I'd say this plays as a more realistic, harder Minecraft, but with a wide variety of game settings to tailor to your playstyles, a great addition.

If you like the builder-survival-crafting type games, I'd say this is one of the best at the moment, with a real reason to team up, especially on a public server, and not a total PVP deathmatch-with-zombies like DayZ or H1Z1. Can't say it's the most amazing of course, but I definitely enjoy my time with it and will hope they keep fleshing out the bugs and PVE side of things.

If you are looking at all the survival/zombie/crafting games out there at the moment and wondering which one to pick...this one wins hands down, get it and you won't regret it. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fantastic in many ways and has the ability to be by far the most entertaining survival game made, but a few things hold it back from being perfect. First lets talk about the good parts of the game.

Pros

-Challenging pve
-Great crafting system
-Map generation is great
-Graphicly getting better with each update
-Building mechanics are done right
-Plenty of levels of difficulty allowing the game to be as hard or easy as you like
-level up system with item quality based on level
-Craftable minibike

Now on to the cons of the game

Cons

-Lots of bugs that can cause items to dupe or dissapear
-PVP has hackers (this just happens not much to be done about this)
-Takes way too many materials to make the highest end buildings
-Sometimes my legs randomly break VERY annoying
-Updates come out very slowly for the game has been in early acess for quite some time.

Overall this game is a 9.2/10 and extremely time consuming if you get addicted to sandbox games like me. In my opinion its a fantastic game if you can get over some of the bugs and will keep you entertained for a couple hundered hours so it's well worth the money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just because you are unique, does not mean you are useful.

7 Days to Die has a problem. It has many problems.
Is the Zombie AI awful.....yeah...
Are the weapons incredibly stock and unappealing.....Yeah...
Is there no risk involved when you can just run back to your house and get your shotgun back after dying.....Yeah...

But most of all, 7 Days to Die has one serious problem. It mixes and matches far too many concepts into spots where they do not belong. Base building is slow and unrewarding, when even stone walls can be broken down by the horde, and when breaking the game mechanics is the only way to provide safe shelter. Mining is slow and unrewarding, digging for hours to only come up with coal and nitrite, only to say ♥♥♥♥ it, and use dynamite to blow open caves simply because you can. Combat is slow and unrewarding, when even a huge horde can bring you nothing but some bullets and pieces of paper. Crafting is slow an unrewarding, and in essence, bland, using the usual PICKAXE, AXE, EXPLOSIVE, FENCING objects to build, bringing nothing new or surprising to the table. This game may be an alpha, it may have some quirks, and it may not be perfect yet.

But if steam had a return button, I'd be smashing the refund key until Gabe kicked down my door, gripped my wrist ferociously, and lovingly whispered into my ear, Cut that ♥♥♥♥ out"

It's an alpha
date: and it isn't a fun one
hoursPlayed: and certainly not worth a moment of your time."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alpha 13 has taken away and messed up a lot of aspects of this game that I loved, but I still recommend it because it's still fun.

But I want the old forges back (where you poured iron/brass/glass/etc into a mold of an object and got that object instead of feeding a forge resources and having it poop back out whatever you want if it has the right tools attached to it). I want different types of meat back, as another reviewer said. Bear stew, venison stew, rabbit stew having different benefit levels? Loved it! I don't like the new UI very much and I feel like crafting has been ruined. The old display of food/water status above health and stamina was great! Why take that out? The server I play on has it modded back in and I'm grateful for that.

The skill system is... really kind of ridiculous. Alpha 9 was the most fun I've ever had in a survival/crafting game. It was simple enough yet complex enough. I liked how crap fell on the ground when you cut trees or broke stones instead of just flooding into my inventory. I do like the new zombies but the assemble" crafting system for weapons/power tools irritates me to no end
date: as does the fact that I can no longer make molds for gun components and make them at my forge. What happened
recommended: guys? I'm really holding out hope for A14."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Spawned in rainy snow biome, made full clothes then got wet. This led to stage 2 hypothermia that drained my stamina until I was mauled by a horde.

Spawned in the same biome 3 miles away from where I died and this time I stood on my camp fire. Five real time minutes later, I finally stopped having hypothermia, but was still too cold to go get more fuel. Horde found my camp and chased me off. I soon froze.

I was able to escape the snow, but ran into a city where a fat police spit at me. Was getting wet the entire time. Chased into the snow again and had the second situation happen and died.

By this time I had so little max health that anything could take me out. Got stunned by a lumberjack horde and died.

The run I was able to make a base, the game practically forced one style of building or else your base will crumble and all the above will happen to you over and over again.

Also, you need a dedicated server to play on, meaning you need to configure your network settings and spend at least an hour setting things up to have all the above happen to your merry band of survivors. Or you could buy a server from a third party hosting service.
Or you could use the game's abyssmal Survival MP" function that breaks every few in game days and forces you to reset your progress.

TL;DR This game is another example of wasted potential

reviewText:
Early Access Review

hey guys this is my very 1st review on steam for a game

i played over 400 hours of this game and i seen it go from simple minecraft game, to a beautiful looking world.

but here my pro and cons to the game

pro+
weapon and item crafting is very easy to use
gets updated a lot e.g monthy for the big updates
6 different types of zombies and they acting different like e.g there is a frost zombie which is harder to kill
pvp or pve, which is nice change if you want to do coop or pvp, plus pvp can be brutal at times and makes some great fights
big sandbox world, where there is lots of player content and everything can be destroyed
the friend lists in game is very easy to use, to find your friends to team up
night and day brings different experience's for e.g day time u can walk past zombies and in the night you better run
hunting can be fun and there is a reason to kill for e.g to make armor and food

cons-
lag on servers can be very bad at times
people do exploit the game at times
bugs like e.g losing items that you have in your backpack and zombies do glitch from time to time and falling though the map and map not loading up
you can not make your own servers unless you have a dedicated server
sometimes it can be very hard to connect to a game
airdrops dropping in rad zone

so that my review and if you have any qustions about the game please let me know and i be happy to tell you all about it

and if you got the game and want somewhere friendly to go i own a server for new and old players a like

so i see you guys in the wastelands :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like zombie games more sandboxy, if you also liked the idea of minecraft and others like it but hated the oldschool look and feel then you'll like this. I mostly play on scavenger as it suits my laid back attitude, but if your a hardcore nutter then max out the settings and see how long you live for. You can play multiplayer or single (I prefer single mode) and the game has a whole lotta things you can fiddle with to get the type of game you want. Gather supplies, build stuff or just tunnel underground and pray, you play how you like which is epic imo. Even though it's in the early stages and thus changing at times (sometimes needin a good tweek) it's good fun I have have no regrets buying into, it unlike a few other greenlight games I've bought.

A14 and all I can say is from epic to more epic, when this game hits release in the future it will set a new standard, even at this early stage it is an awesome blend of survival/crafting/rpg elements. I only play single player and lan with my wife and I have not had a game that has so many options or different ways to play it. You should be warned though, the game has two sides to it, first you must learn to survive the enviroment and then there's the z's, both will try to kill you, good luck.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Why This Alpha Game Is Worth Paying For..

Reviewing a Z game nowadays almost seems played out but I feel this one is necessary due to the current amount of them available.Since L4D released in '09 the Z craze has definitely infected the gaming community. Fast forward to now~

I've recently played DayZ, Infestation, Dead Linger, Contagion, and now 7D2D...
A few noticable difference that stand out:
1. 7D2D is very playable in it's current state with a highly interactive Dev team.
2. Everthing in the world is destructable and usually provides resources.
3. Your toon can jump!
4. The world is persistent offline and online which means your structures and mines stay there until destroyed.
5. Crafting System!! <<-- This is one of my favorite aspiects and I cannot  WAIT until they add more recipes!!
6. Construction. That's right you can build the zombie survivor base you've always dreamed about.
7. Miining.  Mining ores then crafting items. Mining with explosives! +10
8. High scaleability of server configuration settings which gives complete control of the game environment.
9. Hunting and Cooking!! <<--Venison stew anyone? Maybe a blueberry pie..
10. Farming. Rooftop Farming FTW!! +10
11. Zombies! As many or as few as you like, depending on game settings.
a. Zombies Never Run = 0 or 1
b. Zombies Always Run = 0 or 1
c. Zombies Only Run At Night = 0 or 1
d. Zombie Agression = 1-5
e. Zombie memory time? 60 - 180 seconds
f. Zombies are lootable!
12. Character XP/Level system is there but not functional, yet..
13. Mod support and toolkit for modeling/worldbuilding and custom scripting

Hopefully, this review was helpful for you, I'd like you to spend your money on the right game the first time.
I'm sure the others will mature to some great things, but this game is FUN. 7D2D shines amongst the rest in my book and those 13 reasons are why.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From my first try I was hooked on 7 Days to Die.  I missed the Kickstarter for this game, unfortunately, picking it up on the advice of a trusted Youtube Letsplayer at the stage of Alpha 1, and thought, wow this is for me.

From its very early stage of development this game was fully and excitingly playable, and somehow you could tell it had legs.  This game was exciting, realistic, fully working with my PC spec. and totally absorbing.  Blocky graphics didnt matter;  I loved the  way everything but everything is destructable and craftable.  Many have said this is DayZ meets Minecraft, and that is true in all the good ways.  Building your own base, finding ways to keep hordes out, farming your own crops and killing your food after the post apocalypse world is looted out was a challenge, taxing and deeply satisfying.

Its not enough to dig a hole in the dirt and wait for sunrise; Zombies in this game are worthy opponents.  You will NOT survive if you are out at night, or if your base is weak - these undead are fast, scary, loud and deadly.  Running away is not an option.

Then as the long awaited Alpha 2 came out... everything got better and some things got even harder to survive.  Then further updates, more challenges, better graphics, sophisticated crafting tools, this is the gift of a game that keeps on giving.  Just as you thought you had it sussed, new zombie types were introduced, tougher landscapes, zombies that could smell you, hear you, sense you, hunt you.  But its not all in their favour, we now have stealth, smooth terrain, craftable guns, repairable weapons, it just keeps on getting better with each update, and slight (non gamebreaking) bugs are fixed every week and released every friday, so that for a YouTuber like me
(  https://www.youtube.com/my_videos?o=U  )
its hard to keep up with the stuff the Fun Pimps roll out.

Practically every aspect of the game is adaptable to your level and your enjoyment.  You can play on their default settings or you can make it harder if you like Hard Core, or easier if you want to relax and choose less stress.  Want more loot? fine.  What fewer zombies? fine,  longer days and shorter nights? choose your ratio.  Want Airdrops of supplies? you got it.  Tailor the game just how you like it.  Singleplayer is great, Multiplayer is there if you want company, PvE or PvP, all are available.  The smooth terrain now makes it less like Minecraft or DayZ -  those days of that comparison are over.

I believe that any Survivalist (the name we give ourselves in this game) will tell you there have been times when all of us have said Darn
hoursPlayed: right?"   None of the minor problems along the way to Alpha 8.3 (at time of writing this review) have made the game unplayable
voteText: 7 Days to Die in Alpha is better than most games on full and final release
helpfulPercent: better than I could possibly have expected and worth much more than I paid for it.\n\nI fully recommend this game at whatever stage you come on board.  More bang for your buck - definitely."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off I would like to say this is a great game, and hope someday in the future when it is completed this game gets ported to the consoles. There is no game that I know of that has crafting, survival, zombies, multiplayer of this caliber. This game is gorgeous. From the moment the sun sets in game, to the moment the sun rises the game is awesome.
When I first tried the game, I was very skeptic, I was like great another zombie shooter game, boy was I wrong.

The amount of depth the game has at this early stage is pretty impressive. The Developers are always actively keeping us up-to-date on their progress and constantly showing pics of improvements coming to the game on their blog.

I'm currently playing on a public pvp server alpha 9.3. When you first go into the game, it is extremely overwhelming as the learning curve is steep. There is no tutorials so you basically would have to ask people online, or look at some YouTube, wiki, and do some trial and error to learn some of the games mechanics. First person shooter players will feel right at home here, as the controls are basic.

When you start your first game, you start out at virtually very little items. You quickly learn that zombies are all around you and you have a limited food supply. You quickly scrounge around in cars, trash bins for food and must collect items to craft basic items to help you with your survival.

The crafting menu is straight forward you start out with know recipes such as a stone axe. Crafting an items is simply as just clicking on what you want to craft from the list, drag the components to the grid and click craft. After a short time the item is crafted. As you progress in the game you will find more new books that unlock new recipes. You can create forges that smelt your mining ores such as iron, and you can create a campfire to cook eggs, and raw deer meat (yes you can kill bambi!). Sleeping bags and beds crafted are used to save home locations so when you die you can respawn at them. You can farm food to grow, such as potatoes or coffee beans.

The map is huge, plenty of room to roam around and explore or go underground and create secret underground bases by digging. Zombies are slow at day and fast at night, there cute and cuddly but enough to easily overwhelm any player base not properly prepared. You will die a lot in this game, from starvation, diseases and other craziness in the game.
So if you’re an explorer or builder type, this game has plenty at its development stage to keep you busy. I recommend playing with friends to enjoy the many oh ♥♥♥♥" moments you’re going to have trying to survive against hordes of zombies.

What also makes this game unique is the importance of certain blocks in the game that form the many structures in the game such as buildings and farm houses. For example cement blocks have both a structural integrity that can withstand a lot of damage and has a threshold on the amount of blocks it can hold when used for building. Exceeding these capacities when building and not placing the proper foundation to support buildings can cause the whole building to collapse
date: pretty impressive from an engineering perspective. You can fortify buildings and upgrade doors windows etc.
recommended: to withstand more damage.\n\nThere are many things planned for the game
hoursPlayed: such as in game vehicles
voteText: npc's
helpfulPercent: and story etc. This game is a good mixture of everything we love in mine craft
votesHelpful: left for dead
votesTotal: and fallout games.\n\nIt is a great game and I highly recommend!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Speaking as a Linux gamer:

Multiplayer is currently a bit buggy (several exploitable glitches and bugs), but that's okay for alpha software. Singleplayer works without issues for me.

Overall the game is actually quite fun, especially in Multiplayer (I love PvP). Having to consider other people wanting your stuff (or your life) makes it all the more fun when building your fort and sneaking around in a city or other point of interest to avoid getting seen by players is quite thrilling.

If I had to name any, I can think of two downsides:

Sometimes, Easy Anti Cheat (a third party tool included to ward off cheaters) is being a pest and causes problems (mostly kicks you from a server). It also didn't solve the cheater problem one bit as far as I can tell. I still see the same amount of cheaters on EAC servers. So you gotta find a server with capable admins that use global banlist and have plenty of staff around to ban cheaters immediately and can restore chunks that have been vandalized by said cheaters.

Although not strictly a problem with the game, the developers have an absolutely terrible communication policy. If you're interested in what I mean, you can read up on the whole Linux drama with this game and it will become clear to you what I am getting at. It was bad enough that I felt the need to include it in this review and I still think they should improve this.


All things considered, though, I still recommend this game because it's fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So. 7 Days to Die. This review is based off of the latest build (infinite world gen)

This game started off well, a good first alpha build that showed off the features of the game, but lacked content with a limited map and lacking item explations and crafting options.

In this latest build, the game now has an infinitely generated world (which I must say is very well done). After an hour exploring i found a mix of biomes from bombed out, desolated cities (including convincing bomb craters, ruined and intact buildings, ect.)  Goergous forests, stark deserts, lakes flush with wildlife, and frozen hilly forests. One could spend hours just looking for all the nifty features the terrain generator can create, and so far, I have found no real broken generator features.

The new crafting menu is vastly improved, eliminating a lot of the guesswork required while still requiring a challenge to find and assemble crafting components for rare recipies. Unlike older versions, the recipe shows all materials needed in the grid, but you need to know what the materials are, and find them before you can build the recipe.

The UI overhaul adds modular sets for different crafting recipes, eliminating the one huge recipe list, and also adds color-cordinated backlighting to different items, displaying what catagory of item they are. It also fixed the OCD aggravating clipping between the status bars and hotbar (Thank god).

The build still has some problems, sound for one is a huge issue. Zombies are unreasonabley loud at crazy distances, making scavenging overly panic inducing, and often causing injury or death because you can't tell how far away an enemy is. Footsteps and impact sounds also feel too roughshod, and could use an overhaul.

Overall, I quite love the game, and i'll probably play around with this build a lot more. Until then, good luck surviving everyone :3 (also. Dysentery. 10/10)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT Alpha 12.1: Nope, sorry.  Still not enjoying playing this anymore. It is ridiculously dark pretty much all the time. Zombies can be heard almost regardless of distance but, because it is so dark, I can't actually see them until they are almost on top of me. The melee animation looks really stilted now for some reason and even on Adventurer with low spawn settings, zombies are everywhere, all the time. Bears, ditto. Yes, bears are less common since the patch but I still seem to spend half my time running away from either them, or dogs. The Crafting bit of the game has been over run by the Survival Horde part even from Day 1... Maybe I'll come back to it in six months and have another look but, right now, it's on my Can't Be Bothered To Play list.

This is really quite disappointing.  I really enjoyed Alpha 11 and clocked up well over 330 hours playing (yes, I know that's not much to many hardcore gamers but it's still my most played EA game on Steam). A12 appears to be rather odd in places and the community discussion boards appear (appear... ) to have a reasonable number of people making legitimate suggestions for improvements and being banned unreasonably quickly. It's definitely very dark, the weather effects are a nice touch but have reduced the visibility substantially and the wet-and-slimey look to the ground is just plain weird.  The bears are an interesting addition but appear far too often in my opinion and the zombie spawn rate appears to have been increased dramatically.
I hope the Devs are listening more than some moderators appear (appear...) to be.  This should be an enjoyable game - my last few hours in Alpha12 (Nomad setting) have just been frustrating, dark and stealthing past zombies now seems almost impossible as there's likely to be a dog or bear just around the corner.  The ramping up of the difficulty seems skewed to me.
Anyway, I hope those of us who have backed this game in EA (which, after all, is surely the whole point - to obtain player feedback on the game) will be listened to.
No, I'm not whining - I'm just looking forward to a patch that resolves a number of the legitimate issues raised by those of us who are supporting the Devs during Alpha in the hope that the final version will be as great as it deserves to be.
So, at the moment, I can't recommend this game to new players. I wish it were otherwise as Alpha11 was really good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game and the developers seem to be moving in the right direction.

The development news and update posts here on Steam have been lacking but on the Official forums the developers have been very active.

It is alpha, and there are bugs, and a lot of features not yet implemented.  Plus as should be expected for an alpha, balance is always being re-evaluated.  Of course I don't expect real balancing until all the features are implemented and much more debugged.

That said, the game has been fun so far.  I think a lot of people forget that it is an Alpha because the game does play relatively well and has a reasonable feature set already.  That may be part of the inclination to complain about the balance as they've forgotten as enjoyable as it is to play, it is also still very much in a stage where a lot of testing is required and the balance just should not be expected at this point when most mechanics are not in, anything now should be considered place-holder balance at best.

Also, modding has finally been given the OK with the expected 'not yet officially supported' and 'modders should expect mods to break with new releases and changes which may even make them redundant or impossible to recreate'.  Nothing new for a product in Alpha but given the prior confusion as to if modding was allowed (there was even a chill on modding discussion before) this is a great change.

They have even adding a Modding forum on the Official forums:
http://7daystodie.com/forums/forum.php

The future is looking brighter for this zombie apocalypse.

The game itself is an absolute blast.  Tweaked to just how you want to play with the options they've given so far.  Nothing like using a crossbow to shoot bolts to draw zombies away from a building you want to loot instead of trying to kill all the zombies in Gravestown.  Make the whole feel of the game more alive and realistic.  So much fun and it keep getting better with every release.

The Random World Generation is some of the best I've seen with towns actually linking together across multiple biomes.  The latest version added paths from roads to even the side Points of Interest (example a gravel road leading to the out of the way camp site).

Game just keeps getting better and better.  I can't wait for each update.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My first impression after an hour of gameplay is extreamly positive. I would say if you like minecraft and dayz you will probably like this... its fun.  I do think the price tag is a bit high. but if you see it on sale for 20 bucks definatly worth it.

I start out dropped in a desert like scene with broken down cars and garbage all over the roadway. I can hear the sounds of nearby zombies snarling and begin looking around to see if im being approached. I dont see any zombies so i approach the trash and am able to scavenge a can of food and some scrap metal. Next I approach a broken down vehicle where I am able to salvage more scrap metal. I break some small tree like bushes and get some sticks from them. By this time the zombies have taken notice of me so i take off running down into a canyon. I punch the sandstone and carve a small cave into the canyon side and use the sand to make some glass panes. I hear the zombies approching and get the glass up just in time to seal myself into the cave. i see the zombies outside pressed up against the glass wishing they could eat my brains. Inside the safety of my cavern i craft the scrap metal and sticks i gathered into a hunting knife. I then break the glass out and kill the zombie. By this time it is getting dark and out of almost nowhere i am swarmed by many zombies and killed.

Highly enjoyable Sandbox.,,,

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So as i update this review as it was orginally stated as a good game let me update it as the game updated :)

This game's world is bigger than when i used to play it. It seems not only big but has more stuff in the world. More houses in different areas, some areas are the same but over all it's quite amazing. I love how the developers still update the game.

So as an avid survival player... i have to say this game definitely has a lot to offer. Although it's clunky and a bit slow the game has a lot of promise. As i said before you need to get past the graphics and push through the flaws of the game to truly appreciate the game itself.

The game has multiple to nearly endless crafting options along with building options. The game has a server base where you can sort of have a private server to play with your friends or you can join an open server with other players. Along with the update- able to add friends, track them on the map, having so many more health conditions... this game truly gives a survival aspect and the developers are definitely supporting the game as much as possible. You can build gorgeous houses and in zombie attacks have them destroyed... be raided by other players.. dig underground for resources, chop down trees, or even reinforce broken town houses. The game has a lot of promise.

I do recommend this game... with it's flaws the game itself is quite fun, especially with friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Worth to buy and play it now allready; for sure a big YES !!!
Of course there need a lot to be done.. and they are working on it.
For now: this is a realy great game with a lot more potential for the future!
This game is having all a RPG needs: Action, strategie, loots, mining, crafting, building, farming, etc...
Start to get building on my self.. building a fortress around a farm-house near water & corn field.
And making a tunnel from the sellar of the house to the grainsilo on the other side of the street.
So i can escape or going inside from there to. And set up a lot of wooden spikes to kill the zombies!
Everyone can do it the way you like the most.. of course you can build a total new house or fortress everywhere you want on the good balanced map already.
The crafting & building system is the most extensive and easy to handle ever seen in games like this!!!
Extra hugh thumbs up for this!!!
Remember..there are lots of 'zombies' and also wild dogs, giant bees and others to come.. that will try to destroy what you are building...
In all the time i played till now (+-50 hrs), i only have 2 little bugs, and no crashes, so that's not so bad for an alpha game i suppose.
There is a diversification in the actions from the zombies between day and night.. so better looting, crafting and building in day-time, defending at night is usefull to do.
Conclusion:
Like i say at the beginning, there is still a lot to do.. but for sure it's already worth to buy and play!
For now a lot of hours nice playing-time and we hope it will be more and more in the future..
All by all; Thanks to the makers/developers : nice & good work allready, hope a lot more to come..
To every one; Have lots of fun by playing this exellent RPG xD

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before the A13 update: I loved playing this game, it seemed decently balanced, the wait times to craft or break things didn't seem too slow or too fast.
A13 Update: 1st Spawn: I was right next to an irradiated zone so I died seconds after walking into it.
2nd Spawn: Was in a snow biome, I was fully clothed and standing pretty much on top of the fire and I still froze to death. 3rd Spawn: Was in a desert next to wastelands and irradiated zone, almost died of heat stroke a few times, started getting the hang of the new UI (it's terrible) when I came across a resort, I killed the zombles and proceeded to loot the place... it took FOREVER to break into, each door, each baricade takes what seems like years to break, I broke into ONE... yes just ONE room after at least 2 real life minutes of just sitting in one spot staring at the door, I got so bored that I quit right then and there and will not play this game again, at least until a lot of balancing is done.

The devs took a fun and what seemed to be (at least ot me) a fairly balanced game and turned it into a grind fest, with lots of just sitting around breaking objects for what seems like an eternity. I used to be addicted to this game but now I can't stand playing it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a great, great game I would HIGHLY reccomend, even at it's original alpha price of 35$ Now that it's 25$ if you like the concept of Dayz minecraft just make the jump and get it, you won't be dissapointed.

I have bought Dayz, Rust and this, and while I like them all Dayz has been uninstalled. I like playing Rust a lot right now, but creatively I think this game takes the cake. I have always been entranced with the survival genre, and multiplayer games, especially games that encourage players to collaborate creatively. Rust is a more of a post apocolyptic survival game. Rust isn't a kos nightmare frenzy like Dayz is because you do get the ability to stash things and create bases, but as of right now pvp is the more mid-game/end-game goal as everything else becomes fairly easy once you get to know the mechanics. Rust (like Alpha Dayz) relys on the pvp to define the gaming exerience, and it basically turns into a fps where you want to loot cool pvp gear from other people. Just like Dayz. (Not bashing on it I am loving it right now.)

7 Days to Die however is a different creation and an entirely unique game. It is truly a zombie survival sandbox, that can be enjoyed greatly without even going online. The Zombie AI is great, even in its Alpha phase. Even slow walking zombies have a way of creeping up on you without you knowing until the last second, or filling into a house blocking the exits as you are checking food cabinets, forcing you to jump through a window.

I think the coolest thing about the game is that it is not just one game. You truly create the experience that you want to play. The Default (as you have probably heard) is that during daytime there are slow walking zombies, and at nighttime they turn into fast zombies. Extremely fast frenzied zombies that only slow down in the prescence of enough light (campfires, torches, ect.) The zombies will claw through any material to get to you. How long it takes for them to claw through a material depends on how durable that material is (stone is stronger than wood, which is clearly stronger than dirt.) A mudhut would be taken down in seconds at night time. Just being outside at nighttime in default is terrifying, encouraging a kind of forage and basebuilding during daytime, and fortifying and repairing your base at night time.

You can change pages of settings, and even more in depth settings not in the actual game to craft the game that you want, choosing how many zombies spawn, if they are always walkers, or always runners, how much damage they do, or you do and many, many more options.

I never really could get into minecraft because while I loved the concept, I felt no immersion. I felt that the game focused more on the creativity, than the survival immersion, but not only am I not good drawing or art, let alone 3D art, but the 3D art that I could create was in my opinion not terribly interesting, or at least not pleasing to look at. This game is all about immersion, and the graphics are incalcuably better than minecraft (and constantly getting better.) Still the physics are solid and sound, and to me incredible. Every piece of the game world is some sort of resource that you can mine and collect. Every inch of dirt is diggable and obtainable. Every stone that you see can be picked up and crafted into stone blocks" (They are starting to replace classic minecraft blocks with "smooth terrain" something that ironically in the present state I find less smooth and easy to work with than the original block style
date: but I am sure that will be refined and corrected.)\n\nThe reward of simply surviving is one very satisfying
hoursPlayed: but really the sky is the limit. Jump on a friendly server and I am constantly shocked by the imagination these people have. They will have turned a warehouse into a castle surrounded by landmines and trenches with spikes on the bottom of them. Go into the castle and it is just a decoy

lounges and tunnels. Above ground there are towers that lead to large gardens growing many different vegetables and fruit.

There is a sandbox "God" or "Cheat" mode where you can spawn any item or resource that you want at any time allowing you to create anything you can dream up.

My first online experience was on a new server when the game had just came out

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Game:
Survival, horror, zombie and crafting game. Think minecraft but better looking, more intricate crafting and faaaaaar scarier.

My Thoughts:
When I first had a crack at this game it was brilliant, building my first castle and sniping zombies from the top was rewarding as was the scavenging all the materials required for it and fighting zombies with a stone axe. The game was tough but not overly so. You could got to the easiest setting and learn how it all goes then try harder setting knowing how to build the essentials.
Then there was a patch that smashed my hard work. So decided to start again, another patch, hard work smashed. I decided to take a break to preserve my sanity (admittedly a small amount).

Well I came back for another bash after a while and things changed for the worse I think.
For example, while playing this game now my innner geek would ask (or scream and gibber) the following:
Why am I dying when cold? After constructing a shelter, clothes and stood next to a fire.
Why am I dying when hot? After removing all my clothes, standing in shade, stood still and drinking water till I'm full.
Why am I dying at all in easy mode with no zombies????

Anyway, to the review.

Pros:
Crafting is quite easy, and ♥♥♥♥♥ing materials is fun as everything is destructable. Try going into creative mode and laying tnt around the base of a building then detonating it all with a missile.
The graphics are quite nice and the atmospherics are excellent. When the zombies come for you it sends the hairs on the back of your neck right up.
The base building aspect is really satisfying, if you manage to live past the first few days.
I like the physics too, if you do bother to blast the hell out of that building I mentioned you will see it all fall in sequence, very well done to the devs for that.

Cons:

Feels too hard mode even in the easiest settings. I know this is a survival game but if you set a game to the easiest mode and STILL die if you are spawned in an extreem biome (snow, desert or the blasted lands) then where's the fun? In previous iterations of this game you could build something glorious, turn on the zombies and see what happens. Now I can barely even survive to build a wooden shack unless I'm in creative. On a side note, there is nothing more demoralising as being told by the game to build a shelter, fire and clothes to stop hypothermia only to die, (very slowly) in your shelter in a lovely plant fibre outfit and cloth armour next to a fire, from hypothermia:(

I might try this game again in the future, to see if the devs put something in to turn off the dying every 2 seconds because of being too cold or hot. I would have given a thumbs up before finding out some patches don't allow you to carry on with old saves. However, right now I can't it give a thumbs up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A year ago, I would have recommended this game highly. I spent hours and hours building bases, crafting weapons, surviving hordes, and the ambiance of the game was so well crafted I found myself having nightmares about getting overrun by zombies.

But Alpha 13 was a bad start and Alpha 14 has just made the game downright unplayable. I think they've focused so much on securing deals with Telltale, they've lost focus on delivering a quality experience to their original gamers.

Here are my complaints:
1) the weather system is ridiculously illogical - I've been in heatstroke during a snowstorm. As a player, you will spend nearly all your time just searching for water and drinking red tea. This is not hyperbole - in a 24 hour day, I spend about 16 hours just trying to keep myself hydrated.

2) while the graphics have improved dramatically, the bugs they've introduced are horrible. Zombies randomly clip through walls. Hornets spawn an endless stream of zombies so hordes several days.

3) it's become a grinding-based game just trying to accumulate enough materials to build and maintain a base. Exploration isn't all that possible now unless you play the game fully-nomadic, in which case, you desperately need a minibike and loads of gas so you can simply outrun the bugged hordes.

4) quests and skills weren't thought out well. They're there just to be there, not because they add any value to the game experience.

5) on any difficulty above Scavenger, due to the spawning bugs, the game becomes impossible to survive as the weapon balancing has been readjusted so your guns are virtually useless vs. the literal hundreds of zombies that will come your way.

I really, really wish they'd focus less on the aesthetics and understand that gameplay is more than appearance.

Edit: Figured I'd update in light of the A13 update, which was good. Long wait but worth it in the end. I know a lot of people had bug issues, but I was lucky enough not to have really any issues at all. It looks like all the major issues of world gen have been patched too. (Though I kind of liked the caves spawning on the surface, it looked like a meteor impact ha.) The new levelling system is something I'm very fond of, the new models are great and I like the new prefabs. (I'm pretty sure there are new prefabs right? Unless I never just saw them before.) The UI is really updated and I like it.

But anyway: If you're looking for a good zombie survival game it's a good one, especially if you like building and crafting. That's what this one has that a lot of the other ones seem not to.  It's fun on your own of course, but definitely buy a couple copies and send them to your friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lag / Stutter / Refund Simulator 2015 - 2016

Bought game waited for it to precache and load models textures and everything before even getting into the menu.
after celebrating newyears the menu loads Finally launched in to a server with friends. Began the epic stutter walking tried multiple resolutions all the way down to 640x480 not to mention disable everything play around with the settings edit config file, Really shouldn't need to do all this just to have a little fun.

System Specs: I7-6700k CPU 3Gig Nvidia Gpu 16gigs of ram pretty much more then adequate. Conclusion take this trash off early access and this game can blow me it needs way to much performance polishing before id even take another look at it. Which quiet literally is all you can do, stutter and look at your surroundings.

-10 / 10 Would rather eat glass and razers followed by pouring salt and acid on my eyes before attempting to play this again.

Don't like my review feel free to waste your money and file for a refund after.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI absolutely love this game. As a creative person I get to build almost everything while surviving in a world with the undead. My two favourite things combined together! 7 Days is a growing game, and the developers are always in touch with the community, only recently are they posting a new patch which excites me beyond relief. 7 Days is a survival crafting game, where you have to survive in a world of the dead. You can build shelter, find food from scraps, learn new skills from stores, and so much more. Best yet is that you can play with your friends and survive together. I have very little criticism due to the key fact that the developers are in touch. Brilliant game, and It's got massive potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alpha 11 to Alpha 14.5+ has felt completely unplayable / un-enjoyable to a lot of us simply because the devs have completely ignored the stutter issues that came with the new Unity engine (completely unrelated to hardware or FPS). Over a year's worth of time in trying to get their attention about it, and yet they still completely ignore the issue and refuse to even comment on the issue, I've decided to give the game a negative review. There's 11 pages in a single thread, not to mention countless other threads which also have several pages worth, all relating to the same stutter issues. This game might be a pig on resources, but that's not at all what this review / issue is about.

I've waited long enough!

More information on the issues here:  https://7daystodie.com/forums/showthread.php?25024-Movement-stutter-frame-lag-while-at-60-fps

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Picture Minecraft inside an episode of Walking Dead. There is no shortage of zombie games out there, but this indie stands out. At the beginning of the game you basically get dumped into the zombie apocaylpse with next to no supplies. You have to start gathering and building things immediately or you WILL get eaten! Later in the game it has a Last Man on Earth/Omega Man/I Am Legend feel to it as you explore destroyed, zombie infested cities. Build your base well. If the zeds work out where you are (count on it) they will hammer their way through doors, windows, and/or walls.

Fair warning; as of right now the game is still in alpha. Every so often the devs bring out updates which require you to wipe your game save and start over. It can be a heartbreaker. Especially since you just found that thing you've been spending the last week looking for! In trade though, the updates are significant and well-worth the trouble of a restart. Last update gave us beer!
