reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun builder game with zombies and decent physics.  Can really be nerve wracking when you're new at this... and sometimes it can be hard to start out.  Beware of dogs.

The biggest nit-pick is that it seems the devs are intent on making this more and more brutal with each iteration.  Oh, new build?  Let's see what they did.  Oh look, dogs still don't obey the movement speed that can be set, and the harder zombies seem to be getting even tougher.

At least they got rid of the need for books---in some cases.  It'd be nice if they'd get rid of it completely.

Still would recommend---it's constantly being worked on and is shaping up to be one of the best builder/survival games to date.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has been on steam/early access for barely over one month and the current newest patch (Alpha build 6) contains more content/fixes/changes than some games that have been on early access for a year+!!!! these guys are serious and are building an amazing game. It does have a rough appearance but there are upgrades to graphics in the works. The core game is just great and these guys claim to be gamers and it shows in their work. so many great ideas and they keep adding to it!
It currently has soooooooo much crafting and content that it beats out pretty much all other games in this genre. the only problem is that it isnt getting the attention it deserves. I urge everyone to checkout this game and make your own decision but in my eyes its a diamond that is being polished continually.

key things i want to point out...
-FF can be set on or off by server admins. This is great for PVP and Co-oP play!!!
-Enemies can be set on or off, again this helps with constructing.
-You can host yourself or buy dedicated host.
-When you die you only lose items in your quickslot/Belt aka equiped items.
-I hosted my own game and was able to change settings next time i loaded up that saved world. So i was able to set FF to off and not worry about players killing me so i could build, then next time i was able to turn it on again. imagine setting server to build mode and then reset and allow people to then attack each others fortified bases. the same goes for enemies, can be turned on or off whenever.
-Multiple environments on same map. desert, snow, forest, city all in the same map!
-----DIGGING, YES you can dig and build just like in minecraft. construct and deconstruct...Buildings collapse under stress. I was able to digg under a building in key points and cause it to collapse on one side only. made quite a mess too lol

- they are planning to upgrade the graphics and overall appearnce so it isnt so blocky. vehicles will be added later around this same time. cant drive a car up a hill made of squares and steps lol. so they plan to make it more smooth/natural while keeping the digging and building system!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access done right.

Good things to consider:
-Devs are very active and update the game all the time.
-Player community actually want to build and craft instead of PVP 24/7.
-Crafting is cool! Easy to use. Simple to make almost anything you need.
-Biomes with their own difficulty as to how they can be to stay in.
-Every 7 days, the hordes are at their hardest to survive. Tons of them every 7 days.
-Hate PVP? PVE is a thing.
-Hate other people moderating over you in servers? Make your own.
-Hate the horror and zombies in general? Turn them off for creative mode!
-Play with your friends.
-Play with your enemies.
-Play completely alone.
-More types of zombies. Special zombies.

**Fat ones (take more hits to kill)
**Burnt ones (just look cool as hell)
**Female ones (just like in real life, they take one hit to kill)
**Feral ones (Stay away from them at night)
**Fat spitters (When taking enough damage they rush you and splode)
**Spider ones (Not spiders but they climb and scream to call in hordes)
**Pimp walking ones (They hobble, hard as f%@k to get head shots on)
**Crawlers (Hard to see right away and break your legs)
**Dog ones (These run 24/7 and are the bane of most newbs)
**Fat Bee ones (They fly and buzz and want you dead. They give honey)
**Naked ones (Devs gave them diapers now)

Things bad to consider.
-Graphics a lil wonkey.
-Some servers restart completely per minor or major update so you lose all progress.
-People can be booty holes. But not as much as those in Dayz or Rust and other PVP heavy games. The fact that people like building in the sandbox brings in more then just some bored Call of Duty player to the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my updated 2nd review. 9/16/14. My first review was premature and I probably made the game sound much better than it is. If my first review made the game sound like a 9/10, my more realistic 140+ hours of gameplay review would have to put it at more like a 6.5 or 7 out of 10.

Overall, I would give this game a thumbs up. The game is fun to play, even with all it's problems. If you really enjoy sandbox type games, then 7DTD will appeal to you, despite all it's flaws. It's like Minecraft on steroids with zombies, ruined cities, sniper rifles, rocket launchers and eventually, will have driveable cars. I'll list a few of what I consider to be the most important points. Keep in mind that at the time of this review we are still in alpha. If you are considering buying the game in alpha, you should expect there to be bugs, a lack of content and other problems. If you get mad at bugs and other problems, don't buy the game in alpha. With that in mind, here is a rough picture of the game in it's current state:

Pro: Being tossed into a HUGE game map with zombies and discovering ruined cities and surviving and building your first base = fun, though a bit grindy.

Con: The map is huge but repetitive. Running for hours and seeing more of the same randomly generated map biomes gets boring pretty fast. On one hand, the technical achievment of a randomly generated maps is impressive. But then you realize it just gives you a huge bland boring map. There is something very important added to gameplay when you design an intelligent, creative, realistic, immersive, interesting, fun map. Just having an algorithim spitting out huge empty boring maps is NOT an improvement to gaming.You could also view this trend of procedurally generated maps as developer laziness. Gone are the days now when maps where intricately designed to lead the player on a grand adventure of discovery. The trend with the current batch of games is have an algorithim do all the map making. Will we one day have entire games that are procedurally generated and devs don't even need to do anything more than change a few textures and repackage the game with a different title? This will not be an improvement people, trust me.

Pro: In MP, it's kind of nice that you can go miles away from all the other players, and build your base, and maybe even find your own city that nobody else knows about (at least for a bit!). So the huge infinite map gives you some privacy, and maybe the ability to have your own private city, at least temporarily.

Con: MP servers are having major issues with lag, freeze ups, crashes and rollbacks. One server I was on the server owner couldn't even get it to start up anymore, so he had to delete and start over, thus deleting everyone’s bases and loot. There is speculation that these problems are directly related to the infinite maps as it seems the further out people explore on the maps, the more the server lag increases. It hasn't been definitively confirmed yet, but there is suggestive evidence that it is related to the map size / generation. Now considering we don't need infinite maps, I'd much rather have a stable large map then an infinitely unstable map. I've played many MMOs with huge stable game worlds (and thousands of players), and map space was never an issue. Since this game is not an MMO, and is designed for small sized server populations, we really don't need infinite maps....Please devs, just give us a stable comfortably large map.

Pro: Compared to Minecraft, the graphics are amazing!
Con: Compared to all games made after 2007, the graphics are not very impressive! With that said, I always give much more weight to gameplay and fun, and graphics are just a bonus. I'd rather play a game with great gameplay and low end graphics any day than a game with top tier graphics and crap game play. With that in mind, the graphics for 7DTD are adequate.

Pro: Building bases can be fun!

Con: At the moment, the building customization is probably lacking compared to say Minecraft. But that will surely change as game gets updated. Another con for me anyways is the complicated integrity, max load system. If you don't like to do a bunch of math (which I don't, when playing games), it is very likely your uber base that you just spent 20 hours building will ...collapse.


Ok, now the absolute biggest con for this game atm, is.....multiplayer. Yes, unfortunately the pain will increase dramatically as you begin playing multiplayer, and you will start to realize just how f**** up this game really is! Multiplayer servers are plagued by hackers in god mode, flying around, spawning them selves all the weapons and TNT they want, filling up peoples bases with bedrock (which can't be removed), shooting through the environment (exploit, not really a hack), causing the server to crash, destroying peoples bases that they spent 200 hours building, etc...the list goes on. I actually have NOT been the target of a hacker ...yet...but every server I have been on has had multiple instances of hackers and other players losing everything because of it.

On top of the hacker problem, there are other major problems causing servers to lag and freeze up and crash, and many times this results in a rollback --- causing you lose several hours of progress. For example on my current MP server, I got dropped at one point, and for one hour I tried to log back on, and I couldn't, even though the server was still up. At some point they reset the server, and the next morning when I logged on, everything I had collected the previous night (over a period of a few hours) was gone. One of my game neighbors lost his entire base! I had just happened to get lucky on the previous game session and scored a major haul when I found an unprotected player base / farm, and had looted about 600+ food supplies! After starving for a week (realtime), I had finally hit the jack pot and found 600+ food! Then ….all gone. It makes one feel like it's very pointless to even build up an uber base or gather a bunch of loot, when you know you can log in the next day and it's all gone.

Despite all these problems, you can easily play for a hundred hours and not have any of these disasters happen to you. The rollback I just talked about was really one of the few major annoyances I have experienced. Well except when my first MP server decided to quit, and I lost 3 (real life) days worth of gathering and building. But I do constantly hear other players on the servers I am on, complaining about their base disappearing, or large stock piles of loot just vanishing! So it is fairly common.

In single player I haven't really had any major problems yet, other than just getting bored of the repetitive nature of the game map and the grind of gathering resources, and building up a first base. And then of course a new update comes out...and you lose your SP game save, and then you have to decide if the new features that were implemented are really worth starting all over again, just so you can see them. My biggest complaint of the SP experience is the game runs a bit laggy. I can run a game like Skyrim on ultra smooth as butter, and here is this game with vastly inferior graphics to Skyrim, yet it runs way crappier. It's not unplayable, but the graphics lag is quite noticable and irritating sometimes. This is certainly because the developers are inexperienced at making modern high end games, it really shows. But despite all the negatives, most of my 140+ hours of game play have been entertaining. But also repetitive and grindy! LoL. A tentative thumbs up. Worth playing if your bored. I can guarentee you will have many hours of fun. But far from being a great game in it's current state. You may just want to keep an eye on this game and wait for another year of development to pass.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had been following this game for a little while before it came to steam. I was excited to get my hands on it even if it was only in its alpha stage. When this game first came out it is was a huge disappointment. I was crushed. I couldn't tell you how much I didn't like everything about it. I played about 2 hours trying to understand what was going on and I kept telling myself I was missing something; some huge part of the game that would make it what I thought it was supposed to be. I wasn’t missing anything... The game was so early alpha that it was just a concept held up with a bit of scotch tape and some toothpicks. I deleted the game feeling scammed; like I had just wasted my money. Fast forward a month or so later. A friend of mine had been playing religiously every night. I couldn’t understand what he saw in the game. I was bored enough one night to say what the heck and re download it and jump in for some j-j-j-jolly cooperation. I was blown away! Was this even the same game? Everything had been completely re done. The graphics had been significantly increased. HDR, bloom, lighting. The zombies had rag doll physics (Big plus in my books.). The menu, crafting, UI, features, items, weapons. Everything had been made 100x better and re imagined with more content. The way the game played was amazing compared to the day 1 alpha release which was like scraping your eyes on a chalk board and getting the sound from nails. Everything about the game was, surprisingly better. Like a million times better. Like, how could this happen?! I want to believe in magic but at the same time I also want to believe in god. I went from feeling like a kid at Christmas who was good all year but still got coal to feeling like a man who broke open that coal to find a diamond.

This game really was bad when it came out. But since it has gotten the updates that have been promised I can't stop playing. It is extremely fun. It is a mix of FPS, survival horror, crafting, mining and so much more. And! Everything is destructible. If you have looked past this game then give it another glance. I know I am glad I did. It is easily one of my all time favorite games for too many reasons to list. It is the best zombie game on steam. A must own for everyone. This game has come a long way and I am excited to see where it goes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pre-A7.0 I would have recommended this game as a decent builder game (with the zombies off, or occasionally turned on) I spent about 30 hours on this game with the zombies turned off most of the time, building, crafting, and eventually testing out various base designs. But beyond that, I have never felt any real desire to survive beyond the hours spent building this or that. This is Minecraft+zombies. Not open sandbox survival-horror.

I just spent about 3 hours trying out the new things added with the 7.0+ patch(es) and am finding myself getting frustrated with how the ground has been smoothed, making it difficult to tell exactly where you're striking with an axe or shovel (which makes mining out an underground base almost impossible now, at least with any sense of orginized structure to it). A couple of pluses are the 'veins' of ore now, instead of just a block here and there of this or that ore you can find streaks of ore through the dirt, gravel, and stone layers.

The other additions, such as the wait to loot, noise penalties, stealth, and crafting systems are good window dressing for making the game more 'realistic'. But the big selling point for the game (for me at least) has now been ruined, or at the very least complicated for me, the building. As the game stands at this very minute, I can not recommend it at the rather high price of $25. My suggestion: If you're thinking about getting the game, wait until it is out of Alpha to spend your money.

PS: I would also like to add that there are better 'sandbox survival-horror' games out there. State of Decay comes to mind immediately. If you want a 'sandbox builder' stick with Minecraft, it's less expensive and for now, better over all. If the developers don't flub things up too badly, in a years time 7 Days to Die could be one of the best sandbox survival-horror games out there. -IF- they don't flub it up...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7 Days to Die. I like to compare it as: DayZ meets Minecraft. It's literally just that. You have to survive day and night by finding items, such as food, water and weapons. Not only with that you can survive, you also need to build a safehome, where you are safe from zombies and hostile-players. Both compared you have an excellent chance of survival.
You can craft your own stuff too, weapons, blocks, doors, windows, stairs, etc. etc.
Working together with friends and other players is not neccesary, but needed for better survival, especially versus other people.

Some settings you can change in the game are handy. You can start off easy and disable the zombie-spawn. You can also put the spawn-time on normal and even on fast.

Daytime is safest, that's my first tip for you. Now go try it yourself!

I recommend this game. It's fun and you really put your instincts to the test. With friends it's even more fun, on a LAN-party it would be funniest. I can play this all day long, not alone though. Just like in Minecraft: you can play it for hours, but with friends you can play it a couple hours more.
For a decent price you can buy it in the Steamstore.

Rating:
8.5/10
No 9 or 10 because the game is still in it's Early Access, it's nothing near finished. That doesn't mean it isn't fun. The game is already this fun, can't wait for the fun I'll have when the game is fully released.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first got the game, it was amusing enough. Problem is, it seems every time they update, they decide add in something to make the game more tedious and make the beginning even more trollishly hard.

The last straw for me was the every 6 day dog horde that forces you to stay hidden until you have a big enough gun to shoot a pack of dogs that can run almost as fast as you do and the weekly 7th night horde that know exactly where you are no matter where you may be. It's also not a small horde by any stretch of the imagination. If you don't have a strategy for it, you die and the zombies wreck your base. The dog horde wasn't actually so bad, it'll just get you if you're not ready and it spots you.

It wouldn't have been such a terrible thing if the game waited, say, 14-21 days to give you enough time to prepare before it sends you a weekly death squad. It's kind of sad to have to build a base just to abandon it on the 7th night and stand in the middle of an open field to be killed because there's no way in hell you're going to be able to handle a horde on night 7.

Of course, this game is a work in progress and future balancing may fix the various imbalanced aspects, but considering what I've seen so far, I'm not gonna count on it.

I suppose one could disable the hordes and enjoy the game. However, at this point in development, I just can't recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can run Stranded Deep smoothly on Ultra and 1080p

I get 28-48 FPS on this game on everything either off or low and 480p running in windowed mode.

Do I even have to say more?

Sure this game looks promising at all, but at the state it is currently in, the price tag is a ripoff. This game has worse performance than the initial release of the Dark Souls PC port has in Blighttown and that's got to count for something.

Also, this game has ridiculous mouse input delay.

Overall, this game is just a blatant ripoff. I've played games powered by shockwave that have better optimization, graphics and overall production quality than this.

I usually do much longer reviews, but there is not much else to say.

And on a side note: The content on the screenshots are an HD mod for this game. This is NOT how the vanilla game looks like, even at highest settings (whether this is false advertisement or not is a different story, though personally I feel blatantly lied to) so keep that in mind before buying.

Early Access Review

I went to play 7 Days to die recently and found that I was not able to walk around for 20 seconds without crashing. I looked through the forums and have had found that this is a common issue and has been for some time now. I spent a few hours trying to find a sollution, and installed the game in 32 bit which seemed to fix the issue. There is also an issue with mass amounts of lag durring horde mode.

I do know that the game is in alpha, but a bug as game breaking as that should be addressed a lot quicker than The Fun Pimps have dealt with it. I have been playng 7 Days to Die since its launch and I feel that the developers have just become lazy with their bug fixes.

With that said I do enjoy the game when it does work. But because if the issues it currently has, I sadly can not reccommend it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have about ten hours right now on this game and I have to say I don't get the haters.  This game is far superior at its current stage of development than most others.  I love the fact that you can change the zombies to the classic George Romero slow walking zombies or even turn them off if you want.  The crafting system is pretty good and fairly easy.  I would only recommend a tutorial on using it.  The addition of more biomes is deffenately a plus now just adding in some weather for rain and snow and your all set.  I have read some bad reviews about this game and I can tell you from my experience with this game, those reviews just don't hold any truth.  They might have had some validity in the begining but those issues have apparently been delt with.  All in all I'm glad I bought this game and would recommend it to any one considering buying it.  If they keep working on it and, I'm sure they will, It will deffinately be worth the price.  As of the writing of this review the game currently has 3 different game modes, single player and multiplayer, adjustable modes for the zombies, many differnt blocks for building and sculpting the environment, a vast crafting system, four different playable characters, and just plain tons of fun.  If you ever wanted a game that combines Minecraft with State of Decay with Tower defense and a whole plethera of other games but done in a more grown up style, this is deffinatele the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is kinda like Fallout it may not be pretty but it gets the job done.They are making improvements and updates on a regular basis,and stay in touch with the community.This is Alpha but so far i like where most of it is going and how things are being handled.

The random maps are a welcome and there is plenty of loot to be had but use it wisely.It is first person view and the zombies are varied and for the most part not to over whelming if your careful and quiet,They do walk slower at daylight so you will want to do most your scavenging during the day.They can charge at night and do gather in hordes with specials and other infected so stealth is the most important.

They can also dig and climb to get at you and they can tear down your building to get at you unlike most others games where your home is safe here it is always at risk.You can also set traps like spike strips,dig holes with spike strips which is my favorite way to watch them die.You will have to repair or replace damage done to your buildings or traps so make sure to keep up on that so they do not get to you.

You can dig under ground and build just about anything you can think of underground which keeps you safe from zombies but makes getting supplies a little more work and takes longer to build.There also are dogs which can be a big threat early on if not prepared for them,so when you first start your best to try and craft a decent weapon and find a building the first night.

I think for now i have said enough i will post the Pros and Cons now

Pros
Grow Crops for food
Nice crafting and building
Decent Zombies
Lots of things to loot
Huge maps

Cons
Needs more crafting like candles and oil lanterns
Could use a map to mark locations or points of interest like water or good looting areas,towns ect.
Note: it does have a map just no way to mark things it just shows where you been when you walk

Trapped doors to hide your entrances better and maybe make traps for zombies
Better starting gear at least give basic first aid and some kind of weapon

Needs a real offline mode for single player so you can still play if you have no internet. If you wish to play alone as of now you need to be logged into steam before it will launch the game and let you play.

Suicide option to be put back in for single player as it stands now if you fall through something or get stuck the only way to get out is to either wait to starve/die of thirst or reload the game to reset yourself.

Finally Alpha 10 is coming with a lot of changes and as the games changes i may change my review and update it.

In short if you like building,crafting,zombies,co-op this is a good game to get and out of the survivalist games this is one of the better ones in my opinion and worth the purchase .

8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's basically Minecraft with slightly better graphics.
I personally enjoy scavenging cities, refining materials, building a base and fortifying it - But many aspects of the crafting, shooting, building, farming and scavenging are very flawed.

The game could be better made in general - Even for an Alpha.
The multiplayer system is very flawed and many people, including myself, are unable to play with friends - which unfortunately was the most appealing part of the game for me - Both playing co-up and being able to establish a complex community with my friends.

Furthermore the game is heavily overpriced and the creators aren't updating very often - Also it doesn't take a genius to see that this game was a part of the whole Zombie-RPG wave that occurred right after the release of the Dayz Alpha.

In short, don't buy the game till it's either fully released or the price drops heavily.
voteText: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'd give this game a 3/5. I played this game alot before it went on to steam.  It was Alpha 1 and they were going in such a unique direction where the zombies were a legitimate threat at night and nowhere was safe, so you had to board up your house and hope they dont knock your house down into rubble, however, the very next update removed all of that and went in a fairly standard, well worn, direction of making a completely safe house where the zombies sit idly outside.  It's like minecraft where they sort of sit outside, hopeing for you to open the door.  Once outside, the game turns into a call of duty nazi zombies gun fight minus the difficulty.  It's like playing round three throughout the entire game.  You could always jack up the difficulty, but i'd rather not have poor AI zombies take 2 shots to take me down.  I'd assume the online gameplay may be better and there are promises of a semi return to their original idea in Alpha 1. but even their promises only offer a semi-return to it if you make amature mistakes" which doesnt provide quite the same thrill the original Alpha 1 release did for me.  I'd do my research on whether or not the multiplayer is worth it to you
date: because the core ideas as of alpha 6 are not worth the 35$ i paid."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my updated review for 7 Days to Die (alpha 13)


7 Days to Die is an excellently maintained game, recieving updates based on user requests. This is a great way to develop a game.

The new GUI is excellent and I can finally craft items without the infuriating need to remember where to place resources in some silly grid. All you have to do is search for the recipe and click craft. This is very simple and very effective.
Interacting with items is easy and quick. All you have to do is click on an item and you can see every action which can be done with that item. (By action, I mean eat it, drink it, drop it, etc.) The new GUI is also clean and non-obtrusive. There are no silly bars of ambiguity; it's all done with numbers, overlaying a horizontal bar. Genius!


Zombies in this game are truly marvelous. Thanks to the recently added motion capture technology incorporated into the game, they now move how a real life zombie would move. They limp around in the day and still pose a threat in whatever activity you are doing. What makes these zombies so excellently designed is that they repsond well" to damage. Something that some zombie games lack. If you hit a zombie
date: they may become stunned. The zombies will also be knocked back slightly and won't hit you the instant you strike at them. Their growls are scary and this makes for a tense experience at night.\nAt times

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not one to talk poorly of game developers, but I feel this needs to be said so I'll give a fair review of Alpha 13 as I go.

- Visually, this latest update did very well. Most everything looks noticeably better.

- Alpha 13 essentially made the game copy more aspects of Ark Survival's interface, so if you like that interface, you'll likely enjoy this factor a bit more.

- The costs for items is a little crazy now, it seems almost randomly chosen with no real rhyme or reason. Some items are changed to the point they are useless now.

Example: for the same amount of materials in Alpha 12 instead of making 25 arrows, you make one. Yes, a single arrow. While this is more realistic, without increasing the power of the arrows to actually make them useful at one arrow per craft... you basically just made them useless as it took multiple arrows in the head to kill zombies at higher difficulties anyway so you'll spend just as much time gathering supplies for arrows in the early game as you would trying to customize your base.

All of this is understandable and fine. Here's the big problem...

They completely broke the spawns for zombies. Even at low spawns on the second to lowest difficulty on the first night (yes, the first night) you can literally fight an endless amount of zombies if you're spotted even once. A single screamer zombie (Banshee) will call a horde if it spots you. Normally a single horde isn't too bad, but the problem comes with the additional screamers which spawn close to the end of nearly every horde, before it's actually finished. Nearby zombies can alert them to your presence and if they see you, they scream and summon another horde. This is nearly impossible to avoid at all times in the early game as you don't have any feasible way to destroy screamers at a distance or avoid screamers if they happen to catch you in your house at the wrong time.

So, if you get spotted once, most of the time it's game over after a long grueling fight which makes you just not want to play anymore.

Up until Alpha 13 I would have gladly recommended this game, but until this is fixed I would recommend steering clear of 7 Days to Die.

Pros
Gravity
Huge variety in crafting
Promotes creativity
Great concept with zombies that walk at day and transform to runners at night it makes you think twice before going out late

Cons

Overall one of the best survival horrors i have played 9/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review for version A13
I had to change my recommendation since the game became a major overhaul and goes now in such a bad direction that I don't enjoy to play it anymore. You can find my first review further down.

In short, 7d2d stole a lot of ideas from games like ARK or Rust and implemented it. Also implemented it pretty bad. I'm not even talking about the tons of bugs, they will get fixed eventually.

Not sure what exactly happened, but I would say that someone else now has the creative lead. One of the strong sides of the game was so far the easy gameplay with a lot of depth.

This clearly is getting completly changed and complex systems replace the easy one. Systems that add not so much depth, but mechanics that constantly force you to do things. It also prevents you from easy starting anew again. Instead of making the endgame more interesting/rewarding they made the beginning painful (not in terms of difficulty, but in terms of achieving anything). IT's A GRINDING GAME NOW!!!!

A few examples:
> Characters got gimped and a skill system was implemented that adds nothing except to bring your char back to where he once was without the skill system.
> There is now poop in toilets
> There is now a heat system in place that forces you to change your clothing constantly
> There is just one sort of meat in the game instead of a different one from every animal, in general there are less recipes available
> The hud got simplified which took a ton of immersion away (you need now to go trough different menus to see for example how hungry or thirsty you are
> Fighting mechanics took a blow for the worse. Graphics will prevent you from making clear shots, also the way zombies move now make every shot unpredictable
> You can literally be safe now with just tons of wood spikes around you, building anything more is not fun now but just a pain in the ♥♥♥ that needs tons of ressources to keep it repaired (repairs were free before)
> Less interaction with objects, less materials, less recipes, takes a lot of immersion away
> Random terrain generator is completely ♥♥♥♥ed up now - you basically need to build in the desert, because you won't find anywhere else water. And water will now disappear in time.

I could go on for hours like that. The games has issues that would need attention (implement NPCs, make a better random generator, more prefabs, better security against hacks, implement electricity or similar system with logic operators, etc...) but the devs ignore those completly and invest instead only time into changing systems that were fine. As it stands I can only recommend the game to play the older A12 version. That one is a lot of fun. Other than that I'd recommend to buy something else.

------------------------------------------------

Review for up to version A12
Yes, I recommend it. It's an awesome game and you would miss out a lot by not playing it if you like zombies and/or base building, crafting, survival games.

Grab one or a few good friends, open a server and try to survive against waves and waves of zombies during the night while you scavenge for food, supplies and weapons during the day and fortify your base as good as you can.

Always in a race against the clock. The game get's harder the longer you play it. Building on a spot generates heat and this attracts zombies. Also every night until the final 7th night the zombies get harder.

If you survived a week and manage to rebuild the damage you got on the 7th night it cools down. But make no mistake, because week 2 will be harder than week 1.

Only when you managed to survive around 7 or 8 weeks you will be pretty safe. That's also the time to quit and play on harder difficulty as there is not much else to do after.

Multiplayer Servers work different and would in theory give a longer incentive to play, but be aware, that the not whitelisted multiplayer servers are completly flooded with hackers.

The game uses the unity engine (big mistake for any serious multiplayer game nowadays) and you will loose all your stuff and well built base because they take it over with hacks. So multiplayer is a complete NO-GO! with this game.

Be VERY AWARE of that before buying it.

I enjoy the game, however, there is currently a memory leak for 32 bit systems that causes the game to crash every 10-15 minutes depending on how far you are traveling (longer travel, faster crash).

Of course, when this crash happens nothing is saved. You are essentially replaying the same bit of the game over and over again unless you logout for it to save every 10 minutes, anticipating the inevitable crash.

I can't really recommend it in it's current state to 32 bit users. Just wait a few months for them to figure it out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I whole-heartedly recommend this game. If you have been sitting on the fence wondering whether this is just like all the other sandbox survival games out there just stop it and purchase this game right now.

This game plays great solo, co-op, or pvp depending on your tastes.

This game delivers a real challenge and you will die a lot at first until you become familiar with what you must do to survive. There is no tutorial but there are lots of videos on youtube and helpful people on the forums to answer questions.

Crafting, building, exploring, survival.....all are done exceptionally well especially for a game at this stage of development.

I have owned this game for 1.5 years as of this writing and can attest that the developers are active and passionate about this game. There is very little risk of abandonment that I can see and even if it were to happen the current game is worth the price all by itself so you just can't lose.

There are a lot of exploration and survival sandboxes out there but this one stands apart due to its voxel based world and the sheer fun of playing.

Now the negative.... Like all of the sandbox survival games in early access there comes a point where all the threats have been overcome and then the game is boring. The good news is that tougher enemies are planned for this stage of the game and quests and NPCs that you can gather as followers will extend gameplay beyond the initial survival scope. But that isn't in yet.

Also like all early access games you must be patient and forgiving as bugs and wipes will cause you  pain. But if you enjoy experiencing games as they develop and are interested in the survival sandbox genre you will absolutely love this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing and following this game since kickstart and it has been an interesting ride. There have been times the updates didn't do what we wanted or, more often enough broke the gameplay. But we have to remember that this is an EARLY ACCESS game currently and it is still in Alpha. The developers are usually quick to fix the game breakers and are making regular progress towards their listed goals. As a singleplayer game, it is fun for a while and definitely worth sinking some hours into. As a multiplayer game, it is fantastic. There are many different interactions in MP with some people being friendly and willing to trade items and there are some who would rather take by force. I was dissapointed most in the map. In a multiplayer environment it was easy to just run around and find people, but now with random world generation, it has become an entirely new game. Perhaps the best feature of this game are the consequences. Every little thing you do has an effect. Drinking unboiled water might fix your thirst for a time, but you stand a good chance of contracting a disease. Eating certain food types boosts energy but drains hydration. Choice of builing location is critical. If you build next to a road or city, someone may find you. Too far away from loot spawns and you're going to tooless.

TL:DR
This game is great and offers a lot of features and performance especially in alpha/early access. It can be buggy and there are things that need to be tweaked/fixed but it is worth it to play nonetheless. I highly recommend the game and suggest you pick up a copy to support the developers as they improve this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The idea of combining Left4Dead and Minecraft culminates in this open world survival and building game. In comparison to other games of its kind I've found that freedom in building block by block and underground, as opposed to schematics and in existing structures, led to a much more immerse environment and experience.

Watching this game evolve through its Early Access stages has been a treat, the development team stays connected to the community and continues to work diligently to make the game that the players want and a game that they also want to play.

After almost two hundred hours spent both running a server and playing on others I find myself waiting anxiously for the next patch and a chance to conquer the horde with my friends yet again!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Surprisingly good...
I was really sceptical at first, but as one of my friends gifted the game to me I would loose nothing by trying the game.
After seeing trailers and screenshots, my expectations were incredibly low, but after the first 5 minutes the game grew on me. the Atmosphere reminds me of Fallout 3 and the game world is incredible. This game is more akin to Minecraft than anything else. The vast amount of content and the satisfying gunplay keeps me going, and I LOVE the RPG elements... I am a sucker for exp and leveling. There are servers online which you can join for PVP but the most fun I've had is playing solo or co-op with friends. Your character, which you can make any way you wish, is saved as a profile to be loaded in different worlds (no items and levels transfer, only appearance). Crafting and building is extensive. Mining far into the ground and exploring underground caves is just as much fun as exploring the huge cities. There are many blueprints and schematics to find, and there are tonnes of ways to play. If you like survival games but want to stay away from all the hectic PVP, and just loose yourself in a postapocalyptic world, building bases and min-maxing supplies... then this game is for you.
I give it an 8/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7 Days to Die is not necessarily unique in what it offers : Survival, Zombies, Guns and playing with others, but it combines elements from games like Minecraft, too. You need to allocate resources in order to make things yourself, or trade for better items. Need iron armor? Have fun acquiring it. You'll need not only someone friendly to trade it from, or you can hunt for the schematics, items for a forge and recipes, then gather the materials and do it yourself ( my preferred method, I'm only a bit anti-social ).

So, about the 'Like' or 'Similar To' Minecraft bit : I've never played the game, or seen its cubey appeal, but that doesn't matter too much to me. The main pull from it seems to be the open world mining and building system, and I think its quite fun. In 7 Days to Die, you actually need to think about things like load bearing mechanics, and structural integrity.. though that doesn't mean you can't build some very impressive structures.

Another nice thing? The Developers update the game with either larger patches, or hotfixes rather frequently. So, if you find a problem or issue regardless of what hardware combo your PC features, there's probably someone else that has either the same or similar issue, and the Dev's know.

So, here's the end of a review, one of many for the game. Yes, it's an alpha, and it might have the occasional glitch or FPS drop. Thing is far as I'm aware, it's what an Alpha is for : Adding items and fixing bugs, at least a friend tells me so. I believe him.

Been playing this myself in single player, or on servers with or amongst others since late Alpha 8 or so, it comes reccomended from me.. -if- you like these sorts of game elements, listed above. Sure I missed something.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, this is one of my first reviews, so bear with me.

7 Days to Die is, as advertised, a survival game with hordes of zombies every seven nights. If you ever get bored in-between then, just visit your local Pass-n-Gass and enjoy decapitating the rotting meatsacks. Anyhow, let’s get down to business:

Gameplay  Well, to start, it’s a pretty solid game, really. You spawn in a world, no skills, no equipment, and are forced to figure out how to survive in 7 nights when a horde of angry reanimated corpses comes to rip your face off. You create some simple tools and harvest resources, usually wandering around for a while to find a suitable place to live, collecting flowers, rocks, and cotton as you go on. You can use all of these to your advantage, making teas, dyes, and clothes. Oh, did I mention you spawn in boxers?

Yep.
It’s pretty normal to be caught with your pants down by zombies. Who knew the apocalypse was gonna be on a Monday?

Anyway, after finding a nice place to build a fort, or hijacking a pre-fab generated by the game (you lazy sack of plant fibers), you can start to make progress. Every action you do in the game gives you experience.  After enough experience, you level up, giving you skill points to put towards skills to increase your advantage against the ravenous horde currently calling dibs on certain portions of your body. These points can, for instance, be used to increase your crafting skill or mining skill, or saved for later,  more beneficial upgrades.
When you’re not starving or thirsting to death, you’re usually looting for nifty items or parts for other crafting tools, like pipes for a furnace. In most cases, you find turds, paper, or just your usual aviator goggles. (I have actually found more of these than I care to recall. They are not useful in any way except for wearing. More pipes, please!) That’s in addition to hungry zombies, who again, want to rip your face off. Occasionally you stroll up on a tool shop or book store and find some really good loot. Really, it’s more often than not, but you get unlucky sometimes. In essence, cities are your best bet for good loot and loads of zombies.

Mining and hunting also come into play when you’re finally trying to make a forge. It’s harder than you think. Now, back in the earlier Alphas, it was just some rocks and clay. Then, you put in what you want, click on what you want back, and bam: materials. However, in the recent updates, it is extremely tedious. First, you need a Bellows. This is made by 1 Pipe, 12 Animal Hides, and 8 Wood. So you need to have found at least one pipe and killed at least 2 animals to even attempt to make a forge. So, for the forge now, it requires the bellows you made, 50 stones, another pipe, and 50 clay. Now, you have at least had to find 2 pipes. When I say these suckers are a pain in the ♥♥♥ to come by, I mean it. Maybe not so much in Singleplayer, but in Multiplayer, when 75% of everything you look at is looted; it’s a pain in the ♥♥♥. Back to mining: you need to do this every other day to maintain a steady supply of materials, because they go fast the first time you’re making tools and structures.
Even though the forge is hard to come by, it is a wondrous tool. Once you learn Steel Smithing from the skill menu, everything gets a little easier.

Oh, right, I left out the horde that comes on night 7 to rip your limbs off. About half of the previous comes after night 7, depending on what you have your timescale set to. When night 7 comes, the horde is immediately running to your location to kill you. If you die during that night, you will respawn a ways away from your base/last location, so it’s a good idea to mark with a waypoint where you’re staying that night. The best thing is to wait for morning and kill the horde off. Zombies are much easier to aim at when they’re not running around dodging your axe swings or arrows in the dark.

I probably left some things out, but I'm probably killing your eyes too, so I’ll wrap this next section up quickly.


Mechanics  To start, it's a voxel game, so there's that. There is no lawn mower, so your fists have to make due. The only way you can flatten a piece of land is to remove the grass/stones/whatever and place wood frames over it. When you place down dirt yourself, its automatically flat. If that was any other way, I would probably eat my hat.

When building structures, you have to be very cautious about supporting the floors. Big rooms require pillars for support underneath, so when starting out, build small. 9x9 is a good starting base, leaving 7x7 in the interior when the walls come in. When you know your going to want a basement floor or two, I've found that digging that out and building it up from there is the best method. Digging underneath your current house (with everything you've achieved staring down at you) and supporting it as you go isn't exactly my type of relaxation.

Traps and exterior walls prove an effective way to keep zombies from reaching you. Traps include wood log spikes (upgradeable), normal wood spikes (which break down after some time), and barbed wire. Concrete walls with wood log spikes and some type of net (iron bars) to keep spider zombies from crawling up your walls seem to be a great way to protect your home. When building your home in the plains or somewhere temperate, it’s a good idea to use iron bars for windows and metal trussing for the corners on the window layer. Both of these items you can shoot through.
(This is starting to sound more like a guide than a review, but I want it to explain about the game in depth, so.)

Crafting is smooth, simple, and effective.  Sub-categories help when looking to craft for experience. That's really all I can say.
Now, for the ONLY Con of the game:
I find that the only con of the game is that it is highly unoptimized. the VRAM leaks constantly no matter what graphics card you use, and this can kill frames easily, and has caused my game to crash several times. The only way right now to fix it is to go into the video options and hit 'Apply' on your graphics settings, which seemingly resets the memory when it reloads the visuals. I have a NVIDIA GTX 770 on this rig and I have the potential to run this game on max settings no problem, with only 2 GB of RAM on my card. (Don't get confused, I have 16 GB DDR3 on my motherboard.) If the devs would work on fixing the VRAM leaks and cleaning up the engine a bit, this game would be so much more enjoyable than it already is. Despite this crucial flaw, I still have to give this a thumbs up because it’s such a great game with potential in both the game and the graphics. Cough cough. @Devs.

Thank you for reading, and have a good one!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Survival Horror Sandboxing

Starting the game I found myself in a scene very reminiscent of Silent Hill. A wrecked car sat in the road beside me surrounded by my worldly belongings and the desert wasteland was entirely unfamiliar to me. Gathering up my few worldly possessions I boldly set forth into the unknown and was immediately set upon and ripped apart by a pack of wild dogs.

So exactly like Silent Hill then.

My next few attempts fared little better. I tried to break into a house and was snuck up on and stunlocked to death by zombies, I approached a car junkyard and mysteriously died with no apparent cause like in the opening of 13 ghosts, and I had another go at meleeing zombies getting myself stunlocked to death.

Part of the problem is that zombie moans barely change in loudness depending on distance or facing, so a zombie could be trying to extract itself from someone's scummy backyard swimming pool 3 blocks away and you will still hear it hissing in your ear, which makes it hard to tell when zombies are actually close since you just stop listening eventually.

So I quit for a couple of months and came back in another patch when the sound bug had supposedly been fixed. It's still there but not as bad as before, you can't hear them as far and the sound does somewhat scale by distance, just not very well, and I can at least tell the difference between a zombie 20 metres away and one 5 metres away

Nonetheless it seemed like a rather dull survival crafting game. Zombies are easily outrun and can be dispatched with little trouble with an easily crafted bow which fires needlessly slowly and draws out the boredom.

Maybe I'll go play something else. Oh look it's dark now. Oh I can see another player run... oh no that's a zombie! I'll just nerd tower onto this sawmill roof and wait for morning. Oh god they're ripping down the walls! The roof is falling down!

How I survived that first night I'll never know but with that the true survival horror nature of the game became clear to me. As I told my friend of my experience he replied Just wait til night 7 lol". "Wait

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is currently in an alpha version and is neither complete nor error free, but has a lot of gameplay and fun.
You can play solo on your pc or online on servers (many fans are providing servers).
It will take some time to learn to survive the start.

7 Days to Die is a survival game and a combination of a FPS zombie shooter with minecraft. In the starting phase you try to survive while you are collecting the materials for crafting your first equipment.
Then you are busy with the following things:
Exploring the map to collect materials and recipes and improving the equipment
Killing zombies
Building a defense base to survive the nights with ever-increasing waves of attacking zombies
Repairing and extending the base

This game is even in early access better than many fully developed" games.


In my guide you can find more Infos:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=292958838"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Survival Horror Sandboxing

Starting the game I found myself in a scene very reminiscent of Silent Hill. A wrecked car sat in the road beside me surrounded by my worldly belongings and the desert wasteland was entirely unfamiliar to me. Gathering up my few worldly possessions I boldly set forth into the unknown and was immediately set upon and ripped apart by a pack of wild dogs.

So exactly like Silent Hill then.

My next few attempts fared little better. I tried to break into a house and was snuck up on and stunlocked to death by zombies, I approached a car junkyard and mysteriously died with no apparent cause like in the opening of 13 ghosts, and I had another go at meleeing zombies getting myself stunlocked to death.

Part of the problem is that zombie moans barely change in loudness depending on distance or facing, so a zombie could be trying to extract itself from someone's scummy backyard swimming pool 3 blocks away and you will still hear it hissing in your ear, which makes it hard to tell when zombies are actually close since you just stop listening eventually.

How I survived that first night I'll never know but with that the true survival horror nature of the game became clear to me. As I told my friend of my experience he replied Just wait til night 7 lol". "Wait

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\n7 Days to Die is one of those games that you want to share with friends who have never played before, and let them experience its' awesomeness with you. It's a voxel based survival crafting tower defense game that touches on gameplay similar to Minecraft and Fallout 3. At first I was quite apprehensive about this game, mostly because of it's poor reviews and, at that time, the price. I nabbed it when it was on sale, then learned that the developers had lowered the price indefinitely. As I played, exploring immense landscapes, learning crafting recipies, and adapting nighttime survival strategies, I began to wonder why this game had gotten such poor reviews. I know now that I should have bought this game long ago, even at its high price. I have enjoyed watching 7 Days to Die's progress more than any other early access game I have played up to this point. I've found myself on more than one occasion reading players' conflicting suggestions and complaints, then come next update realize that the developers had actually listened to that constructive criticism and developed a method to try to satisfy everybody. You can adjust different settings to cater to your specific preferences and difficulty, even after you have started your game. If it gets too easy, just bump up the zombie spawn rate, or vice versa. I wouldn't recommend this one to gamers who have no patience for early access bugs. Don't expect glitch free bliss with this one. But the pros highly outweigh the cons. Judging by what I've seen the game progress to, I have a good feeling that for us patient gamers who appreciate meaningful development...the end product will be well worth it!
voteText: 19 of 33 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI am not recommending this game at this point not because of the gameplay. But off of the fact that if you want to play this game with a friend in a co-op game that is private is almost impossible without spending more money on a server or joining someone else's server. I preferably love this game, great potential, but it is the most aggrevating thing when a friend works his hind end off to get enough money to buy the game, and quickly come to find out that it takes nothing short of money or a miracle to join his friends game. If anyone has found a way to do a private co-op match then let me know. At this point if you have hopes for you and your buddies to survive this apocalypse in a unpenetrable fortress that all of you created, it is not worth it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\n7DTD ay only yet be at alpha 5.1 but has lots to do already and is pretty playable long term even without all the systems coming in place yet.  It can be nerve wracking and an adreniline rush strying to stay alive during the day when the zombies are calm and you need to gather supplies and then try and survive the night when they are very fast and aggressive.  The game has a lot coming to it still but has a huge amount now.  The price might seem high, but your buying the final release and getting early access now.  Good video of what is coming on the 7daystodie.com site and on their forums.  The Fun Punks (developers) are extremely responsvie and pay a lot of attention to feedback and what palyers are looking for.  The games has different levels of survivor mode (if you can you can survive well past 7 days) and also horde modes which let you try and survive 7 days without scavenging but just getting air drops of supplies.  More game modes coming.  Its great to play solo or multiplayer and its popular so has many servers available to play on.  Zombies come in many forms from just teh walking dead to acid spitting zombies, crawling zombies that grab ankles, wall crawling zombies that can reach you on second and third and higer stories, aggressive (day and night) zombie dogs and mutated hornets!  The game has a expansive crafting system where you can use items scavengered to make other items, mine and farm and forage for crafting supplies.  Guns and ammo, food and water and other necessities can be found or made.  The game can really keep you on the edge of your seat the whole time you play.

It can be nerve wracking and an adreniline rush strying to stay alive during the day when the zombies are calm and you need to gather supplies and then try and survive the night when they are very fast and aggressive.  The game has a lot coming to it still but has a huge amount now.  The price might seem high, but your buying the final release and getting early access now.  Good video of what is coming on the 7daystodie.com site and on their forums.  The Fun Punks (developers) are extremely responsvie and pay a lot of attention to feedback and what palyers are looking for.  The games has different levels of survivor mode (if you can you can survive well past 7 days) and also horde modes which let you try and survive 7 days without scavenging but just getting air drops of supplies.  More game modes coming.  Its great to play solo or multiplayer and its popular so has many servers available to play on.  Zombies come in many forms from just teh walking dead to acid spitting zombies, crawling zombies that grab ankles, wall crawling zombies that can reach you on second and third and higer stories, aggressive (day and night) zombie dogs and mutated hornets!  The game has a expansive crafting system where you can use items scavengered to make other items, mine and farm and forage for crafting supplies.  Guns and ammo, food and water and other necessities can be found or made.  The game can really keep you on the edge of your seat the whole time you play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It got this game a while ago and honestly didn't really like it too much, but that was probably because I was new to the whole craft/survival thing, and the game did not do a great job at making it easy to understand how to survive, but now the game is very friendly to start, and the crafting interface is extremely easy to understand even if you are picking up the game for the first time. With the added skill trees and the natural progression you gain from just doing random things such as using a bow or crafting is a really nice added feature.

The game definitely gives you chills, and you can't hide forever, The zombies WILL find you, and one night what ever little shack you decided to stay the night in will be destroyed and you will have to run while a horde of sprinting zombies chase you down. Hope you have good stamina or GGWP.

I did come across a nice place located in the middle of a river, (coordinates 580N, 70E) I've been shacking up here and it survived an attack from a horde, if you are having trouble this is definitely a good place to set up camp

Overall this is a very good game, and would definitely recommend to anyone looking for a scary survival game.

Pro Tip: Don't fight bears.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hard facts after 770 hours of gameplay
I gotta say that this game is not what i payed for and changed a lot mostly to the worse. It used to be fun but it becomes more and more of a ridiculous grindfest and if u have a job or you study but want to get far in the game then forget it...
(i played in a group of 4 and it was still just lots of grinding with no end)
The developers try to force you to spent more time in game by making simple things more complicated with every so rare patch instead of actaully adding new content to the game that would keep u busy on advanced stages. On advanced stages its exactly as boring as it was, now it will just take you longer to get there.. trough lots boring and time consuming endless grinding...
Terrible , lazy solution if you ask me.

PROS:
Great Building aspect.

CONS:

- Object/Weapons textures could be way better i mean even the original not HD Skyrim was better and that game is like what 3-4 years old now?The landscape textures are just bad, but they added HD light effects? set your priorities straight...
Sound quality is super cheap. Game performance is poorly optimized if you can talk about optimization at all.

-Glitchy graphics like see trough ground textures. You may eventualy fall trough such a glitch into a endless fall.
Glitching terrain textures which will form some awkward shapes and block your path so you could even get stuck in them.

-Glitchy zombie animations (which can get you killed)

-Lags ,many lags, even if your machine fits the optimal requirments or is above.

- Finding a decent community is very hard.

- Too many hackers and no decent protection to keep them out.

- Leveling... Well this is the worst level/upgrade system you ever saw besides of the fact that it kills immersion and dances on its grave, It just feels not realistic and annoying as if it was pushed in just to exist because hey all other games have that so lets kinda have one too.All the drops are now level adjusted says you have no chance of getting any even partly decent weapon/tool. It sells it self as a realistic survival game right, says it depends on scavenging and looting for things which will help you to keep the fight and stay alive... those are things which depend on luck , you should be able to find something great or trash... here you will find only trash till you get to a higher level no exception.	 Where is the thrill of what is in the next house im going to loot? What keeps me motivated to go on? 20 more levels of trash and no hope? probably not.

-Extreme time consuming farming for resources. I get it here they wanted to make it suddnly more realistic on this part right? And they did it, exactly on the spot where no one would like it to be.
I mean did i buy a mining or wood chopping simulator and didnt know it?
If i would love to spent hours and hours on braking stone and chopping wood i could as well just go outside now and do it in real life.
Immersion is great but not in everything.

- Bugs spawn endless stream of hordes for several days which will ♥♥♥♥ your base.
At this moment kiss your ammo good bey (which is hard to get) not only because the hords will really not end but also because now you will miss your target even if you aim dead on.
Why? Because you dont have the skill points spent on this type of a weapon.... and that is supposed to be a ego shooter? a game where your true aim doesnt count for sh*t?

-You will spent most of the day just eating and drinking or searching for food and drink. There is no end to your thirst and hunger.

- Now the furnace takes like two hours or so (real life time) just to let you use the resources u grinded hours for already.And that is only for you to be able to start crafting and that doesnt include the long crafting times yet.

- The weapons and tool crafting system is insanely bad, back in time you would have to advance from wood to iron to steel as far as you would get those... now u have to level up tool smithing to insanity just to get a dam pickaxe which will not break after some couple of hits. I dont start on the guns.

- Devs dont listen to the community and seem only to fix things which are ultimatly game breaking while closing eyes on other known bugs.

- Fixes take too long or dont happen in some cases, even though they tend to releas some hot fixes after every patch there are too many bugs which survived over a very long period of time.

- I see no new content for almost a year and god this game lacks on that.
And when they do add some little new thing to the game, that thing is going to be bugged!
like those mini bikes,that took you hours maybe days to put together and would glitch trough the ground on your first ride saying bey bey. just one of many examples.

-PvP is crap. Besides the hackers that will destroy your base no one can raid anyone! Because of the land-claim block which makes buildings indestructible.
Again one point where they need more immersion but hey stone chopping realism was top priority i guess so they had to leave the less important game aspects out.


I could go on for a longer list but i think this is enough info to form a opinion on the product.
Its very sad how they keep ruining this game.
And by now the game it self looks like a dead end. Sadly i see no future for this project, I would be happy if they would prove me wrong though.

Do i recommend this game? No, definitly not anymore!
I would strongly recommend to not buy it at the current stage.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nTried of zombie games that suppose to be coop and fight against zombies but in the end it's just PvP with tons of hacker? Wait no more! This game truely has a coop mode where everyone teams up and kills the infected. It contains elements from minecraft and survival games including Day Z. When you play during the day you might say to yourself, the zombies only walks, and the only real threat is the Police man and the zombie dogs. INCORRECT. At night all thoses walking zombies you can out-run them in just 1 second are now running, stronger, and more dangerous then before. Even a Vertern player with the best guns can fall and become zombie food at night. So what do I do at night if the zombies are too deadly?!?!?!? Well there's 3 options, go at them at full speed and get kill in 2 seconds. Be a sneaky snake and pray they dont find you. Or you can man up and build a home!!! That's right you can build your own home. Now I'm safe right? NOPE! Zombies can smell and hear you still and they can look through windows. There some special zombies like the spider zombie that can climb up to your so called sniping spot" on your roof and slaughter you. At day you must gather food

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHaving used to being a heavy gamer in my younger years before growing up like we all have to do eventually and taking on the responsibilities of a working life i wanted to still be able to have a lil gaming session from time to time but finding an appropriate game that could be played here and there and picked up from where i left off was hard to come by. I wasnt very knowledgable with sandbox games and how much fun they can be. If you are the type of person like myself with a busy personal life but seeking a game that is challenging/easy going (subject to your game set up options) alot of fun and prefer to enjoy coop with friends than online inc pvp then look no further. Having the freedom of doing whatever you want to the environment and building bases to survive, looting, crafting, messing around with friends for giggles and having to look over your shoulder from zombies especially during the night then this comes highly recommended. We all seek different needs from a game and i am easily satisfied with one. With the randomly generated worlds coming in one of the next updates this game is always going to be fun for me personally and others who enjoy this sort of thing. You can make the game as hard as you want or as easy as you want with the ingame options but may have to do a little bit of trial and error to find the most enjoyble setup. If anyone is considering this game but not sure then feel free to message me for any advice or want to know more before buying it in the Alpha stage.  Happy gaming ladies and gents.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In the long line of survival games mushrooming up nowadays, this one really gets it right!

There is nothing that makes a zombie game more stupid than stupid zombies.....

DayZ?  => Nobody is even looking at the zombies
Rust?  => They removed them... and not too soon
Minecraft?  => Known for the almighty Creeper.

But with 7d2d you'll find the definition of Zombies that you are looking for.  Scary monsters banging on your house, and you'll be there, crouched with your crossbow, ready to shoot out of any hole that will appear in your shabby, wooden house.

Besides this, you'll also have a long list of items to craft, different areas to explore, and to build your own.

This is an alpha, and it shows.  They have some tweaking to do on their game so it's more efficient for FPS & smoothness (particulary for multiplayer) , as well as add more content.  Still, even in its current state it is already a game that will hook you to your pc for days and have you looking forward to every future update.

If you like this genre, this is definetly worth your time to check out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Best game I have played in a very long time.  It is still in developement, but is better then anything most major game studios have put out in years.  Easily.
- If you at all have interest in killing zombies then this is for you.
- If you at all enjoy immerisive survival(ie splinting your leg when you take a fall, drinking boiled water instead of water straight from a pond) this is for you.
- If you like exploration this game is VERY MUCH for you.
- If you like crafting/building games (ie minecraft) this game is right up your alley.
-Please note, this game will take you more then a half hour to understand.  It is hard, you will die, a lot.  Once you get your feet under you, and start procceding along the learning curve, the game opens up and is quite exciting. I have been playing avidly for over a week now and I am still being amazed by the content I am discovering and starting to incorporate into my play style.  (ie farming coffee so I can go caffine crazy and sprint like a track star.  etc)

Furthermore, it should be mentioned that when creating custom worlds to play in the user can extinsivly customize the game settings, tailoring the game to whatever is more entertaining for their particular play style and interests.  (ie I have a friend who doesn't enjoy survial games, he plays it as just a FPS zombie horde slaying, exploration game.)

In conclusion, this game brings together aspects of a lot of games, in one package that functions quite well and provides a challenging, immersive, custimizable, and extremely fun experience.  Expect to find your self playing this game significantly more then you may of anticipated. I sure have!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I LOVE IT!!! It's totally minecraft meets The Walking Dead... there are a few things that still need some work and things, but for a game that is still in its Alpha stage its agazing

Update:

From the time of this initial review till now there have been some substancial changes. Random Gen. maps, lighting adjustments, physics, etc. you can read the patch notes if you would like a complete list of changes. there are sill a few minor flaws with the game but in my opinion it is VERY polished and functional for an late alpha stage game. Mining, salvaging, crafting, farming, sandbox free-roam / build. and Zombies.. we can't forget the zombies. The zombie AI is a bit... off if you ask me, but thats just my personal take on it. bodies de-spawn WAY to quickly after death leaving you unable to loot all the bodies when say a small horde of 8-12 zombies are finished off you have have the opertunity to look say 3-6 depending on your speed and how quickly you dispatch the group.

There is a hang up with cooking fires and forges when maps hit around the 900+ day marker where you can put fuel and ingreadents in, but the timers don't count down and therefor don't make your food / water / smelt, etc.

Block tie-ins are a personal annoyance to me and a few rotations on specifics as well. for example the Iron Bars. when placed you can ONLY place bars in the vertical orientation from left to right, front to back, diaginal etc. you can't rotate them to place then horizontal AT ALL for placements like ledges or overhangs. They also DON'T tie into the blocks around them as they don't occupy" the full block there is a gap on the side of them that is easily walked thru... and thus zombies can bypass them aswell.

These are a few of the flaws I am aware of
date: but have come to accept as this game is still in development and is progressing VERY nicely and is updated often with LOTS of improvements and changes. In closing
recommended:
its WELL worth the $$ for the amount of time you can easily spend in game exploring both your survival instinct and your creative side.

Holy crap this game has come a long way this year so far. New animals, Blood moons, More crafting than you can ask for, mining, survival, scavaging, zambies and new zambies recently. Its like Fallout adopted a baby from Minecraft and Left for Dead...... The game, not the Baby.

Been playing this game since a couple of months after it went Alpha and holy crap it was buggy. Now i hardly run into bugs anymore. The major ones like map chunks missing, unlootable animals, disappearing drop crates. The graphics have come a loooooong way. Beautiful and taxing. I have a decent PC and it chugs a little when there is a lot of lighting (torches) on max settings. Theres a system in crafting now with different and improved tiers of quality that improve as you level. YEP RPG system as well. I know reviews are supposed to have the pros and cons but at this moment its my favorite game and i look forward to seeing what they do in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game. It's still in Alpha, but playable with a few bugs (sniper rifle).

I would compare this to a L4D2/Minecraft combination. With that being said, the game can get frustrating at the begining, but once you have a system down it becomes less frustrating and more resource stockpiling. In that it is a combination of those games, you will see alot of enemies that are very simular to L4D2 enemies. Cops are almost identical to the Spitter in the series. A few enemies are quite unique and can be a headache while trying to gather equipment. The idea you have to build everything is quite simular to Minecraft, except the list of available items to create and thier plans are all right there, removing the need to go wiki to look up ingredents.  The game does last longer than 7 days as a contridiction to the title, which is nice.

There are many different options when starting a game. From single player to multiplayer, random map or Storyline map. The options of what happens to your gear when you die, how often items reset, how often airdrops happen, and even the legth of each day (way awesome).

Some very interesting ideas that the game does offer is the ability to become infected, suffer from injury and disease, and attract zombies with some of the items you can have in your inventory. The ability to go into sneak" is almost exactly like Skyrim
date: to include the HUD icon.\n\nThe multiplayer portion of this game is what seals it down as a great game. When set up right it makes things interesting for a 4v4 multiplayer map as teams can fight over resources in an area
recommended:
all while also trying to keep from being killed by zombies.

The down side to this game is that the crafting time can be really long and some resources aren't easily available as fast as you will go though them (brass and gas). If you don't have a good balance of difficulty you can find yourself spending your time just grinding with little to no challange.

Tips: Leave your zombie run to Default
hoursPlayed: set your bag to "delete" when you die
voteText: and set your day/night ratio to 50%."
