reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have had this game for quite some time but had not gotten around to playing it.    I kept checking back and reading reviews and forums to see how it was coming along even though I owned a copy.   I was waiting to see when it reached a point where family and friends might decide to dive in.    That point was reached a few weeks ago.

I downloaded the Dedicated Server and fired it up in my house.   Myself and two of my sons jumped into it and spent A LOT of time dying.   We loved every minute of it.   We could immediately see it could be a challenge and it had a lot of things to do.    The effects of drinking unpurified water from lakes, rivers, etc and getting the little squatting and pooping icon in the lower left corner while you run around with the effects of diarhea is just one of numerous funny things.   However, the game is serious and even though that is funny it is a serious thing and is simulated as such.   It is only funny to realize the game simulates to that level and can be quite amusing.

As this game is in early access it keeps getting better and better.    This is all my son, and wife have been playing for about two weeks straight now.   They'd put spikes strategically in river crossing points for zombie hordes, they've built towers for sniper posts, they've dug and built larger underground homes with large amounts of storage, they've established corn, cotton, coffee, potato, blueberry, and other farms near their location.

They currently exploit a bug where if you are deep underground and stand close to a wall and look up it will clip and you can see the surface way above you and watch the hordes of zombies wander around.    This game is very stable from our experience, has a ton of features, and is for the most part bug free.    It has come a long way and can be a lot of fun.

Also, if you've wanted a more co-op Zombie Survival game than the DayZ fare and don't really want to deal with the PvP aspects that is an option here.   However, it can be also run in the free for all style where newbs are fair game to camping  veterans who hunt them.    Our personal dedicated server this is not a problem and we just deal with surviving and exploring in the environment.

It does have a standard map that it uses, but it also generates random maps that work really well.

In this game surprisingly the DESERT biome is a nice place to be.   You can survive on Cactus fruit, and make Yuka Juice. :)   It has quite a number of Biomes.

More realism is hopefully coming in the future such as greater thirst in deserts, and needing to have clothes or something suitable in the winter environments.   Those would be nice features.   They'd make the game harder, but that only extends its challenge and longevity.

I very much recommend this game.

For the Unity haters out there.   This game is made with Unity but functions very well.
voteText: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Holy crap this game has come a long way this year so far. New animals, Blood moons, More crafting than you can ask for, mining, survival, scavaging, zambies and new zambies recently. Its like Fallout adopted a baby from Minecraft and Left for Dead...... The game, not the Baby.

Been playing this game since a couple of months after it went Alpha and holy crap it was buggy. Now i hardly run into bugs anymore. The major ones like map chunks missing, unlootable animals, disappearing drop crates. The graphics have come a loooooong way. Beautiful and taxing. I have a decent PC and it chugs a little when there is a lot of lighting (torches) on max settings. Theres a system in crafting now with different and improved tiers of quality that improve as you level. YEP RPG system as well. A survival aspect called wellness" that determines your Health and Stamina.

I know reviews are supposed to have the pros and cons but at this moment its my favorite game and i look forward to seeing what they do in the future.

I still remember my first play.

Spawn in the middle of a forrest.
Loot car and various items around
Find a cabin
setup shelter
Dont know they busted my door down
Get ♥♥♥♥♥ by a nude zambi

11/10
Have gotten ♥♥♥♥♥ by neumerous nekid zambies

Thanks The Fun Pimps. Keep up the good work."

Friday 7 March 2014

First off, I would like to say that this game was not always fun or playable for me. When I got it in Alpha 6 for $25 bucks, it took forever to load and initialize, the game lagged badly and frequently, and there were definitely some features, such as the random map generation mechanism, that simply were not there. My laptop is running Windows 8 with a 2.7 GHz AMD processor and 4GB of RAM, so lag should not have been a problem according to the posted game requirements. It made me upset, and I was very unhappy that I was unable to play the game I had just dropped $25 on.

And then along came Alpha 7.

Decided to give a little more of an indepth review since there doesn't seem to be many of them.

1. Crafting:
- Building: You can craft pretty much whatever you want to build out of. Cobblestone, brick, prick paver for a pool, stone, whatever.
- Traps: You can also craft pipe bombs, sharpened sticks, land mines, use spider webs, anything to help fortify your hold.
- Food: Yes you can make multiple kinds of food though a cooking and items like gas cans through the chemistry system.
- Aestetics: What fun is the zombie apocolypse if you can't have pretty things in your house? You can now craft items (or steal them, and tv's/paintings from rich people), to decorate your house!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do I wish to recommend this game? Yes.
Look further down for a longer explanation.
I recommend this game, simply because the game is brilliant and it only gets better with multiplayer. This is a great game for you and your friends and you are gonna have a good time. However, this is not a perfect game at all and I will list my impressions of this game so far (remember it's early access, things can change).

+
You can play alone, with friends on LAN and on servers
Game cointains Navezgane-map and random generation. Navezgane will be boring to play after a while because you will get to know the map quite well. Random generation, however, will create your world entirely random as for landscape and prefabs via a seed system like in Minecraft.
Many recipes for craftable items for building, weaponry, armory, food, drink, medicin. You start with basic recipes and will unluck some as you find recipe books.
Smart gravity, fitness and quality system makes the game a lot of fun; even after 10 hours because the world feels alive, you can improve your stamina, so there is a reason for playing it awhile and the quality range as for weapons and tools makes many items unique and rewards the player for her/his hard work.
Many lootable places such as houses (small ones, tall ones, big ones), waste bunkers, cinemas, supermarkets, shopping carts, vaults, weapon shops, gas stations, banks and apartment buildings.
Different types of enemies: Zombies (feral zombie, slow zombie, fast zombie, nurse zombie, spider zombie), dogs, bees. There are animals as well (although they're not aggressive. Bears will come in an update soon, though)

-
The game is not optimized at all, even after switching to Unity 5 (the engine on which the game is build).
Even on a high-end pc, this game won't look particularly beautiful, at best it will look decent.
Different bugs (which might/might not be fixed) such as: Texture flickering, extreme impact from small jumps resulthing in sprained or broken legs, some zombie bodies will bug out (you'll know when it happends).
There are too many server wipes and not enough people to fill out the variety of servers.

Final conclusion and a comment:
Currently, the game is 8/10 in terms of overall quality. Play it for gameplay and content, not graphics. Otherwise, you will be disappointed. As for my final comment, I will talk a little about the developers: The Fun Pimps. The game is, as you might already know, in early access and it is being updated frequently. These updates are big updates cointaining huge chances such as Unity 5 and random generation, but also smaller updates addressing bugfixes and improvents. In other words, the updates are very various. However, as for the developers, communication isn't what they do best. When they wanted to switch to Unity 5, it took months and many people was frustrated because of the lack of information on steam. However, if you are interested in their project, whether you have the game or not, check out their tumblr account. Look for Joel Huenink on Tumblr and youtube and you will get an insight as to what they are currently working on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is by far the best in its genre.

7 Days to Die is the perfect mix between crafting / survival and building / sandbox. The multiplayer is very similar to that of RUST or Day Z on public servers, with a much more intricate crafting and building system.

7DTD is like a combination of everything good about Minecraft and RUST. It has a voxel based, infinitely generated world and block based building system similar to Minecraft, and a crafting system that far exceeds that of RUST. There are randomly generated points of interest, including many shops and stores filled with valuable loot. Three types of animals can be found (pigs, deer, and rabbits) and the zombies are plentiful and varied.

The gameplay is multi-staged as you build and grow a base. Scavanging is essential to find food and water in order to survive another day, until you are able to start a farm for food. There are many different types of edible items, some of which give positive or negative buffs.

The buff system is a masterpiece. Eating rotten food will lower your stamina temporarily, coffee can increase your stamina for a period of time, and zombies will infect you with enough damage. Antibiotics will cure your infection, but they are rare to find and hard to craft. Luckily it takes days for your infection to progress, up to three stages before you will die from it giving plenty of time to find that essential cure. Painkillers increase health over time as well as medical bandages, and a hit from an enemy can cause you to bleed out if you aren't careful.

The penalty for death is extreme. Every time you die, your wellness is lowered by 10 points, meaning your maximum stamina and health goes down 10%. Wellness starts at 100 and goes up to 200, but for a new player this is a crippling handicap. Increasing your wellness is very hard to do, as the only thing that really helps is the very uncommon antibiotics. You can cook several types of items together into a pie that will increase your wellness, but during the early game without a farm this is an impossible feat, and the benefit is very small. If you are experienced enough to survive, increasing your wellness will double your health and prevent you from dying nearly as much.

Every 7 days a super horde spawns, with many powerful zombies that will see you nomatter where you are. You can not hide, you can not run. As zombies run at night, having a base strong enough to survive their assault is required. Scavanging for and building guns and bullets to fight the horde is an intermediate skill, as you need to mine for coal and potassium nitrate in order to create gunpowder.

Now that the positive things are out of the way, here are the negative things. As I'm writing this review during early access, please note that some of these things might change. First off, the wellness system needs some work. Once you die a few times it is nearly impossible to get back to full health. They have attempted to fix this by making it scale to your health, so the lower your health the more wellness you will get but at it's current stage it is still very flawed, and detracts from the game experience. This is especially important for new players, who will find themselves unable to damage zombies or sprint for more than 10 seconds at a time.

There are still many glitches present, most notably the fireplace glitch. Sometimes when cooking large amounts of food or water you will lose everything. Occasionally you will duplicate an item. This is a serious glitch that I hope gets addressed soon. I have wanted to quit many times after hording enough food and water to survive, just to see it dissapear before my very eyes. If you have a full inventory, harvesting your crops will result in losing your crops, as harvested plants don't drop but instead dissapear. If you are crafting an item and log out, you will lose everything in your crafting area. This is very bad because certain items, such as TNT, take a long time to craft and you can forget that you are crafting them and log out, leading to a large waste of very precious resources. There are a few other glitches but none of them are noteable here.

Another gripe I have is the lack of tutorial or information, similar to Minecraft. Almost everything in this game can be found by playing, but certain things like food recipes and controls aren't very obvious such as the RUST-like opening of doors and fireplaces. It would be nice if they added readable books in the environment to at least address this issue.

Also the ingame voice chat could use some work as it does not seem to function well or at all, and communication in a game like this is absolutely essential.

My final verdict is to BUY THIS GAME IMMEDIATELY. The develeopers The Fun Pimps are constantly updating this game with bug fixes and new features, but in it's current state it is well worth 30$. I Kickstarted this game because the quality was immediately visible, and it has now become the gold standard of early access in my opinion. I would strongly recommend that you play this with others as the difficulty is rather high, and building / defending a base with friends exponentially increases the fun. If you have ever enjoyed Minecraft, RUST, Day Z, or other similar games like The Forest, this game is a must buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Firstly, great concept for a game. Love the mix of crafting with first person shooter aspects, along with the building physics which add a nice touch. Generally I feel a sense of desperation while I play it as zombies whittle away at my defences during the night and I have been scared ****less as those flying hornets that fly straight at my face. I find this game gives me a decent amount of enjoyment and is a good time killer.

Unfortunately, these experiences are somewhat dulled down due to a clunky interface and fractured gameplay. This can be mostly forgiven due to it being in alpha stage of development so nothing is going to be perfect, however the price tag is misleading and gives the impression of a far more polished game. £22 is ALOT to be spending on an unfinished early access game, and does not match the experience and features that you will get. I understand that the developers may be looking to boost their funds to continue polishing this game, but £22 is a long shot for a game that has this many issues. I have to admit that if I hadn't seen youtubers play this game I would not have paid as much as I did, and if I had the opportunity now I would rather wait until later on when the game is more complete until I commit myself to buying it.

So would I recommend this game? In the future, maybe. In its current state? Probably not. Although it is guaranteed to give you a few laughs and some enjoyment, I would recommend waiting to see how this game unfolds before you part with your cash.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The following is my thoughts on the game after 80.2 hours of playing, current version alpha 11.3 (April 26, 2015)
I haven't been playing the game that much nowadays but still enjoy starting a new game whenever I marathon a bunch of podcasts. It's a great game to mindlessly play at low difficultly settings while listening to some crap. ;)

The game has been updated frequently and now has some real good looking graphics after updating to Unity 5. Along with the updated graphics comes optimizations. I never get low frames that much anymore even with maxed settings.

Still a great game to play.


The following is my thoughts and experiences of the game after 48.7 hours of playing alpha 8 through 10.4 hotfix.  (December 21, 2014)
My experience has been a little less enjoyable after playing for so many hours straight. Hordes spawn too fast with as much as only 2 minutes between horde attacks even when the game is set to low spawn rates. It's only day 3 on this new world, I don't think they should be coming this fast. But I guess that just adds to the challenge that many say is the proper way to play the game.

The game's unoptimized state has never really bothered me that much as I was always able to maintain a good 60 in nearly all parts of the map with settings turned to low or off. The city was where it'd some times drop to 50 and below. But with how fast these hordes are spawning my fps frequently dips to <30fps while they're around making the game stutter and hard to defend against attacks.

Even with these issues I'm still going back to the game multiple times a week. It's great watching the game slowly take shape with each update from the dev team!


The following is my thoughts and experiences of the game after 22.8 hours of playing alpha 8 through 10.1.  (November 30, 2014)
I like it.



The reason I had any interest to pick up this game was because of the Game Society Pimps and their videos. If not for them I might of just passed on this game.
This is a very fun open world sandbox zombie survival game. It's fun playing with your friends.
There are bugs and it's not optimized but as it's still in alpha and these problems should be resolve by the time the game is done.

PS - I had a pretty sweet underground base.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is trash, even if it was free to play you'd feel like you've been ripped off. It's hard to believe that a game with graphics this bad can run so poorly. Even if the terrible looking enviorment and zombies don't bother you, the unstable framerate is ridiculous.

The combat system is garbage, probably the worst hit detection I've ever seen in a first person game. A zombie can strike you from 2-3x their arm length. You'd swear it's a latency problem but then you realize you're playing single player. Escaping from zombies doesn't seem possible anymore, they can spawn a few feet in front of you right out in the open.

I didn't mind the incredible amount of time between updates when it was actually improving the game. The latest build however seems to have only added garbage that inconveniences you. It feels like 13 was thrown together at the last minute, not something that's been carefully planned out for months.

Listening to the positive reviews for this game was a mistake I made. I understand that different people like different things, but some of the praise I've seen this game get makes me think these people have never played a basic survival game in their entire lives.

I can't believe this game's price is near other EA games like Killing Floor 2 or Ark: Survival Evolved.

This is likely the worst game in EA, it should never have made it through Greenlight.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It saddens me greatly to have to do this. I have been around this game since the days of alpha 8. However I cannot recommend this game in its present form. Alpha 13 broke so many things that didn't need tweaking in the first place. The crafting system is gone (it’s still there but is a former shell of itself) right clicking is gone to search is gone. The whole new interface practically slaps you in the face to break immersion it simply doesn’t fit. It looks like a computer interface it’s too clean almost if that makes any sense. the inventory interface doesn't feel like it belongs in a survival game rather then a down and gritty crafting aspect we are left with something that has all the recipes listed that you can just click on and it auto crafts them for you what did this need fixing ?. Zeds take forever to kill now, and can still hit you from 10ft away. The rate at which you get cold or hot is way off balance. Basically if you spawn in a snow biome or a desert biome you’re hosed.
now on to my next gripe.  My system specs
amd 8350fx
asus rog am3+ mb
16gb g skills 2400mhz ram
crossfired 7950s
500gb 10k rpm hd
corsair h100i cooler
1250 watt seasonic gold rated psu
Windows 7
I should have no issues running this game hell fallout 4 runs at 60+ on ultra with no frame rate issues. So why on earth am I having lag spikes and frame rate drops from 60 down to 15 in some areas for no given reasons what so ever. Tried with both video cards then tried with just one still the same thing. I understand this is alpha but hells so is ark and I still manage a solid 40-50 on that on ultra. I love this game i really do I like the concept and up until alpha 13 I loved where it was going. However in its present state I cannot suggest anyone buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I remember when I first started playing this game, the first hour of frustration trying to figure it out before it finally clicked and it was suddenly so much fun. It was literally my favorite game, I remember calling my cousin just to tell him he needs to buy it so we could play together. He doesn't even play games, I was just so excited I wanted someone to ♥♥♥♥ around with on this crazy new game I found, it was so fun.

That was back in A9 or so, though, and I hate to say it's gone downhill from there. While the game improves visually (it's honestly damn sexy for a voxel game especially if you get to play it on max) the fun just slowly disappears. I'm not getting bored of it, it's just getting not fun. Crafting is being dumbed down while survival is getting harder, the interface has been so simplified that it's become complicated (it makes sense if you've played it) and the scavenging/foraging has turned into literally nothing more than hold click until the tree/rock/dirt's healthbar reaches nil" which takes absolutely forever on everything now and just makes it feel even more repetitive than it already was.

I've tried a few times to play it during A13 and now it's finally reached the point where I just can't. I'll try again in A14 but for the time being I can't even reach the point where I can craft a forge (literally the point where the game actually starts) without giving up out of boredom. It's just grinding now
date: except instead of killing zombies you're killing foliage. It's much less suspenseful.\n\nIf they can stop trying to complexify and simplify at the same time I think the game's still got a chance
recommended: but right now the game's developers seem more confused than I do and that's never a good sign."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this game quite a bit in alpha 12.5, and while the game still has potential in A13 it is going in a direction I really don't like.
Right now, the game is playable, but not intuitive and definitely not new-player friendly.
Granted, it was hard for newbs before, but that was due to the hostile environment and enemies ambushing you.
Now, in addition to that (and bugged enemies) they also have to fight the interface and system to get anything done. And that is AFTER they've manged to SLOWLY grind their way to the same action speeds new characters had when starting in A12.5! Front loading the tedium to make you EARN to have fun later is not the way to go.
Yet one of the more prominent people in the  developer team for this game is very rude, and constantly acts dismissive of many complaints the community has with the game. His fanboys are even worse, and it's frankly sickening to watch.

So, why do I?
Because the game, at its core, is really good. It is, and it has so much potential to get even better. If this was still A12.5 I'd recommend the game in a heartbeat. But right now it's just not fun to play anymore.

I advice you to stay away until the game is completed and judge then if you find it interesting. You seriously don't want to participate in this particular development cycle.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As someone who has never played Minecraft and still has no interest in it, it's strange that I have taken so quickly to 7 Days to Die.

Perhaps it's because I enjoyed playing games like Left 4 Dead, but found the linear approach to the game boring. In 7 Days to Die you can survive the zombie apocalyse in the way you want to! You can be a nomad roaming from town to town, baracading yourself in buildings on the 7th night and not worrying about the place getting trashed. Or build a fortress-like base that you never leave, except to explore. Or build a nice little house to live in, but a bastion somewhere nearby to retreat to.

However, I think it's the multiplayer co-op that makes the game for me. There's nothing better than raiding a town with your friends, hoping to find something special. It's going to get dark soon? Well there's one last house to raid, I've got this feeling there's an SMG schematic in there.

Definitely worth getting when on sale. Probably not worth it on full price if you're going to play solo.

this game takes alot of good features from games like minecraft and builds on them in its own way, obviously this is focused more on survival so this is a strange blend of fending off zombies and building your own creations. The crafting system is very nice and detailed and as of patch 9 the worlds are now endless so there's always places to explore. In my mind this game is best played in a small group of friends.

So far i'd say this is easily one of the best zombie apocalypse themed games i've played. the graphics arent the best, the combat is a bit gittery and there is no character customisation (until patch 10) BUT the gameplay has been pretty damn addictive. Would certainly play this over a game like DayZ

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is VERY fun. Yes there are a hundred minecraft clones out there, but this one really takes the win in terms of actually fun.

Even just being in alpha, there is a lot you can do and more is being added over time. One thing that I really like about the game is buildings and mines actually have a structural integrity.

By that, you can't just build a skyscrapper and expect it to stay standing. Even a one story building that is built to large will collapse. Mineshafts also have to be kept small otherwise they will collapse on you.

Now, being in alpha, the game does have its occassional bug. Right now in a world with my friends, we barely get any zombies to spawn and when they do, they spawn walking towards our location in a line of anywhere between 10 - 40 zombies. The other day when I wasn't playing, they told me a wave of at least 50 showed up.

Defences are helpful but do not last long with the zombies. Different kinds of zombies and enemy types add interesting elements to the game.

One example is normal zombies will just attack your building when they sense you and you can easily repair the damage, but Cop zombies actually puke corrosive bile at the building and destroy blocks instantly.

We have yet to hit night 7, as we had to restart our world a few times to get the hang of the game, but it sounds like it will be a real challenge.

One last fun item is exploring the world is a real treat! Nothing makes you happier than finding an Auger in a random building, which makes digging out a mine 100x easier.

Make sure you have the wiki for the game open if you plan on playing! VERY VERY helpful!

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**The sun is rising, you are all alone, only a few things left in your pack.  Behind you, a stange moan emerging from the trees.  A walker pushes forward and savagely pursues you with humger in its eyes.  Do you fight?  Do you run?  You get one hit in and then are scratched by the creature, begin bleeding out.  Your only hope is that you are not infected as you quickly apply your last bandage and run for cover.  After running a great distance and forging for food, you feel your stomach rumble as you enter a town.  It is swarming with walkers.  If you stay quiet, they may not see you.  The sun is beginning to set, they thrive during the night.  Now it is time for another choice, do you creep into the town hoping to go unseen, running for the safetly of a boarded up home?  Or retreat into the woods, hoping a small hole will hide you until dawn?  How will you survive the first night?**

I cannot say enough about this game- it is exactly what I hoped for!  If you enjoy the gut-wrenching fear of being chased by zombies (most especially for the first several days), mixed with an open world full of crafting, scavenging, and building- then this is certainly a game worth purchasing!
I remember the very first days on the server, with little to your name besides a jar of water, can of beans and a torch.  You are then forced to run or fight, build better weapons, search for food to sustain you and board up and existing home or create your own for the fear of night where the zombies become feral and of course, preparing for the doom of the 7th day horde.
This game has a variety of zombies, lots of variable difficulty options, tons of loot, a completely interactive world, things to craft, things to learn and all with the added fear (at least for me) of being bitten and eaten alive.
I love this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am not often inclined to take the time to write reviews, but this game has shaken my apathy. I was intrigued by the trailer and when the game went on sale I bought it. I don't have a true dedicated gaming computer and I can't run the game on the high setting like you see on some of the YouTube videos of this game and I've never gotten my FPS past 30. That being said I love this game.
The up and down side of this game is that it does not hold your hand and tell you how to do anything. The first three days I played I spent in an adrenaline soaked fearfest. After spending the night crouching and doing nothing in my fortified prefab I made some sort of noise and within moments dozens of wicked fast zombie ripped the walls down and tore me to shreds. After logging off in a panic I went to various wiki pages and YouTube to educate myself. After learning the massive crafting system and the all important first day order of operations (check out Oak's Game Room 7 Days to Die tips and playthroughs) I have since been able to make it 7 days without dying consistantly. I have not played much multiplay and no PvP (for me the zombies are enough to think about, thank you) but I can see the draw, especially because once you've had a chance to make a base, mine ore, find and read the books, craft guns and ammo and stockpile food you become a stand alone army. You will go from hiding from the undead to carrying meat around to attract more, allowing you to further cull Zach's population. That chilling fear of ever present death will be replaced by the rush of power as you look down in complete safety as the undead rush toward your stronghold and kill themselves on your redundant defences, leaving you to tend your garden in peace.
Since the game is in Alpha (I started in 10.4) there are still some major changes coming down the road and a few bugs (very rarely crafted items will disappear from the crafting window if you search for something else), but the game is very playable and quite fun. There are plans to make a story with missions and so on, but there is none of that now and it is still crazy addictive. I would recommend checking this game out and helping the developers flesh out this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After about 30 hrs. of play I can say this is my favorite zombie survival game. I have seen some reviews compairing it to Minecraft, they must have been a bit of time ago because the game has come a long way since then. The land and items are no longer blocky. Hills are a nice and smooth incline and you don't have to jump constantly to navigate it.

The crafting system is great. Some things, like the stone axe (whice normally is the first thing / weapon / tool that you make) can be crafted from the onset of the game. Other items you have to find the recipie and learn it to be able to craft the item. There is also a time element in the crafting, depending on how complex the item depends on how long it takes to make it. The good thing is that if you need to craft a lot of something, like say arrows, once put the items in the grid and start the crafting you can close your inventory (which is where the general crafting grid is, there isn't a crafting table) and the items will keep crafting. It's great especially when you have a group of zombies on your tail and you run out of crossbow bolts. There are several forms of crafting in the game but I will let you figure those out.

The zombies, in my opinion, look and act pretty darn good. There is a nice amount of zombie models and they look good. What might put some off is that even though there are a good amount of different models of zombies, each specific zombie looks the same. The big fat zombies look all the same, no variations. That is no big deal to me, the rest of the game more then makes up for it. The zombie animations are good as well. Sometimes they might act a bit wonkey when traversing an obstical, like when they are stuck in a spike trap they have a tendency to hop and hop. They are creepy as hell when you have a bunch of them shambling towards you and completely terrifying when they are running straight to you (if you have them set to run) with arms out stretched. If you do have them set to run at certain times of the day, the game gives you a great sense of urgency. You know you better be inside somewhere before they start running because you will be dead if you don't, unless you are armed to the teeth.

The devs are great. If the community askes for something, they try to put it in. If the community then decides they really don't like the change they take it out. I have never had the oppretunity to talk with the devs, but everything I have seen on the fourms shows that they listen to what the community.

This is my first review and I hope that it has helped some. If you are still on the fence check out some reviews or let's plays on your favorite video site. But if you like zombies, get this game. If you like crafting, get this game. If you like getting the ever lovin crap scared out of you when you are holed up in the attic of a house and the zombies are outside tearing the house to pieces and you know any second the house is going to collapse, then GET THIS GAME!!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a great combination of minrcatf-like games and fallout. I like that there actually is a danger out thereand your bases must be designed wisely. Getting the perfect base takes time, and you might end up losing everything after some weeks of surviving so the game is a constant challenge.

The online gaming is great most players are nice and respectful, even on PVP, sadly the game seems to have poor security, cause twice in one day hackers logged in and screwed the game for some players. Losing everything to a horde or a fair fight with another player is ok, but spawning TNT through the walls is just frustrating, but that happens rarely and it's a very small minority of the players.

Still a few lags and bugs, but nothing game breaking and very enjoyable during LAN parties. If they keep developping in that direction this game will stay awesome and get even better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a challenging, fun, and entertaining game which is horribly entertaining in its current incarnation.  The fact it's still in Alpha makes that even more impressive.

Fighting off zombies hordes while trying to find enough scraps of food and cups of clean water to survive long enough to mine for resources to build a defensible safehouse has never been so much fun.  Add to that the exhilaration of creating and detonating TNT....and you have a damned-near perfect game.

The A11 update still has a few bugs (though I haven't experienced as many as others), but it restored my excitement about playing 7DTD.  Zombies are freakin hard to kill now, it's nowhere near as easy as it had been to run aound out in the open, and crouching now rightly makes movement painfully slow!  Though it's aggravating as hell to have to recraft so many early weapons/tools because my quality is low since I haven't leveled much yet, I find this adds even more tension to the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having fairly minor experience with free world survival games, playing Rust previously, I had a fun time... but it was missing something, you could get your bases all nice and zombie proof, and essentially player proof within a few days, it became a sniping fest after a little while.

Early access 7DTD however had me screw up fairly quickly, found some unboiled water, promptly drank it while dehydrated and began vomiting everywhere. Found some meat, and had some walkers on my butt within moments. Soon after, I noticed a giant Wasp, which cottoned on to my existence and stung me to death.

Now, after that whole death spam, I made it into a derelict metropolis, noticed a lovely building with plenty of easily exploited areas for drop pits, pungees, and all round safety for my scaredy-cat self. I went out after the first night had finished, hearing sounds of a plethora of walkers that wanted my tasty flesh and took axe to skull... got overwhelmed, and died. Nobody looted my corpse, so that's a bonus. I then began constructing my ultra-secure, 4 story building repairs. Not a soul made it into my place alive.

I began making high powered weapons, and had a very great secondary and tertiary base, all nice and cosy, away from dogs and wasps. The downside being: your bases only have 1 mattress over all bases, so, essentially your respawn may not actually be anywhere near your homebase (really, I'm just an idiot and didn't realise soon enough).

PROS:Super duper easy to kill yourself from things like - water, food, rancid food.
Get drunk.
So. Much. Space. I literally ran for DAYS attempting to reach end borders, or other signs of civilization. I found a few rebar drop fortresses but that was few and far between.
Zombies are smarter than the average bear - they can sniff you, they can hear you.
When night comes, an immense sense of oh shi~ begins. When you get weeks into survival, you can still get mobbed by ever increasing intelligence.
Respawning gun safes, cabinets, book shelves; which all allow recipes and blueprint discoveries - so fun collecting whole sets!
Playing with friends, especially new friends on vent, TS, Skype etc. is hilarious when they're trying to find you and hilariously get mobbed to death before you arrive.CONS:While the Zombie design is cool, there's a lot of rehashed skins, there's little variety to actual Zombies - essentially bruisers, fast walkers, slow walkers, and occasionally a bloat type...
Dogs suck balls.
Wasps suck even more balls, especially without some kind of Crossbow/ Gun on hand.
Underestimating falls and leaps; easily gib yourself...
Sometimes dogs and wasps can warp into your shoeboxes (if you're out on the hunt and need a safe area to die if you're too encumbered).
Climbing Zombies, which I guess is technically a pro, because they also show you your base flaws.
Overall, I really enjoy this game, it's too bad I don't get to play it more, really. P.S. While there are a dime-a-dozen free world Alpha Zombie Survival games, this one does have a certain, I don't know what that really tickles my fancy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While this game may not be the most graphically pleasing (they've actually made it look much better than it did before)
this game has pretty much ruined all of the other survival zombie games for me.

It's similar to minecraft in the sense that the world is never ending (if you set up the server like that) and it's voxel based so the whole entire game world is destroyable.

It did take me a little bit to get used to the whole crafting system of the game but as with most games that have crafting involved, it doesn't take too long to learn what you are doing.

Setting up a private server for my girlfriend and I was extremely easy and we had a blast.

The game really has a 3 part system to it going as:

Beginning:
You are just starting out, having just a can of food, water, and some bandages. It's an intense struggle to survive but usually the most fun.

Middle: You have a somewhat decent base that'll keep you relatively safe during the night and getting food/water isn't as bad as it once was.

End game: You have a pretty OP base, more than enough food/water to survive for quite awhile, many guns, loads of ammo, and you are pretty well off on gear. (This is the least fun part of the game for me)

The game was a blast while just playing PVE with my girlfriend, however if you enjoy PVP then you won't be let down by this game either. Playing on a pvp server is filled with suspense. One second a guy who's naked says he is friendly, the next he is trying to chop your head off with an axe just so he can jack your stuff.

The game has a ton of playability, there was only one VERY SMALL bug that I ever encountered while playing and it wasn't even close to game breaking, and the developers are actively adding new stuff to the game.

7DTD is definitely worth the $25, however you can find it on ♥♥♥ for like $8-9 if you would like to save quite a bit of money.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was already fantastic in the past, but after the a!! update it has surpassed all of my expectations, and put any doubts to bed!

Not only does it now look absolutely incredible, it has become a bit harder to survive the zombie attacks, and the atmosphere has gone stratospheric!

There are some early issues with a few bugs since the big update - for me, they have not been game-breaking or much of a problem at all - in fact the opposite, they are barely noticable and do not negatively impact the gameplay.

I highly recommend this game - after 642 hours and becoming totally addicted to the early alphas, Alpha v11 has just made it even more unmissable! If you have the balls, get the game! You'll be so glad that you did!

On top of that - the devs listen to, and communicate with, their customers.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So.... I might have put some time into this game so far. Almost entirely on random generated worlds- each start being a unique experience and extremely rewarding. I started with the basics and now I've modded just about every xml file to personalize the gameplay experience even more than the very thorough options they give you in the menu.

My wife and I play on a custom server together (that was easily made in about 5 minutes) and we are honestly excited about every update and often check the dev blogs to see what is coming down the pipe.

This is not a perfect game. Hell, this is not even close to the finished product they have promised. This is a game that is still in Alpha. But the thing about this game... it's so good and addictive despite the state that it's in and the updates ARE coming, and the development team IS  keeping an eye on the community's ideas and  complaints- that I have faith that when the finished product arrives it will be exactly what was promised. And more importantly, I'll be happily playing while we wait for that day.

You may not want to put the money in on it today- I totally get that. But you damn sure want to follow this game so you don't miss the release and what looks to be one of gaming's finest moments.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So.... I might have put some time into this game so far. Almost entirely on random generated worlds- each start being a unique experience and extremely rewarding. I started with the basics and now I've modded just about every xml file to personalize the gameplay experience even more than the very thorough options they give you in the menu.

My wife and I play on a custom server together (that was easily made in about 5 minutes) and we are honestly excited about every update and often check the dev blogs to see what is coming down the pipe.

This is not a perfect game. Hell, this is not even close to the finished product they have promised. This is a game that is still in Alpha. But the thing about this game... it's so good and addictive despite the state that it's in and the updates ARE coming, and the development team IS  keeping an eye on the community's ideas and  complaints- that I have faith that when the finished product arrives it will be exactly what was promised. And more importantly, I'll be happily playing while we wait for that day.

You may not want to put the money in on it today- I totally get that. But you damn sure want to follow this game so you don't miss the release and what looks to be one of gaming's finest moments.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was overlooking this game for a long time and I regret it. A friend gifted the game for me and I wasn't very keen on playing it until I tried it out. It's definitely worth its low pricetag, doubly so when on sale. For an alpha state game, it's more complete than many of its big-time competitors.

With the widest variety of game setting customization and capability to run a private listen server for your friends, single player only game, or joining a dedicated server, 7 Days to Die is the best zombie survival game out there unless you dislike looting or crafting your own gear.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I didn't have high expectations for this game, but decided to buy it based on some reviews I saw. I must stay that I'm very happy with the purchase, because the game is awesome. I haven't played other games like this one, so I don't have anything to compare it to.

The game is intense, yet the building aspect gives a nice contrast.
The building system is really cool
Single player is fun, and I can't speak much into multi player but if you know people who play it I imagine it's a blast.

Cons:

The ladders could use a graphics update

Early Access Review

I love this game.
I play this game a lot more than I should.
I build things that make no sense, and then shoot zombies in the face when I realize that my building makes no sense.
This is one of those rare jewels that pops up and everyone labels it as just another zombie game, but this is a zombie game that tests you in the Zombie Apocalypse. Build shelter... and log spikes... or die.
*breaks leg*
... there's also that.
*hobbles back to base*
Worth the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While this game may not be the most graphically pleasing (they've actually made it look much better than it did before)
this game has pretty much ruined all of the other survival zombie games for me.

It's similar to minecraft in the sense that the world is never ending (if you set up the server like that) and it's voxel based so the whole entire game world is destroyable.

It did take me a little bit to get used to the whole crafting system of the game but as with most games that have crafting involved, it doesn't take too long to learn what you are doing.

Setting up a private server for my girlfriend and I was extremely easy and we had a blast.

The game really has a 3 part system to it going as:

Beginning:
You are just starting out, having just a can of food, water, and some bandages. It's an intense struggle to survive but usually the most fun.

Middle: You have a somewhat decent base that'll keep you relatively safe during the night and getting food/water isn't as bad as it once was.

End game: You have a pretty OP base, more than enough food/water to survive for quite awhile, many guns, loads of ammo, and you are pretty well off on gear. (This is the least fun part of the game for me)

The game was a blast while just playing PVE with my girlfriend, however if you enjoy PVP then you won't be let down by this game either. Playing on a pvp server is filled with suspense. One second a guy who's naked says he is friendly, the next he is trying to chop your head off with an axe just so he can jack your stuff.

The game has a ton of playability, there was only one VERY SMALL bug that I ever encountered while playing and it wasn't even close to game breaking, and the developers are actively adding new stuff to the game.

7DTD is definitely worth the $25, however you can find it on ♥♥♥ for like $8-9 if you would like to save quite a bit of money.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a challenging, fun, and entertaining game which is horribly entertaining in its current incarnation.  The fact it's still in Alpha makes that even more impressive.

Fighting off zombies hordes while trying to find enough scraps of food and cups of clean water to survive long enough to mine for resources to build a defensible safehouse has never been so much fun.  Add to that the exhilaration of creating and detonating TNT....and you have a damned-near perfect game.

The A11 update still has a few bugs (though I haven't experienced as many as others), but it restored my excitement about playing 7DTD.  Zombies are freakin hard to kill now, it's nowhere near as easy as it had been to run aound out in the open, and crouching now rightly makes movement painfully slow!  Though it's aggravating as hell to have to recraft so many early weapons/tools because my quality is low since I haven't leveled much yet, I find this adds even more tension to the game.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having fairly minor experience with free world survival games, playing Rust previously, I had a fun time... but it was missing something, you could get your bases all nice and zombie proof, and essentially player proof within a few days, it became a sniping fest after a little while.

Early access 7DTD however had me screw up fairly quickly, found some unboiled water, promptly drank it while dehydrated and began vomiting everywhere. Found some meat, and had some walkers on my butt within moments. Soon after, I noticed a giant Wasp, which cottoned on to my existence and stung me to death.

Now, after that whole death spam, I made it into a derelict metropolis, noticed a lovely building with plenty of easily exploited areas for drop pits, pungees, and all round safety for my scaredy-cat self. I went out after the first night had finished, hearing sounds of a plethora of walkers that wanted my tasty flesh and took axe to skull... got overwhelmed, and died. Nobody looted my corpse, so that's a bonus. I then began constructing my ultra-secure, 4 story building repairs. Not a soul made it into my place alive.

I began making high powered weapons, and had a very great secondary and tertiary base, all nice and cosy, away from dogs and wasps. The downside being: your bases only have 1 mattress over all bases, so, essentially your respawn may not actually be anywhere near your homebase (really, I'm just an idiot and didn't realise soon enough).

PROS:Super duper easy to kill yourself from things like - water, food, rancid food.
Get drunk.
So. Much. Space. I literally ran for DAYS attempting to reach end borders, or other signs of civilization. I found a few rebar drop fortresses but that was few and far between.
Zombies are smarter than the average bear - they can sniff you, they can hear you.
When night comes, an immense sense of oh shi~ begins. When you get weeks into survival, you can still get mobbed by ever increasing intelligence.
Respawning gun safes, cabinets, book shelves; which all allow recipes and blueprint discoveries - so fun collecting whole sets!
Playing with friends, especially new friends on vent, TS, Skype etc. is hilarious when they're trying to find you and hilariously get mobbed to death before you arrive.CONS:While the Zombie design is cool, there's a lot of rehashed skins, there's little variety to actual Zombies - essentially bruisers, fast walkers, slow walkers, and occasionally a bloat type...
Dogs suck balls.
Wasps suck even more balls, especially without some kind of Crossbow/ Gun on hand.
Underestimating falls and leaps; easily gib yourself...
Sometimes dogs and wasps can warp into your shoeboxes (if you're out on the hunt and need a safe area to die if you're too encumbered).
Climbing Zombies, which I guess is technically a pro, because they also show you your base flaws.
Overall, I really enjoy this game, it's too bad I don't get to play it more, really. P.S. While there are a dime-a-dozen free world Alpha Zombie Survival games, this one does have a certain, I don't know what that really tickles my fancy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In most survival / building games the building is lackluster.
Not so here.

There are building physics. (this ain't Minecraft)
You actually have to use your brain when putting your Awesome House Of Blocks together!

Also there are many block shapes. Wedges, corner wedges, inside corners, plates, poles, pillars...
You can build something that isn't square and design elaborate death traps for zombie hordes.

You can play SP and play by whatever rules and at whatever difficulty you want and there are many servers, often with mods and custom rule sets, to choose from. Mine is modded quite heavily because the vanilla game is a bit... alpha and not balanced with diversity in mind. (meaning that there is one super awesome rifle and once you have it there is no point in using anything else)
But that can be changed. =)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do recommend this game.
----First id like to start with the negative things though (i know its a bit backwards)
The dev team can be kind of finicky at times, they tend to break things in attempts to fix it, only making things more frustrating. For example they took out the viability of melee combat in comparison to ranged, i dont know why because it was in no way overpowered as you still needed tons of meds and bandages. They do realize the issue ... but wont fix it for a very long time from now(alpha 13 to be exact). i dont know about you but melee combat not working in a zed survival game is really bad. HACKING it is real... and it is alive, i dont know what the devs are trying to do to stop people from hacking but it is bruuutal, your house, everything you worked for can be gone in the blink of an eye to a hacker so beware. An easy fix to stop hackers is to disable creative mode, i know a lot of creative people would be upset and all but us online players dont like getting hacked on(i speak for us all) .Other than that of course there are the usual alpha complaints, be ready to deal with constant wipes and at times stability issues, they are easy to overlook unless you are some architect that likes spending all their time on building something pretty.
--- As for the positive, The game is pretty and is getting even better over time, the environments and the textures, variety of weapons and crafting. Its super fun especially when played with a good community or even just 1 friend. the variety is just so huge you never know what you are going to find. i do recommend playing it on hard or feral though or else the game is kind of too easy. The sheer potential of this game is enormous and with every large update you find yourself in a somewhat brand new game.
HAPPY HUNTING!!!

PS. They added this thing called gore blocks recently and its god aweful and i hope they fix it, at first it made sense that zombies dead bodies could pile up causing others to use them as a +1 elevation platform, but the way the devs implemented it is poorly executed in my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do recommend this game.
----First id like to start with the negative things though (i know its a bit backwards)
The dev team can be kind of finicky at times, they tend to break things in attempts to fix it, only making things more frustrating. For example they took out the viability of melee combat in comparison to ranged, i dont know why because it was in no way overpowered as you still needed tons of meds and bandages. They do realize the issue ... but wont fix it for a very long time from now(alpha 13 to be exact). i dont know about you but melee combat not working in a zed survival game is really bad. HACKING it is real... and it is alive, i dont know what the devs are trying to do to stop people from hacking but it is bruuutal, your house, everything you worked for can be gone in the blink of an eye to a hacker so beware. An easy fix to stop hackers is to disable creative mode, i know a lot of creative people would be upset and all but us online players dont like getting hacked on(i speak for us all) .Other than that of course there are the usual alpha complaints, be ready to deal with constant wipes and at times stability issues, they are easy to overlook unless you are some architect that likes spending all their time on building something pretty.
--- As for the positive, The game is pretty and is getting even better over time, the environments and the textures, variety of weapons and crafting. Its super fun especially when played with a good community or even just 1 friend. the variety is just so huge you never know what you are going to find. i do recommend playing it on hard or feral though or else the game is kind of too easy. The sheer potential of this game is enormous and with every large update you find yourself in a somewhat brand new game.
HAPPY HUNTING!!!

PS. They added this thing called gore blocks recently and its god aweful and i hope they fix it, at first it made sense that zombies dead bodies could pile up causing others to use them as a +1 elevation platform, but the way the devs implemented it is poorly executed in my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I normaly dont spend much time on reviews of games becouse i tend to play them, but this game deserves it.
Its been what, over 2 years now since i bought the game? I pretty much got it when it got on steam, and wow what a great 2~ish years it has been.

If you are looking at a game in early access, you want one thing, and thats propper development.
Well stop looking since this game had exactly that and much much more.

In the years i played it up till now, this game has always been great, and it just keeps getting better with every update. This review is for version 14.5, but i will also take the development in the past years into account.

Ill give an overview of pros and cons, then a summary of when to buy this game, and last some game tips and tricks for when you start off.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Pros;
+ Large open world, multiple biomes each with a unique feel to them
+ Interesting, realistic and versatile crafting system
+ Great gameplay (controlls, movement etc)
+ Skill and level system
+ Good grafics, and music
+ Lots of  tools and weapons, for everyone something (melee brawling, guns blazing or stealthy, you can play how you like)
+ Lots of loot and building materials
+ Weather system, that changes depending on the biome your in.
+ Set world, random generated worlds, single player and multiplayer (with easy to set up server)
+ Propper development, every update makes the game better

Cons;
- Its an early access game, meaning you might encounter some bugs, and saved games might not work after major updates.
- Loading screen takes long when you start the game up.

The few bugs or gliches that i have encountered in the past years are few and got fixed in a matter of days sometimes even hours.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When should you buy this game?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If you like Zombie games, Survival, Crafting, Building, Lots of loot, the option to play the way you want, and a game that keeps getting better with every update, this is the game for you.

If i had to compare this game with other games, i would say it reminds me of Minecraft, and survival games like DayZ, Rust etc.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Below i will give some tips on how to start off, beware of MINOR SPOILERS!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Last updated: April 2016
---------------------------

When you start off in the world you get only the most bastic needs, a bit of water, and food, a torch, and a bandage.
First thing you want to get as fast as posible, is a stone axe, the game tells you in a little tuturial what to do. You need to pick up stones laying arround with the button ''E'' or hit some boulders with your fist (left mouse button), then you need some grass, hit it with your fist to pick some up.
Then you need wood, any tree or bush will give you some when hit.
You can craft the stone axe in your crafting menu by pressing ''TAB''.

The stone axe is a multi purpose tool that is your new friend, you can use it as a club to smash zombie heads, use it as an axe to chop down trees, and a pickaxe to get stone.

Make sure you pick up a lot of stone, wood, and grass becouse you will be making lots of stone axes.

You might want a save way to kill a zombie here and there, the bow is a cheap and easy item for this.
You will need some wood, and grass to build the bow, the arrows can be made with stone, wood and feathers.
Feathers can be found in bird nest that are scattered on the floor here and there (and in or on some buildings)

Food/Water; you can fill glass bottles and empty cans with water from rivers and lakes, also you can cook the water on a campfire so you wont get sick.
Food can be cooked in different ways, altough not all food needs to be cooked to savely eat it, all canned food can be eaten right away.

Surviving is your main priority at the start of the game, you want to loot as much as you can and stay away from zombies, getting hurt early in the game is a bad idea, and dieing (if you dont have perma death on) will lower your wellness, wich is the maximum hitpoints and stamina you have.
Only take out the lone zombie here and there if they are in the way of a building you want to loot, by using a bow and/or using the hit and run tacktic. Try hitting zombies in the head.

You can find Cloth fragment by looting, breaking down clothing you find, and by crafting it from cotton plants (those bushes with white fluffy balls on it). You will need it for making bandages, and first aid bandages in case you get hurt.

Where to survive your first night: Its best to find 2-4 buildings together, and choose the highest one. There you would want to make your first base at the top floor or roof.
While one of the  buildings will be your starting base, the other buildings can provide food and materials to survive.
If you play with a seed or random generated game, you might have to do with what you find, always try to be from the ground so zombies cant reach you straight away. (shops have a flat roof with a ladder at the back and will do just fine)

Every 3 days, unless set differently a plane will fly over and drop a supply crate, this always contains resources like antibiotics, medkits and sometimes other suplies.
If you get infected you have 3 days to live unless you take antibiotics or honey, so make sure you get that crate, since its a great help.

Usefull loot: Canned food, Water, Medical suplies, Mining helmet (great protection and flashlight that you can turn on with ''F'')

Tips!
If you are having trouble with surviving at night, instead of setting the dificulty lower, you can also set the zombies to always walk. As default the zombies run when its dark and walk when in (day) light. I always have them set to walk becouse it feels to me like zombies should walk.
This however does not affect zombie dogs.

Dont go into cities or any big cluster of buildings, more zombies and also stronger zombies spawn here.

Every 7 days at night time a horde will come for you, if you are having trouble with them or find them anoying, either keep moving when they come or go back to menu when they have spawned and then go back into the game, and they will be gone.
___________________________________________
I hope this review was usefull to you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Im not someone who can write great reviews.
Just got one thing to say.

I loved to play skyrim to death,  what that has to do with this game?  Nothing, but I just saw my own profile and the games I played.

7 days to die just shot up to 2nd place in most spend game time. and I would not be surprised if one day Skyrim will lose its number one position on my list of most played games/spend game time.

Now I utterly dislike minecraft, for the reason it just looks to blocky, the way it looks does not say the gameplay of minecraft is bad, cause  a lot of people from age 5 till over age 50 are playing minecraft, for me , I tried minecraft but i just hate the graphics, and yes im a gamer that prefers quality graphics over gameplay.

Back to 7 days to die:

Now admitting on what i said earlier, graphics over gameplay. 7 days to die might not be looking as stunning as some 1st person games, still its appealing enough.

I don't quite understand what exactly grasps me so much in this game, its maybe just does moments where you sitting in the dark, and hear the zombies near you, trying to demolish the building arround you when they sense you.

The sound effects in this game are very well done, the sound of a nearby spider zombie just creeps me the heck out.

There is a certain magic about this game which enchanted me to play it for nights in a row.

Just the mere and vast creativity on what you can build. (conerning that i might start to understand people who play minecraft a little bit better, still nope I cant get past the blocky minecraft graphics, i wont touch it)

Now in all honesty, this game is still in alpha and i was not there at its beginning I just start playing about a week orso, but for an alpha this game is worth the monies! and the support.

It only gets better in the future.  I hope so.

so yeah if you use your pickaxe and spend a few hours to cut away all the concrete support pillars and the building still wont collaps and it just floats there on an invisable barrier, its probably somethign they will fix later :)

---------------------------
Connectivity / multiplayer
---------------------------

I dislike PVP,  but i like to play coop.

I found that its very hard to see your game listing when you start a public game.
but if you are playing this through steam, just start the game, and then let your buddies join your game through VAC ( so they need to click your name in their steam friendlist and say join game).
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Well, a lot of talk, and maybe my first adn only longer semi.. review...or just personal feelings about the game.

here is the short version of my review:

DEV TEAM: TAKE MAH MONEY!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Less like 'Minecraft + Zombies' and more like 'Fallout + Building', to me. TL;DR version: Punishing but enjoyable.

AO and I found the default difficulty punishingly difficult to start on, and even on weaksauce nubcakes difficulty we got pantsed a few times. Maybe now that we have ideas for general building order and what to prioritize, we could play through it again at a higher difficulty and have it be challenging rather than Corpse Run Simulator 2014.

We've put in about 60 hours of play on a random-gen world and still haven't found all the different buildings or weapons yet (damn you, sledgehammer, eluding me!), but we've sort of hit the Fort Knox point in our base and have enough supplies stockpiled to last a dozen nuclear winters, so we're feeling pretty done with this playthrough.

Things I Liked:
- It felt like a zombie apocalypse, Part 1: If you were bleeding and didn't have a bandage, you were pooched. If you were in a zombie-infested area and made too much noise, you were pooched. If you drank unboiled water, you were pooched. Pretty much, until you got high-end armour and weapons, you were pooched for just about everything.
- It felt like a zombie apocalypse, Part 2: the ruins and wasteland biomes were very pleasingly atmospheric, and the overall music/ambience was great. Even in our idyllic little wooded meadow, watching the sun set and the sky go bloody through the treebranches was fairly creepy.

Things I Didn't Like:
- So zombies can hear and smell real good, but a giant lighted complex doesn't interest them? I had a hard time with this.
- Starting off and immediately, repeatedly dying nearly put both AO and I off the game within the first 15 mins of playing. That first step's a real doozy.
- The wiki is... rough. Several times we got stumped by conflicting information only to finally figure out it was talking about something from five revisions back. If something's the 'Official' Wiki, I expect a little more care taken.
- The zombie girls had nicer ♥♥♥♥ than me. Character generation, in general, was Fifty Shades of Uncanny Valley. Also, what the everloving ♥♥♥♥ is with me starting in a bra and a thong? If you're gonna make me run around with my nasty polygony ♥♥♥ hanging out, I expect the guys to start in jock straps or assless chaps, kthx.

All in all, definitely worth the money for me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like the survival/crafting/building/exploring aspects of Minecraft and you like a good first-person Zombie apocalypse, you will absolutely love this game.

Pros:
·         Great gameplay – And this is the most important thing!
·         Great atmosphere
·         Genuinely scary
·         Zombies/Crafting/Survival/Base building
·         Huge playing area to explore

Cons:
·         Graphics differ wildly in quality – most are good to fair (the voxel terrain, some zombies), while others are so rough it’s like games from 20 years ago (corpse, car). As this is an early access game I hope these will be improved.
·         Some of the female zombie models are gratuitously sexualised, this might appeal to teenage boys, but will put other people off.
·         There are a few balance issues with perhaps too much loot.
·         On some random maps you get too many identical buildings/ruins

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is the game I have been asking for since I first started playing zombie games, back when Left 4 Dead 2 was still new.
At first I was skeptical, thinking it looked like just another Minecraft-like clone. However, after watching Markiplier and LordMinion777 play it, I decided to give it a shot.
Within minutes of playing, I already became addicted and wanted to play more.
My two best friends also recently bought the game and we decided to try it out together. At first it was a little rough, all of us were spawned so far from one another and it took us a while to meet up. We did have to start over a few times until we got a hang of the game. But once we were able to group up and figure out a plan, we were able to get a grip on the basics farily quickly.
This game is alot of fun and well put together. The zombies are actually scary (esapecially at night), the different biomes are amazing and well put together and the survival is a bit of a challenge but fun.
One of my favorite things is the consequences for your actions. Most zombie games you just charge it, weapon firing and if a zombie got too close you would just lose a bit of health that could be replenished with a health kit then you carry on. But in 7 Days, zombies are more of a threat for you not only lose health but can get infected, bleed or even break bones, each of which require something different to heal you. I also like that you to be weary of what you are carrying and what you are doing as some smells and noises will attract more zombies.
Overall, this is a great game so far and I can't wait to see what the next update will bring.
A few things we are looking forward to:
1. Possibilty of cars- cars would be helpful for scavenging far from camp or if one person has a broken leg and can't run.
2. Weather effects- this could make the game more of a challenge
3. Zombie bears- I'm not looking forward to this one but my friends are...
A few suggestions we have:
1. Add more wildlife that may be huntable, such as birds, fish, etc.
2. Clans, groups or tribes that you can create and join
3. Silencers for weapons
4. Tripwires, trapdoors, etc for setting traps

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFirst game I know of, where you can interact with the whole enviropment you see, plant crops, make corn bread, and do all the other things needed to survive. It's the first game that I have ever been so much interested in. You can dig down, build up in the sky and explore unlimitedly huge random generated world with hundreads of places to see. reviewText:
Early Access Review

7 Days to Die is a very good sandbox/zombie game especially when played with friends. I play this most days with my partner (she loves the game and plays very little else). The feel of the game is very good and the night times can be truly intense if you caught out in the open, and even in your base when a full horde comes it can get very intense.

Things I like:

- Building is pretty solid at the moment, especially if you install one of the modded recipe packs

- Defence is a lot of fun and you can be very inventive

- Cities are great fun to raid provided you don’t go in guns blazing

- Graphics are not bad for an indie though with alpha 11 it looks like they will get a major update

- Combat is straight forward and feels about right in my own eyes.

- Crafting system is good again is event better with the modded recipe packs I Have not played on public server's so can’t give a review of them as we play on our own private server

Things that could do with a bit of an update:

- Building variety/biomes feel a little repetitive in random generated maps, a modded prefab pack improves the buildings but the zones still feel a bit cut and paste at times. Alpha 11 will be changing the random gen so this may well change very soon.

- Need to add some prolonged goals other than getting the Sniper Rifle/Magnum, yes this is a sand box but still needs some long term things to work for - skill system may fix this to some extent but they need to add some areas that are a lot harder to loot/get in to until your better skilled/equipped or something.

- Mining/chopping feels a bit slow but this is probably to stop people destroying your base to fast on PvP servers.

Overall for an alpha this is a very good game that I would recommend to people as a must buy, I know there are probably better looking games but the feel of this game just sits well with me. It is so much better with friends than solo this I cannot stress enough.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since the beginning of time, I have been a zombie fan. I have all the movies and try to play all the games. However, I have always been wanting a game where it was me and some friends surviving against hordes of the living dead. I have played many games with zombies, and have lots many, but this game is the closest I have ever been to the perfect zombie game.

I have played several zombie games, across many platforms, and I have spent 10x more in this game than any other. I love the combination of the survival aspect and the buidling aspect. I love that the zombies actually pose a threat and you can't just hide in your home. With the combo of the Zombies and the physics based gameplay, you must be innovative in your attempts at survival. You cant' just pillar up and wait out the night. You can't just dig a hole and everything will be alright. The zombies will come for you.

I also love the fact that the devs have allowed options inside the game. For example, my current server I play on is walking dead style. Walkers Only, No specials. You can set length of days, if the zombies run or not (when they run too), loot probability, and so much more. No matter your style, you can tweak the game to your satisfaction.

However, I do want to emphasize that this game is Alpha. You will find bugs. You will have to start over several times. Things will go wrong and you will get frustrated. Very frustrated. You will probably rage quit a few times. I have. However, each time I do, I soon come back for more. In fact, on my server, I am known to be the one who finds bugs and to get stuck in them.

As the game stands now, it's a 7 out of 10 for me. Which, honestly for me, that's a very good score. Very few games score any higher.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThere are a slew of sandbox, zombie survival, and crafting games available these days and out of all those I would have to say that this game stands near the pinnacle of them all. Although still in Alpha, as of 06/13/15, this game easily could be in Beta and in most other cases I believe any other dev probably classify it as such. The game runs fluently, even on a crappy laptop if set to easily adjustable lower settings and a large majority of the gameplay is functional. With this in mind there are obvious bugs present and lots of things that need work but it is still in development and the vigilance of these devs more then compensate for continuing bugs as well as new ones that arise when each update occurs. Overall, it's exactly what it says in the title, it is The Survival Horde Crafting Game". And with devs that back the game and take some pride in their work I would definitely recommend it for those who want to have a quality game with guaranteed improvements in the future."

Early Access Review

I've put in my hours, so let me put in my review. Keep in mind that this is indeed an Alpha game, and a work in progress. Currently the game is in patch 10.4, with another patch planned soon.

Excellent Things:

I have played alot of zombie games and alot of survivel games, Many of them have on cool mechanic or function that makes the uniq. But come on most of them are just the same thing.
