reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am reviewing this game based on the Early Access version as of 5/27/14 -
My playtime on this account is not representative of my actual time with this game -

I like 7 Days to Die. The game works as advertised and has a great track record of consistent and substantial updates. Personally, I find the zombies to be a little tough to kill and the zombie dogs to be a bit overkill but if you like your survival zombie games more on the challenging side then this should appeal to you. Lots of things to craft, building a fort and surrounding it with defenses is a good time. You can even mine for ore like that one game (you know which one). Playing with friends is fun as well and I have not had any large issues with lag or network connectivity.

The only negative thing I can say about this game, which isn't so much the game itself but the Early Access aspect of many games, is that you will play it and get tired of it long before the game is completed. Again, this is my opinion. This is a solid game as is right now and it is good. But that just makes me want to wait to play it until I can get the full experience.  So while I have spent a significant time with the game and it's systems, I have not tried to dig deep into the games meaty bits.

Overall, I would strongly recommend a purchase; especially if you have a buddy or two to survive with.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\n7 Days to Die is a Voxel-based zombie survival horror game in which your objective is to survive the harsh and unforgiving elements of the landscape and 'wildlife' around you. You are tasked with providing yourself with a home be it temporary or not to protect yourself against the inevitable hordes of the un-dead that WILL prove a problem to you least you own a gun or good melee weapon. You get get food from basic scavenging though it gets scarce after a while so you must learn to hunt local deer, pigs and other animals or you can look into farming. You'll be wanting to get water from scavenging more than anything since there enough water bottles in a local town to drown the Ugandan population. Zombies can travel alone or travel in hordes and as you survive for more days they get tougher and tougher until you need to be more intelligent with how you do or rather do not deal with them. Overall it was a fun game while it lasted if not a bit...repetitive. The animations were a bit off. The graphics weren't exactly gorgeous to look at and 7 Days to Die is one of those game where there is no shame looking up the Wikipedia for how to build things or get ♥♥♥♥ done. Honestly it was fun while it lasted, which was about a few hours. It isn't really any fun without friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really enjoy playing this game. It is a rare gem in that it is similar to minecraft but not a terrible cash grab knockoff game. Visually it is ok but not spectacular but certainly a step up from the blockiness of minecraft. Building is a nessicity rather than an outlet for you're creativity. If you don't have a reinforced shelter then you aren't going to last long.

The thing that keeps this game fresh is the huge expanse of crafting options available that gives you a reason to survive. A huge range of food and medicines can be crafted from crops as well as biofuel for chainsaws and drills or you can mine for metals and ores which can be smelted and made into tools and guns.

Then you must improve and upgrade your base and defenses which is where your strategy and creativity comes into play. Make use of trenches and spike traps with land mines and barbed wire, maybe throw in some lookout towers and you might just be able to survive a few nights against the zombie onslaught. However as the days and nights go on the zombies get tougher and are able to climb over walls and tunnel under your base and can easily overwhelm you.

Each life offers you another chance at building a better base and trying a new idea. Maybe an underground base? maybe build on top of the tallest building in town? underwater? Grab a few friends and get into a game for the best team playing survival experience.

I almost forgot its still in early access which seems hard to believe but I can't wait to see all the future features they have planned.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am reviewing this game based on the Early Access version as of 5/27/14 -
My playtime on this account is not representative of my actual time with this game -

I like 7 Days to Die. The game works as advertised and has a great track record of consistent and substantial updates. Personally, I find the zombies to be a little tough to kill and the zombie dogs to be a bit overkill but if you like your survival zombie games more on the challenging side then this should appeal to you. Lots of things to craft, building a fort and surrounding it with defenses is a good time. You can even mine for ore like that one game (you know which one). Playing with friends is fun as well and I have not had any large issues with lag or network connectivity.

The only negative thing I can say about this game, which isn't so much the game itself but the Early Access aspect of many games, is that you will play it and get tired of it long before the game is completed. Again, this is my opinion. This is a solid game as is right now and it is good. But that just makes me want to wait to play it until I can get the full experience.  So while I have spent a significant time with the game and it's systems, I have not tried to dig deep into the games meaty bits.

Overall, I would strongly recommend a purchase; especially if you have a buddy or two to survive with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The first time I went to the City  I strolled in there with my pistol and shotgun thinking I was John Wayne.  I ran away crying like a little girl.  Today I went back.  Two pistols, two shotguns a hunting rifle and my trusty crossbow - a 1000 rounds of ammunition.  Today I was Clint Eastwood.  The fight was dirty and mean.  I shot a cheerleader in the face.  For a moment the thought crossed my mind that perhaps she had once been pretty - but I couldnt dwell on these things and pumped two rounds into a fat guy in a hawaiian shirt - next up a couple of nurses, I put them down hard.  I saw a cop out the corner of my eye, spun, switched to hunting rifle and he bit the dirt, they were coming at me now in twos and threes from all directions - I pulled  my pistol out - remember your training - get  a little height and pick off the closest first,  stay calm, aim fire, aim fire, aim fire.  The fight went on through the night, by now I was playing hit and run, the crawlers had snagged me a couple of times and my leg was broke,  by morning the damn hornets were buzzing around me and I could hear the wails of those long armed mutant freeks that I new meant trouble.  I fought my way back to the mound I had been stood on nearly twenty four hours ago and we started again - Some trophy wife in a red dress took one in the back of the head, I heard somebody giggle, It was me.  The strain was showing, I knew I was gonna crack, I pulled out my shotgun and started walking down main street - You tell 'em I'M coming... and hell's coming with me...

That was day 86.

I play no death"  If you die you start again from scratch
hoursPlayed: no crying for mummy."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7 Days to Die is a very good sandbox/zombie game especially when played with friends. I play this most days with my partner (she loves the game and plays very little else). The feel of the game is very good and the night times can be truly intense if you caught out in the open, and even in your base when a full horde comes it can get very intense.

Things I like:

- Building is pretty solid at the moment, especially if you install one of the modded recipe packs

- Defence is a lot of fun and you can be very inventive

- Cities are great fun to raid provided you don’t go in guns blazing

- Graphics are not bad for an indie though with alpha 11 it looks like they will get a major update

- Combat is straight forward and feels about right in my own eyes.

- Crafting system is good again is event better with the modded recipe packs I Have not played on public server's so can’t give a review of them as we play on our own private server

Things that could do with a bit of an update:

- Building variety/biomes feel a little repetitive in random generated maps, a modded prefab pack improves the buildings but the zones still feel a bit cut and paste at times. Alpha 11 will be changing the random gen so this may well change very soon.

- Need to add some prolonged goals other than getting the Sniper Rifle/Magnum, yes this is a sand box but still needs some long term things to work for - skill system may fix this to some extent but they need to add some areas that are a lot harder to loot/get in to until your better skilled/equipped or something.

- Mining/chopping feels a bit slow but this is probably to stop people destroying your base to fast on PvP servers.

Overall for an alpha this is a very good game that I would recommend to people as a must buy, I know there are probably better looking games but the feel of this game just sits well with me. It is so much better with friends than solo this I cannot stress enough.

Early Access Review

This is my favorite game in my library.  Hours upon hours exploration. Tons of things you can craft. Zombies can either be a challenge or non threatening, depending on how many you encounter. If you take on a horde, make sure you are geared and full of ammo. Even if you are geared to the top, a zombie horde could still tear you apart.

This game is a must own. If you like survival, crafting, zombies, horror, friends, sunlight, guns, crossbows, dogs you don't want to pet, exploration, sand, snow, trees, water, caves, rabbits, the sky, grass, a stick, etc. You'll find it in this game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThere are a slew of sandbox, zombie survival, and crafting games available these days and out of all those I would have to say that this game stands near the pinnacle of them all. Although still in Alpha, as of 06/13/15, this game easily could be in Beta and in most other cases I believe any other dev probably classify it as such. The game runs fluently, even on a crappy laptop if set to easily adjustable lower settings and a large majority of the gameplay is functional. With this in mind there are obvious bugs present and lots of things that need work but it is still in development and the vigilance of these devs more then compensate for continuing bugs as well as new ones that arise when each update occurs. Overall, it's exactly what it says in the title, it is The Survival Horde Crafting Game". And with devs that back the game and take some pride in their work I would definitely recommend it for those who want to have a quality game with guaranteed improvements in the future."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since the beginning of time, I have been a zombie fan. I have all the movies and try to play all the games. However, I have always been wanting a game where it was me and some friends surviving against hordes of the living dead. I have played many games with zombies, and have lots many, but this game is the closest I have ever been to the perfect zombie game.

I have played several zombie games, across many platforms, and I have spent 10x more in this game than any other. I love the combination of the survival aspect and the buidling aspect. I love that the zombies actually pose a threat and you can't just hide in your home. With the combo of the Zombies and the physics based gameplay, you must be innovative in your attempts at survival. You cant' just pillar up and wait out the night. You can't just dig a hole and everything will be alright. The zombies will come for you.

I also love the fact that the devs have allowed options inside the game. For example, my current server I play on is walking dead style. Walkers Only, No specials. You can set length of days, if the zombies run or not (when they run too), loot probability, and so much more. No matter your style, you can tweak the game to your satisfaction.

However, I do want to emphasize that this game is Alpha. You will find bugs. You will have to start over several times. Things will go wrong and you will get frustrated. Very frustrated. You will probably rage quit a few times. I have. However, each time I do, I soon come back for more. In fact, on my server, I am known to be the one who finds bugs and to get stuck in them.

As the game stands now, it's a 7 out of 10 for me. Which, honestly for me, that's a very good score. Very few games score any higher.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alpha 12. Used a recommended seed called KillMeNow on the random generation (highly recommend, lots of POIs). Ran for awhile until I found a nice cabin with a forge and stone walls close to a town and other scattered buildings. Cleared out the zombies and started fortifying with wooden log spikes. It was the first night as I sat upstairs that I realized a bear had spawned in the place of two stair blocks in the house I had chosen for myself. Alright I thought, I'll just kill him and fill in the stairs, nope he can hit me through the walls. that's fine, I'll have a bear defending the stairs then, no problem. Bear starts to tear away at my house, heading for me medicine cabinet. He has to die now. Spend the night crafting as many arrows as I could, it was not enough. Day breaks and I start gathering materials, including a barrel of oil... I ran back to my house and placed the barrel above the bear. Ignorant of the ways of the barrel, I punch it, BOOM! It explodes instantly and I die, the bear SURVIVES and is now loose on the bottom floor of my home. I quickly change my outlook on the situation, I now have an indestructible bear defending my stairs, he can have the bottom floor, that's fine, I'll Make it work. The bear had other plans. Sensing freedom for the first time in its life, the bear makes a b-line for the door, even better, I thought, I'll have a bear outside my house defending against zombies from all sides. The bear rips its way through my door and dies on the log spikes. I now have a giant hole in my house, reduced wellness and no guard bear in the middle of a popular zombie horde migration path.

10/10 Don't mess with bears

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is really cool, and the sandbox aspect brings a lot of customization to the game (which, for control freaks like myself is an amazing thing). Or, if you like it simple, you can just find a point of interest that's already built and hang out there. The server I've been playing on is more like co-op, we don't run around looting each other which makes the game play much more peaceful. It's rather cool seeing what other people are building/doing and getting ideas. We trade with each other and talk to each other about bugs or ideas. There are a couple of downsides, however. One is that certain items don't regenerate in the map (meaning you have to go further and further away to find them), and another is that you can't build everything that you see spawn in the world (for example a bookshelf is uncraftable). This could potentially change, however as it is in Alpha. But so far I'm very impressed with how enthralled you can get in this game, and how much you can do. I can never stop expanding and killing zombers!
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhen I first bought this game early in its alpha phase I had some regrets. The early blocky look just did not do it for me but I always would come back every month or two and check on this game because I saw some depth that could be interesting later on. Fast forward now to version alpha8.6 and this game is quite fun, has dumped the blocky look and has me quite excited for the future. They have borrowed some of the better elements from games like Rust, Minecraft and DayZ and combined them into a quite complex crafting/building game with sizeable numbers of zombies that can be a real menace to you at times. If you have some friends to play with online and you enjoyed the building and base raiding of Rust but wished it were more complex in the crafting area, you should get this game. Or even if you like a solitary open world game it is still worth getting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a major fan of Voxel Games, probably going so far as saying I go No-Lyfe when It comes to them. I have to say this is probably one of the best, I cannot say it is /THE/ best, Becuase that would mean it was fact and theres no possible way for something to be the best without a stastic backing it up, Besides... the concept of best is a matter of opinion.

Eitherway, I for one enjoy this game very much, Playing since A1, I've seen as Navesgane changed over time. I've seen whole castles built and cumble because the smallest error. I've seen wars fought over land and food, and seen teamwork come to fruition, This game has had many, many memorable events. I've seen people laugh it up at a rather odd looking zombie, and I've seen people lose everything because of a misfire.

This game is in no way, shape, or form perfect, it has it's bugs, it has its annoying people, and yes... it's not done... I'm not using it as an excuse, if you dont like it, To each his own, I'm just pointing that out, Somethings just need patience, You can't take every word as truth, and every image as plausible. Things are going to change, for better or worse, I for one intend to see it through, one way or another.

I love this game, It is my S***, I mean-.. yes there are times when I do have to take a break, But any game you play, you'll have to eventually set it down for a day or two. But I'm always searching the forums for cool ideas, Making some form of impregnable fortress, or just chilling with friends.

The multiplayer is kinda wonky, not unbearable, it has it's issues, but for most part is fun, Co-ordinating a group of 20 people on a 60 man server can be kinda hectic if your ill prepared, but it is definitly an expirence, Especially if it turns into an arms race and a war...

I would like to see more from admin controls, but thats for a different time, and weapon mods.... Workshop mayhaps?

Eitherway I'm happy to kill things, and have things to kill those things. Heres to A7 and beyond.

Long Live the New Navesgane Militia

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has all the core features I have come to think of as desirable in a game.
- co op lan and online
- can build stuff
- can destroy stuff, fully destructable is great
- has tough enemies, but lots of control of difficulty settings
- is challenging and rewards creative thinking
- 3d world, fps and looks good for alpha
- extensive content, with more to come (story missions etc)
How does this game differ from say minecraft, well it's not blocky, the enemies are tougher, more varied and make more sense, (things dont teleport), the atmosphere (post apocolytic) feels more visceral.
It can often feel intense and demands that you work out what to do and prioritize what to do to survive.
Of the cons - there are some minor bugs and some things that don't look or work quite right, which it appears the developers actively work on whilst also refining and expanding the game. I recommend the game if you like this style of game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Survival Horde Crafting Game!

So… if you have tried a game like Minecraft - you will understand some of the gameplay here. Just add a few things to your vision of Minecraft:

1. Remember the paranoia from Left4Dead when you encountered the witch first time? That feeling will be there much                 more… almost all the time… Especially at night!

2. Add the lack of Gravity from Minecraft into this game and add some better looking graphics.

3. Add zombies… a lot of zombies… daylight is as in the movie “Night of the Living Dead” and the nights are more like “World War Z”

4. Add a lot of guns!

To boil it all down it’s a mixture of the best from Minecraft added with the best from games like Left4Dead or Rust or DayZ.

If you’re into paranoia, zombies and survival games – then this is it!

Haven’t tried a game that after 30 minutes play forced me to crawl into a corner with my torch inside a small church for another 30 minutes of play time… just staring at the entrance and waiting for daylight to come!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As far as zombie survival goes this has to be one of the best I've played especially in early access. Most game developers make a ton of excuses, promises, and plans that never deliver, while this game seems to be developing smoothly while also remaining PLAYABLE. Most of the glitches seem to be fairly negligible from my experience so far.

Pros
+ Building Capability
Way better than rust or any of the prefabricated excuses for building that most survival games have at the moment, infact on par with what you would find in minecraft with a better look and feel to it.
+ Scavenging
No more Chuck Norris vs. tree immersion killers like they have in minecraft, rust, and other games like it. Make tools based off of materials you can gather from smaller sources before tackling the big projects.
+ Zombies & AI
They can smell you, see you, and sometimes simply sense you. This is way better than the husks of DayZ, or the rabid bunny rabbits of Minecraft.
+ Updates and Content
Never expected when I originally bought this for the devs to be so loyal in their updates but wow they have been progressing this game like it actually means something to them, crazy right? Devs that don't abandon their community.

Cons
- Hard Start
I'll admit it's a bit hard to get started in with little explaination on how to get your first tools. I personally started out scavenging till I found a pickaxe and shovel only to find out later in the game that a stone axe can work however slowly and can be made from gathered materials.
- Players Per Server
Unfortunately the only huge thing is the amount of people that can play before it takes a massive dive in server sync which can ultimately drop everyone from the server or just make the few people experiencing it rubber band like crazy. Watch your server population and limit who plays or else it will happen.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played all the survival games out right now. DayZ (mod and standalone), War Z (now called Infestation: Survivor Stories), Rust, Unturned, etc. This is the one I stuck with hardcore, and it's not even done yet. I've played since Alpha 1, when everything was blocky and there was no stealth system. That game was terrible, yet still held its own compared to most other survival games. Looking at it now, with a complex crafting system, stealth, hordes, random gen, and so much more that's been added since those first weeks... This is THE game. If you buy one survival game, make it this one. I guarantee ya, you won't regret it.

Edit: After reading a few of the negative reviews, I have to add that this game is IN ALPHA. There WILL be gamebreaking bugs, in fact they released an update (A3 I think) that crashed my buddy's computer. This was before they released on Steam, ofc. Ever since, there have been no problems as far as corruption goes, but these things CAN happen when you buy a game that isn't finished yet. Not specifically talking about anyone in particular, just sayin'.

As for the forum moderators, I suggest sending a pm to Joel on the 7dtd forums. He's a great moderator, fair and funny, but he's not paid to be a babysitter. He's an actual dev who is doing his part to create this game. Still, if you have a valid complaint, I'm sure he'll listen. He helped me link the game to my Steam account when he could've just sent me a link to Google and told me to figure it out lol.

Point is, this is a great game with a great dev team, and though there WILL BE BUGS, they're doing the best they can with what they've got. This isn't Bohemia Interactive, this is a group of guys making a badass game. At 900+ hours, I've gotten my $25 out of this game many times over. Best game I've ever paid for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7 Days to Die is 1 of my personal few games I'm REALLY looking forward to and went on to buy it in Alpha. It looks very promising and things that they're planning to do and goals are quite interesting and unique combinations from different genres. Semi-Block system from minecraft with better graphics and visuals.. add survivability with not only food and health but also water.

Able to play it in Co-Op? YES!
Crafting system? Yes!
Lots of guns and weapons? Yes!

UPDATE:::: 26/07/2015

Personal feeling:
I haven't played a long-while until 11 & 12- builds, the game became SIGNIFICANTLY more responsive and polished compared to what it was. The textures can still use some improvements here and there, but the apocalyptic set-up saves it slightly... I just find that in some cases (i.e character ) it still hurts to see low quality textures/graphics. But normally nothing distracting me from playing the game... after first few days you'll be wearing clothes anyways. The gameplay itself got significantly better to and as it stands is actually fun to play, run around and loot, kill zombies and so on.

Improvement speed:
Game is developing and taking shape in big leaps, something to be expected for an Alpha, I am slightly" concerned about them stopping "before it's baked" because for me
date:
so far I see almost infinite potential...

Small Feature Wish-list:

* More pre-made maps
Overall there's plenty of great ideas people are giving to them in the forums already

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If Minecraft grew up, DayZ wasn't bugged, and H1Z1 worked, then they would all be called 7 Days to Die.


So, what is 7 Days to Die?

It is an open-world sandbox set in a post-apocalyptic environment.
http://youtu.be/V5dWpZXrnwY


Ok, but what makes it good?

1. Ingame item search engine

2. Ingame crafting guide

3. An exceptional building system

4. Feral running zombies which are actually a threat

5. PHYSICS!!!!

6. PVP and PVE options

7. Password protection for servers and crates

8. MODS!!!!!! YEA BABY!!!! xD

9. Continuous progress being made towards developing the game


Ok, so what does it lack in?

1. Moving vehicles (Alpha 11 update will be adding a moving vehicle into the game)

2. A wider range of items, structures, and textures (can be remedied with mods)

3. An end game


Summary:

7 Days to Die is in Alpha, so it is still very much in early development. Despite that, it is a hugely fun and addictive game which sees constant progress and updates.

So, if you are in the market for DayZ, or H1Z1 then you might want to check out 7 Days to Die before throwing your money away.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Below this is the current review. I opted to leave the original as well for reference.


------ORIGINAL REVIEW: VERSION 7.11----------

I played this game for a little bit when I first purchased it, just before alpha 6 was released. I was impressed. I played again later, around version 7.11, and I can say without a doubt that I enjoy this game. Having to take structural integrity into account to make sure your buildings and mining tunnels don't collapse on you rather then just as eye candy is a very welcomed plus. While there is equipment degredation and normal needs (food, hydration, stamina,)  I have never felt that these were too prevalent, yet it's just taxing enough to make you actively think about it.
In the end, it will be very interesting to see how this game turns out, but from what I'm seeing right now... We're all in for a very good game.



---------NEW REVIEW: VERSION 12.4---------

Ok, I've put a good amount of time in the game between each patch. So far I am greatly impressed with the changes that the team has made. The game is starting to take shape and it leaves so much potential for mods when it's done!  But, this isn't much a review without actually reviewing it, so here we go.

Graphics: As I said in the opening, they have upgraded the engine and it now supports better graphics as well as weather effects such as rain, fog and snow. Unfortunately, for one reason or another, there seems to be some kind of issue with high end video cards and the game. That, however, will be patched out soon enough. The night sky looks great; first thing a friend of mine said when he saw it was Woah

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game about two weeks ago now after playing Rust for months on end (since January) At the time I wasn't sure if I'd go for DayZ, Rust, or 7 Days to Die (which a lot of players seem to be stuck in deciding)

I went for Rust because it was the cheaper of the three and seemed to be in the middle of 7 Days and DayZ in regards to gameplay. It was fun and entertaining and I loved building a base from starting out with not much. However, the gameplay got repetitive, it involved a lot of play time in order to maintain everything you owned and to try and make sure nobody blasted your base and took your stuff while you were offline. As a father and single income worker, my free time for games is limited. The other issue is that updates for Rust have been very lacking lately and it has just become a bit stale. DayZ seemed even worse with updates, and the amount of content in the game is very lacking in comparison to 7 Days and Rust. It looks pretty, but eye candy can only go so far.

7 Days to Die is impressive and deserves a larger player base than it currently has. I was originally put off by the graphics in its early versions a few months back, but that was clearly a mistake. Besides, the graphics have been getting better and currently are about par with Rust. The reason I can see for the lesser quality graphics is that they focused so much more on the gameplay and content and it all works very well, especially for an Alpha.

The other issue I had with 7 Days to Die back in January was its price, which was the most expensive out of the three. Now it has dropped in price and is cheaper than DayZ.

And for someone who doesn't have a lot of free time to play games, having a single player / offline mode to play is great. The Zombies are very effective and keep you on your toes. With the new update coming with the motion capture animations for them, it's just going to get a hell of a lot better.

Now, let's say you get the basic stuff to survive for the night, or so you think, now you gotta find a place to settle down. There's a little neighborhood with some houses. Smack a few zombies around and drop them, ok, so this house is empty and I'll call it my own. I'll put my stuff in the fridge, make some storage boxes, start crafting a few things. Hmmm.... it's getting night time now. Guess I won't be going far. Wait, what's that noise? Footsteps? Screaming and odd breathing?? Well they won't find me in here, I'll just keep quiet and put out the fire. Uh oh, they're getting close. They're on the doorstep. Now they're banging on the door and screaming! Oh crap, the windows smashed in the back. Jebus! They're bashing through the walls!! Is that a Zombie Bee I hear? Oh MY GOD THEY'RE INSIDE!!!! THEY'RE RUNNING AT ME!!! HOW DID THEY FIND ME!!?? CRAP THEY SMELLED THE FOOD IN MY BACKPACK!!! AAAAAHHHHH!!!!!

^My first night.

I did survive though :P

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7 Days To Die has been around for quite some time now. I recently purchased it off a discounted price and I have to say its quite fun. At the start it was really frustrating, you will die from lots of reasons. Running into radiated zones, getting shot by bandits, dying from zombies and even dying from lack of food/water.

Your basic stats include stamina,food,hunger and health.
Stamina affects your physical activites that range from running to felling a tree with an axe. The lower your stamina, the slower you interact.
Food/Water are your basic survival stats. There is a constant challenge to build a decent food/water supply and foraging for food in the wild is also difficult. The more stamina you drain, the faster your food/water stats will go down.
Health is the usual. You would require medicinal items like bandages or first aid kits to heal.


The game crafting is quite developed but theres still room for more. When I first started, i was totally lost and i needed to wiki/google search how to do things. Although the recipes are provided, you are missing some and you have to learn these by reading skill books that can be found in various loot drops around the world.

Combat is moderate. There are a couple of guns, ranging from pistols to hunting rifles or shotguns. Crossbows are also available. You can even make a bone shiv from large bones that you may come across. However, fighting with zombies is rather dull. You just need to avoid their swipes. A huge horde can become a big problem. Typical zombie swarm problems.

There are a couple of zombie types. Crawler zombies crawl towards you slowly and they can sneak up on you in thick vegetation. Normal Walkers have a few variations, infected women, nurses, cheerleaders and fat walkers. Naturally the fat ones would have more health and it would take more effort to bring 1 done. There are also cop zombies that hurl acidic vomit at you. Zombies will drop loot according to their variation.

I managed to group up with a couple of people and setup a huge base. Normally if you're on your own, raiders tend to pick on you more. And when i mean raiders, those are other players that attack other people for resources or for the fun of it. You will die and you will be annoyed. But thats the fun. Picking up from where you lost and rebuild.
I got raided by a pair of bandits and they jeered at me. Infuriating as it is but i teamed up with other survivors and continued playing.

---------------
tl:dr,
YOU WILL DIE. ALOT.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game about two weeks ago now after playing Rust for months on end (since January) At the time I wasn't sure if I'd go for DayZ, Rust, or 7 Days to Die (which a lot of players seem to be stuck in deciding)

I went for Rust because it was the cheaper of the three and seemed to be in the middle of 7 Days and DayZ in regards to gameplay. It was fun and entertaining and I loved building a base from starting out with not much. However, the gameplay got repetitive, it involved a lot of play time in order to maintain everything you owned and to try and make sure nobody blasted your base and took your stuff while you were offline. As a father and single income worker, my free time for games is limited. The other issue is that updates for Rust have been very lacking lately and it has just become a bit stale. DayZ seemed even worse with updates, and the amount of content in the game is very lacking in comparison to 7 Days and Rust. It looks pretty, but eye candy can only go so far.

7 Days to Die is impressive and deserves a larger player base than it currently has. I was originally put off by the graphics in its early versions a few months back, but that was clearly a mistake. Besides, the graphics have been getting better and currently are about par with Rust. The reason I can see for the lesser quality graphics is that they focused so much more on the gameplay and content and it all works very well, especially for an Alpha.

The other issue I had with 7 Days to Die back in January was its price, which was the most expensive out of the three. Now it has dropped in price and is cheaper than DayZ.

And for someone who doesn't have a lot of free time to play games, having a single player / offline mode to play is great. The Zombies are very effective and keep you on your toes. With the new update coming with the motion capture animations for them, it's just going to get a hell of a lot better.

Now, let's say you get the basic stuff to survive for the night, or so you think, now you gotta find a place to settle down. There's a little neighborhood with some houses. Smack a few zombies around and drop them, ok, so this house is empty and I'll call it my own. I'll put my stuff in the fridge, make some storage boxes, start crafting a few things. Hmmm.... it's getting night time now. Guess I won't be going far. Wait, what's that noise? Footsteps? Screaming and odd breathing?? Well they won't find me in here, I'll just keep quiet and put out the fire. Uh oh, they're getting close. They're on the doorstep. Now they're banging on the door and screaming! Oh crap, the windows smashed in the back. Jebus! They're bashing through the walls!! Is that a Zombie Bee I hear? Oh MY GOD THEY'RE INSIDE!!!! THEY'RE RUNNING AT ME!!! HOW DID THEY FIND ME!!?? CRAP THEY SMELLED THE FOOD IN MY BACKPACK!!! AAAAAHHHHH!!!!!

^My first night.

I did survive though :P

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7 Days To Die has been around for quite some time now. I recently purchased it off a discounted price and I have to say its quite fun. At the start it was really frustrating, you will die from lots of reasons. Running into radiated zones, getting shot by bandits, dying from zombies and even dying from lack of food/water.

Your basic stats include stamina,food,hunger and health.
Stamina affects your physical activites that range from running to felling a tree with an axe. The lower your stamina, the slower you interact.
Food/Water are your basic survival stats. There is a constant challenge to build a decent food/water supply and foraging for food in the wild is also difficult. The more stamina you drain, the faster your food/water stats will go down.
Health is the usual. You would require medicinal items like bandages or first aid kits to heal.


The game crafting is quite developed but theres still room for more. When I first started, i was totally lost and i needed to wiki/google search how to do things. Although the recipes are provided, you are missing some and you have to learn these by reading skill books that can be found in various loot drops around the world.

Combat is moderate. There are a couple of guns, ranging from pistols to hunting rifles or shotguns. Crossbows are also available. You can even make a bone shiv from large bones that you may come across. However, fighting with zombies is rather dull. You just need to avoid their swipes. A huge horde can become a big problem. Typical zombie swarm problems.

There are a couple of zombie types. Crawler zombies crawl towards you slowly and they can sneak up on you in thick vegetation. Normal Walkers have a few variations, infected women, nurses, cheerleaders and fat walkers. Naturally the fat ones would have more health and it would take more effort to bring 1 done. There are also cop zombies that hurl acidic vomit at you. Zombies will drop loot according to their variation.

I managed to group up with a couple of people and setup a huge base. Normally if you're on your own, raiders tend to pick on you more. And when i mean raiders, those are other players that attack other people for resources or for the fun of it. You will die and you will be annoyed. But thats the fun. Picking up from where you lost and rebuild.
I got raided by a pair of bandits and they jeered at me. Infuriating as it is but i teamed up with other survivors and continued playing.

---------------
tl:dr,
YOU WILL DIE. ALOT.
But you learn from those mistakes and pick yourself up again.
Have fun out there!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

'Another zombie survival game' - you.

7 days to die is a zombie survival game. Maybe it isn't fair to review this game seeing as (at the time of writing) it is in 9.2 Alpha version. But seeing as this review is mostly positive, it should be alright.

There's a few things about this game I'd like to talk about:
Gameplay
Graphics
Crafting
Zombies
Multiplayer
Pros and Cons overall.

Gameplay:
7DTD is a sandbox game. At the start of the game, you get dropped at a random place in the world. This can be one of four locations:
Snowy mountains
Forest
Deserted city
Desert
From there it is totally up to the player to decide what they want to do. To keep survivng the player will need atleast food and water. Shelter is optional but highly recommanded, seeing as zombies get stronger at night.
As player you need food and water to survive. You can also get infected, or get diseases like diarrhea. Ofcourse those things can be cured by things you find while scavenging.

Graphics:
In my personal opinions, the graphics aren't terrible, but they could be better. To be honest, for the graphics it has, it should be easier to run. Even on a high end pc it sometimes has lagspikes or crashes, wether this is because it's still in Alpha or not I don't know. Either way, don't excpect anything fancy.

Crafting:
Crafting is pretty big, most things you see outside can be destroyed and used for crafting. You can chop down trees, or chop down entire buildings and make them collapse. The remains can be picked up en used again for crafting.
Bushes, rocks, and grass are things that are mostly used in crafting, espescially at first, when the player is getting started. Later wood and stone become very important, for building a base.
Later, guns and armour can be crafted, But those require molds and blueprints
There's also a farming system, but I'm not a big fan of that. Just like real life the plants need time and sunlight to grow, but it just takes too long.

Zombies:
There's multiple version of zombies. Zombies are both called 'zombies' or 'walkers'
A few examples that you're going to see a lot are:
Bloated zombie: A fat zombie, does more damage, and takes more damage. Drops better loot as well.
Nurse zombie: A normal zombie, except she has more chance to drop medical items.
Zombie dog: Probably the most annoying type of zombie. Fast and does a lot of damage.
Snow zombies: Zombies that live in the snowy mountains. They are all a tougher than normal zombies.
Police officer zombies: They're like blaoted walkers, except they also have a ranged puke attack.

Multiplayer:
Unfortunatly, multiplayer doesn't really offer anything new. It's just a second you running around in the world, except he isn't controlled by you. You can track other players.
Also unfortunate is that you have to rent a server to play with others, but if you know how to 'port forward' you can host a server without charges. More info for that go here:
http://7daystodie.gamepedia.com/Server#Port_forwarding

Pros and cons:
Pro:
- Fun to play
- Multiplayer
- Good crafting system
- Building is well done

Cons:
- More fun to play with others
- Once you've set up a stable base, which includes food, water, and protection, the game can get stale.
- Have to rent servers
- Game has lagspikes and sometimes randomly crashes


Overal I'd rate this game a 7.5/10, and it's still in Alpha mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Thankfully I purchased this game after ignoring some of the previous negative reviews (including one top-ranked review that listed screenshots and all this back and forth) because it turned out to be one of the best survival sim games that I have recently purchased. . I can't speak for the previous state of the game, but as of right now it is a great survival game.

Let me start at the top, with the gameplay. It's FUN! There is plenty to learn, see, and do. Scavenging around there are various weapons and items, all used for something. On the default settings, it is nearly impossible to survive a night by yourself - you need friends! This is not a single player game, it's meant for multiplayer/at least one friend with you.

The game has plenty of different buildings around the world, all unique. It has a lot of different building materials, all can be reproduced or placed by the player. You can dig up carpet, take paintings and tvs, then take them back to your own base to place them. Weapons can be dissasembled into parts, all weapons and tools have durability that can be repaired. Once you spend the time to learn the game, it is not difficult to maintain your weapons or tools. There are plenty of different foods, some foraged or cooked. You have health, hunger, thirst, and stamina to maintain. The variety of places and things to scavenge means it is not too difficult to maintain these basic stats. When I say 'varied', I mean it has at least multiple items of that type, unlike several other games that only have a few of each type. Even though items like food tend to be the same (they have different stats but they are similar) it is nice that they have several different ones of each type, it keeps the game interesting to find new things.

Update: They released a dedicated server component that you can download via Steam by clicking on Library and selecting Tools. If you scroll through the list of games in Tools, you will find 7 days to die dedicated server. Downloading it puts all the files you need in your Steam\steamapps\common folder.

The multiplayer server component is included with the game and it works similar to minecraft or terraria. You host a world on your local machine, and you can create new worlds to host. It has the ability to create new worlds or continue previous worlds. Once you select to create or continue a world, it asks you to press enter before entering - but by that time the world is already hosted. In this way, you can start a server/host a game without actually joining - the server is not a separate executable like some games but that doesn't diminish the ability to host a server. There is a list of settings you can change, and that are changed for many servers. The number of zombies spawned, whether they can run in darkness, how hard they hit, increasing the loot, etc. Right now there are around two thousand servers when you browse for a game, some labelled PVE and others PVP. You can see each server's various settings when browsing for a server to join.

The map is reasonably large for current survival sim games and it looks and feels like a recently inhabited world. Doors are blocked by chairs and windows are boarded up. I can't compare it to DayZ because I haven't played much of that game, but compared to Rust the world is much larger and much more varied. The game is easy to learn and get into and the building system is easy like Rust or minecraft.

One unique feature this game has, is that the world is destructible and structures require support. If you are building a bridge and destroy the support beams, it collapses. Trees fall after you chop them. Parts of houses will collapse if you destroy enough of the walls. It's not very complex, but you can only build blocks that have reasonable support and you can not build over thin air very far.

As much as I can tell, everything can be mined or destroyed. Interestingly the axe works much better than a pickaxe on wood, and pickaxes work much better than an axe on metals and minerals. The game has a shovel and an auger, which work very easily on the earth. It's really nice that you can find/create different mining tools that work better or worse on different materials. Guns, knives, clubs, they all do some damage to break materials down just not all equally well on all types. Metal is not difficult to come by, many items can be broken down into scrap metal. You can smelt scrap metal into iron ingots. The forge has a mold" system

hoursPlayed: copper molds

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Still in Alpha Highly enjoyable. If you like Minecraft, Left 4 Dead, Project Zomboid or DayZ this game might be for you!
There is still alot to be added but as of Alpha 5 you can mine, (like minecraft) craft items, build a fortress to survive the night. You'll need to eat and drink water which will force you to raid houses and town full of zombies and eventually lead you to farm.
Dont get caught out after dark (in normal settings) zombies run at nightime and will tear down your walls, tunnel down through the soil to break into your bunkers and do all they can to get to you. The AI is still reasonably dumb but its still fun for zombies!

If you like the games i listed or are just keen on zombies and dont mind a few bugs grab this game. Ive been playing co-op for days with my friends supports up to 20! player games its worth the $30 early access fee which means you paid $30 to play now and get the full finished game when its out for only $30!

If your still on the fence as with ALL early access games youtube lets play videos and watch a couple.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not quite sure why I bought this to be perfectly honest. It's been sitting in my library for 18 months now and I just cannot get into the game.

I do not have a particularly powerful computer but it can handle most games pretty well, and yet with this game even on low-settings it feels laggy, slow and my computer quickly heats up like an oven. I'm wondering whether this game is just poorly optimised. Either way, it makes the game almost unplayable for me.

As for the graphics, I tested the 'ultra' settings and they just seem very poor to be honest - and not the sort of low-resolution style that is acceptable (e.g. Minecraft). It just feels like playing a game from 10+ years ago, and feels miles behind the standards of today's survival game graphics. I particularly don't like how the game just 'fades' into black in the distance.

Furthermore, from the short time I have played the game, the sound quality isn't great either. Zombies for instance, will sound as if they are a metre or two behind you with loud footsteps, and yet are barely visible when I turn around.

The combined poor sound and visual quality doesn't make the game particularly immersive.

Although, perhaps I'm being a little unfair. After all, graphics and sound aren't everything. Game mechanics are also important - and possibly something I haven't played enough to truly appreciate. Either way, for a survival game, I am impressed (and a little bewildered) at the character's ability to pick up countless cinder blocks without any help and yet take 100's of punches to kill a zombie.

18 months and I haven't seen a huge amount of progression to address the above issues. At this rate, I feel I'll be waiting years for a playable game to be produced out of this. Sorry, but life is too short for that.

£18.99 is far too expensive for a game of this quality.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't recommend yet until few things are fixed :
- balancing :  I don't event know why melee weapons are there since they are pretty much useless.
- performance : even on a decent hardware, you can't avoid having big drops of the framerate, even without much objects on the screen
- tutorials / starting up : you're pretty much lost the first hour of gameplay, but it's a survival, so if you have basic knowledge in this sort of game, you'll end up easely.  But it's definetly not for the casual gamers : it's not the type of title you'll end up with lots of friends playing on it.
- netplay : you end up on a huge map with only 8 poeple at the same time, at most.  We're really far from the other titles of the genre (H1Z1, Rust, ...) that can handle 50+ poeple easely.  So the netplay can be pretty much boring.  If you like PVE more than PVP, it's definitly your type of game.

On another side the game itselfs has good ideas :
- tons of items / crafting
- you can interact with the terrain, make your base | hideout | mines.
- if you have friend to coop with, it's still a nice game to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bearing in mind that (at the time of writing) this is in alpha, I have to say that this has good potential.
I play at home, multiplayer with other members of my family. We have it set up on a private server on our home LAN.
The first thing you want do do once entering the game is locate somewhere to build a safe haven. And as night falls the urgency becomes apparent. During the daytime, the zombies are ok to deal with, but at night they move twice as fast.
You can craft your own weapons and ammo - I personally like the crosbow (must have watched too much of The Walking Dead!) I know there are plenty of critics of this game, good and bad. My two pence worth is that it is better to play with someone else rather than on your own, due to gathering/building before night.
It does occasionally have it's moments than can effect the cleanliness of your underpants - especially if you play it in the dark.
Worth a punt!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fun, brutal, intense, and rewards intelligent play. On top of this, the devs set a great example for how to release and develop an early access game.

Considering the subject of most of the top comments I'll start by talking about the dev process. I play regularly with a couple of mates and we all regularly comment on how great the regular updates and communication from the devs is. Blog updates let players know clearly what is being prioritized and why, and what we have to look forward to in the upcoming patch. Patch notes are thorough and understandable. Decisions about what the devs are prioritising make sense. Major patches are very regular considering the size of the dev studio, and contain big servings of new content. AND WHEN THE DEVS STUFF SOMETHING UP THEY FIX IT IN THE VERY NEXT HOTFIX. For example, in a recent patch bows became very underpowered, forcing low level players into deadly melee combat with zombies. Coupled with this, the forge (which is a key part of progressing from weak hand crafted items to better metal items) became very hard to come by. Both of these issues were identified by the community, the devs listened, and they were rebalanced in the very next hotfix. I can't think of another early release game where I have been so impressed by the dev process.

Now about the game itself. It's brutal, tense, replayable, and heaps of fun. In order to survive and progress you need to make intelligent decisions and think about how you're going to use your time. Difficulty progresses as you do, so you never feel overpowered or underpowered (or when you do get rekt you realise it was your fault). The world is interesting, unforgiving and diverse. The zombies are scary, in a good way. If you do die or otherwise suffer a setback you feel it, but you can make a comeback if you play it right. I regularly find myself on the edge of my seat, or scared, or elated, or just generally having an interesting and fun time. It's also great to play coop with a few friends. You can employ different strategies, and you will realise the outcomes of your decisions. It's a great way to play.

With that in mind, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME!

As a final note, THIS GAME IS IN ALPHA. If you can't deal with bugs, or losing your save game with each major update, or incomplete features, THEN DON'T BUY IT. If you can't deal with these issues then don't buy ANY early access game. At this point if you buy it the devs DON'T owe you a complete game. They do owe regular and reasonable progress towards a final product, and in a perfect world they should have open, 2-way communication with the community during this process. In my experience both of those are true. Mad props to the devs, they're doing a great job.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really liked this game, seriously, it used to run smoothly for me, it was fun to build, and graphics looked like they were improving (even thought I dont care how it looks, but was a nice improvment), and all around was a good game if you wanted to play zombie survival minecraft.

I wish that I could say the same now. When I left the game about 2-3 months ago (I was burned out playing it, moved to another game), the game ran perfectly, the loot system was great, and all around a solid game. Now if I try and play it, it lags like f***ing crazy, not network lag, LOW FPS LAG, on a computer with 16 gigs of ram and a 4gb graphics card and 6 core processor. This game should be running perfectly, but now it sucks. Not only that, somehow, the graphics are WORSE. So, worse graphics and a low FPS, when before, improved graphics and high FPS.....DOESNT MAKE SENSE TO ME.

Also, the loot system is now RUST. You hit a tree with an axe, you get wood EVERY TIME YOU HIT IT. Before, you had to chop down trees for logs which can then be crafted into planks and other things....Now you get wood every time you hit trees, dirt, rocks, god knows what else. This game is now an abomonation that needs to roll back these latest updates to fix what shouldnt have been messed with, cause now, Im playing 7 days to die, and now I feel like Im playing RUST.
